TALK.START.PARA: —Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows:

PETITION.TITLE: National Flag
PETITION.PARA: To the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:
We the undersigned draw to the attention of the Senate:
We are proud to fly the Australian Flag and will oppose any changes to it.
We support the Constitutional Monarchy and will oppose any moves to turn Australia into a Republic.
We believe in loyalty to the Crown and Nation, pride in the National Anthem and respect for our existing Australian Flag.
And your petitioners in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Commonwealth Threatened Species Bill
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.

The Commonwealth Threatened Species Bill recognises that Australia has the worst extinction record of native mammals of any country on Earth in recent history and that species extinctions are still occurring at an alarming rate.

Your Petitioners ask that the Senate should support Commonwealth Threatened Species legislation which uses the full powers given to it by the Australian Constitution and which provides the necessary financial resources to halt the loss of species on this, the oldest continent on earth.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Mabo
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:

PARA.TAB: We, the undersigned citizens of Australia, respectfully submit that:
The High Court's Mabo decision has caused division and dissension, uncertainty, resentment and economic damage in Australia.
Mabo will not solve the social, educational, housing and other problems of Aboriginal people.
Mabo is an attack on our Federal system of government, under which the absolute control of Crown lands and management of land titles have always rested with the States.

The only solution to Mabo is a referendum of the Australian people for a law to overrule the High Court and re-establish equal land rights for all Australians, under the normal procedures of State and Territory laws.
And we strongly urge the Senate to reject any other proposed solution.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Leaded Petrol
PETITION.PARA: To the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:

PARA.TAB: This petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia opposes the reduction of octane quality of leaded petrol from January 1994, resulting from the Government's `Lead Roundtable' meeting. The petitioners note particularly that this reduction in petrol quality:
(1) Jeopardises the use of vehicles made prior to 1986 for operation on high octane petrol and could lead to many of those vehicles suffering serious engine damage;
(2) Will result in worse vehicle operation, higher emissions and greater fuel consumption for up to three million vehicles;

(3) Will have negligible benefit to the community, through reduced lead emissions, because the oil industry proposes to leave lead levels in petrol unchanged in Victoria, South Australia and Western Australia, and because the use of leaded petrol already is rapidly decreasing;
(4) Will disadvantage vehicle enthusiasts and low income members of the community.

PETITION.PARA: And your petitioners therefore urge the Senate to take action to ensure the continued availability of high octane petrol for Australian motorists.

TALKER.NAME: Senator HILL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition)

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to speak briefly to that motion. What should be understood is that the government is substantially changing the program that it earlier set out. In particular, the Wet Tropics of Queensland World Heritage Area Conservation Bill is dropping down the list. I understand that that was as a result of a request from the Australian Democrats because of the ill health of Senator Coulter. We understand that and will cooperate in these unfortunate circumstances.

PARA.TAB: However, the government ought to realise that senators on this side have worked long and hard to prepare that bill for debate this morning. They worked late into the night last night and are ready. We were told it was coming on today. I hope the government understands that, if this is going to occur and at the last moment we are to be told that bills are no longer going to be debated in the order that we have been told earlier, this should be a give and take situation. Towards the end of last session, when we made a request in similar circumstances, the government objected to it.

Here we are at the beginning of the session and the government is already substantially changing the program it has set down. We respectfully ask that, if that is to happen in the future, we be given more notice than the notice we were given this morning. We also make the point that, if the government is going to ask for cooperation with substantial variations to its program, it should recognise that when we ask for such changes in reasonable circumstances and it ought to accommodate us.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support my leader's concern about this matter. I am sorry that Senator Coulter is ill and I wish him well and a speedy recovery. However, this is a concern to me. I understand that neither the Democrats nor the Greens are ready for this bill. I am handling it on behalf of Mrs Gallus and was not ready either, but I ensured that by doing some work last night my staff and I were able to get the matter under control.

PARA.TAB: It is of some concern that we find out this morning that it is not going on. I also note that the space bill is coming on a bit earlier. As a member of the Senate Standing Committee on Transport, Communication and Infrastructure which made a report on matters that I understand are being taken up in that bill, I wanted to speak on that legislation. However, I am not ready to do so now because I have been concentrating on this bill. I do not suppose that will receive much consideration from the Greens or the Democrats.

It concerns me that various factions of the Labor Party rearrange the program as they did yesterday to suit themselves. There are winks and nods all the way along and the three groups of the Labor Party look after themselves. We do not seem to be taken into account when these things are being considered.

I am concerned about this change in the order of business and not only the change in the position of the wet tropics bill, but also the change in the order of all those other bills in such a way that will cause disruption to us. It is no wonder that the government cannot run the country even with the help of its allies, the Democrats and the Greens, if it cannot even get the order of today's program correct.

TALK.START.PARA: —At the request of the Leader of the Opposition in the Senate (Senator Hill) and pursuant to contingent notice, I move:

PARA.TAB: That so much of standing orders be suspended as would prevent the Leader of the Opposition (Senator Hill) moving a motion relating to the conduct of the business of the Senate, namely a motion to give precedence to General Business notice of motion No. 556 standing in the name of Senator Campbell for this day, relating to an order for the production of documents by the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Gareth Evans) concerning property leases.

SPEECH.PARA: I have moved for the suspension of standing orders so that we can deal with the motion relating to the tabling of documents concerning Centenary House. This is a matter that I have pursued through the forums of both the estimates committees and the questions on notice provisions that we have. I have met with resistance from the government in relation to some key elements where the government has sought to substantiate the rent paid at Centenary House.

PARA.TAB: I think the government is being quite obstructionist in this matter and that this is a sensible way for crucial information in the Centenary House affair to be brought before the Senate. I seek the support of the Senate in the suspension of standing orders so that we can achieve the tabling of this information before the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Democrats will be supporting this motion in the fervent hope that it takes a very short time. We think what Senator Campbell has to say is quite reasonable, but we certainly do not want to spend a lot of time on it.

TALKER.NAME: Senator CROWLEY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Family Services)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Campbell Sen I.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of Senator Hill, I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1)That there be laid on the table of the Senate, by the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Gareth Evans), not later than immediately after question time on 10 February 1994, with respect to the leases referred to in paragraph (2), being leases claimed to be comparable in terms of net rental with the net rental paid at Centenary House, a statement of each of the following items of information:

TAB.TAB: (a)what is the address of the property;
(b)what is the net lettable area;
(c)what is the commencement date of the lease;
(d)what are the lease terms;
(e)what is the breakdown of the building outgoings on a per square metre per annum basis; and
(f)what is the effective value of the incentive.

SPEECH.PARA: (2)That the leases with respect to which information is ordered under paragraph (1) be as follows:

TAB.TAB: (a)June 1993—the pre-commitment lease in NSW where the rental is $462 per square metre gross ($420 per square metre net approximately), and
(b)May 1993—the pre-commitment lease in Victoria where the rental is $399 per square metre semi gross ($370 per square metre net approximately),

PARA.TAB: being the two leases referred to in the Australian Property Group answer to a question on notice given to Estimates Committee D in 1993.

SPEECH.PARA: During Estimates Committee D there was a lengthy debate about the rental, terms and conditions and processes by which the Australian National Audit Office entered into a lease in the building known as Centenary House and owned by the Australian Labor Party. I do not intend revisiting all of the arguments and the political controversy about that deal here today. There are other forums where that will be pursued.

PARA.TAB: However, during the inquiries at Estimates Committee D, ably supported by my colleagues Senator Parer and Senator Minchin, I sought information from the Australian Property Group and the Australian Valuation Office in relation to comparable rentals in Canberra. We also put to the Australian Property Group and the Australian Valuation Office the contention that, in the current property climate, this would be one of the highest effective net rentals in the whole of Australia, including all of the large commercial capital cities such as Sydney and Melbourne.

That is a contention I still hold, but it is something that is hard to establish unless we have information, and this is the information that we seek here today. It is information that we sought during the supplementary estimates process. The information has been partially provided by the Australian Property Group, but what we seek here is information which will actually help the Senate reach a conclusion on this important point.

At Estimates Committee D, I asked the officers whether they could find any evidence of any higher effective net rental anywhere in Australia, and in answer to that question the Australian Property Group officers provided me with a very short piece of information which is effectively no information. They said that they had found that in June 1993 there was a pre-commitment lease somewhere in New South Wales at $462 per square metre, and that somewhere in Victoria in May 1993 there was an effective rental of $399 per square metre.

When discussing this matter privately, Madam Acting Deputy President, I have said to colleagues that that would be very similar to someone coming to me and claiming that his house is worth $100,000 and, when I ask, `Why is that house worth $100,000?', saying to me, `I know that somewhere in Victoria a house was sold for $100,000'. Of course, it is very interesting to know that somewhere in Victoria a house sold for $100,000, but one needs to know whether that house is made of wood or stone, and whether it has got three bedrooms, four bedrooms or five bedrooms and what size land it is on. In fact, unless one knows all of the crucial details of the property, it is hard to establish the relevance of the fact that somewhere in Victoria a house was sold for $100,000.

When we come to commercial property, the same principles apply. It is no use saying that somewhere in New South Wales or Victoria a certain rental was set unless one knows where the building was, what sort of building it was, and how large the area was. As Senator Parer said to me this morning, one needs to know whether it was a street-front shop of only 50 square metres or whether it was a massive amount of space which might accommodate 200 or 300 people. Those are crucial pieces of information, and without that information the simple provision of a bland rate per square metre is of little help in our inquiries.

I have had it put to me that the government defends this by saying that it would offend the credibility of the Australian Property Group if it were to provide this information. Madam Acting Deputy President, I say that it is offensive to the credibility of the Australian Property Group to provide information to the Senate that has no credibility in terms of property professionals: that is, to provide a bland rental rate with no supporting evidence. It offends the credibility of that organisation that it would even seek to have senators accept that sort of information without at least some detail as to the relevance of the rental rate.

I seek further aspects of the information to determine what is known as the effective rental. I do not want to bore the Senate too much with what an effective net rental is, compared to what a net rental is, but most of my colleagues from Western Australia—and I see Senator Chamarette here—will know that during the late 1980s property developers went mad and ended up building a lot of very big buildings that no-one really needed. The developers have, in recent years, been offering people enormous inducements to attract them into the buildings. Those inducements can be free fit-outs, free partitioning and so forth; they can be free rental, which means that one can enter into a lease for 10 years and not pay any rent for five years; or they can be reduced rentals. There is a whole range of inducements that are being used to attract people to the empty buildings in Perth, Sydney and Melbourne.

Of course, that reduces the effective rental that is received by the landlord. If one is doing a comparison of rentals paid in a building where there was no incentive paid with those in a building where there was an incentive paid, it is very hard to say that one rental rate is comparable to another for the purposes of a valuation, because the bland rental that is put into the lease agreement may well not reflect the real rental value of that building. When it comes to taxation purposes, when it comes to local government ratings and water ratings and so forth, one needs to determine a figure that is a net effective rental, which is the real rental that is being paid to the landlord. I think that is the simplest explanation I can give of what an effective rental is.

To put it in more simple terms for people, when it comes to renting out houses, for example, if a person were to rent out his house for $200 a week but give away the first six months of that year as free rental to induce someone to come in and rent the house for a year, the effective rental would be only $100 a week instead of $200 since no rent would be received for the first six months. I think that is probably the simplest explanation of what an effective rental is.

In this information, we are seeking to find out the value of the inducements that may surround the thin information the APG has provided to the Senate. We need to know the value of those inducements; we need to know also the breakdown of the outgoings, the insurances and all the other amounts relating to the leases so that it is possible to determine what is the core rental that gets paid to the landlord, the Australian Labor Party, in that building. Then we can find out whether or not this is the highest net effective rental in the whole of Australia, which is what I suspect.

For these reasons, we have had to go to this further length to get what I consider to be quite simple and important information. I cannot understand why the Australian Property Group would not provide this information to the Senate. It is not commercial-in-confidence information. It certainly does not breach the confidentiality of APG customers, which the Minister for Administrative Services, Senator McMullan, said in his answer to my question on notice No. 889. This information, as I have said privately to the Democrats and to the Greens, is information that is readily handed across the counter at the Australian Valuation Office every morning to valuers and trainee valuers and their secretarial support. It is information that is handed across the counter at a state valuer-general's office.

When people are valuers or trainee valuers, as I was once many years ago, and they are seeking to do a valuation of a particular suburb or a particular building, they go to the government, be it state or federal, and they nicely ask whether it can provide them with recent information about rentals or leases or property sales in the area. They pay a small fee, which is usually to cover the photocopying. That information is provided, and it is provided without any questions being asked. It is outrageous that a junior trainee valuer, as I was many years ago, can go and get that information from a government agency such as the Australian Valuation Office or the Land Titles Office or the valuer-general's office of state governments, but that, for reasons considered confidential, the Australian Property Group will not provide that sort of information to the parliament of Australia in what is a genuine investigation into the credibility and confidence the Australian people should have in the property dealings of the federal government as they relate to the Centenary House deal.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support the motion moved by Senator Campbell. My reasoning is this: we have already had substantial debate on Centenary House, which I will not go over again, but in the process of that debate two points were made. One was the impropriety of a government in power arranging a lease deal which, on the face of it, had all the elements of secrecy that produce suspicion that a special deal has been made. The other part of it, and this is the nub of the points raised by Senator Campbell, is the question of accountability. What the department has done is try to fob off Senator Campbell in a very straightforward question. One of the most important aspects of the Centenary House deal was the level of rental paid, the escalation provisions and the net return to the Australian Labor Party. These lease conditions, which are not supported by the Department of Finance, are not just a cost to the government, a cost to the Auditor-General, but, ultimately, a cost to the Australian taxpayer.

PARA.TAB: Apart from the impropriety, and the view that the general public takes about deals being made by incumbent governments, if the rental is a fair rental we do not have a lot to object to. Just as an aside, honourable senators might recall that one of the greatest stirs that occurred when the Russians saw the light and chucked out the Communist Party was to do with the deals made on properties owned by the Communist Party that had been paid for by the Russian taxpayers. So it is a matter of propriety.

Let us get back to the motion moved by Senator Campbell. For the parliament to be able to determine whether a fair deal was made, we must know comparative costs paid by other clients of the Commonwealth government. It is a clear accountability that we are looking for. It is no good the department trying to fob off Senator Campbell and saying, `Here is the rental in Sydney', but refusing to give any other details on the basis—in my view, the phoney basis—that this is a matter of commercial-in-confidence. The Department of Administrative Services, the Australian Property Group and the Australian Valuation Office are accountable to this parliament, which represents the people of Australia, the taxpayers of Australia. To come along and say, `Here is the rental, but we will not give you any other details, so you cannot ascertain the net rental', is arrogance. It is the sort of arrogance we have come to expect in this country. It is important that the response be given.

As Senator Campbell indicated, what is wrong with the government telling us the address of a property which is rented by the Commonwealth? No wonder we had the suspicion right from the word go, when the then secretary of the Australian Labor Party, Mr Bob Hogg, denied that there was any deal made for the leasing of Centenary House, and when subsequent information provided by the minister himself indicated that when Mr Hogg made that remark at a committee hearing, in response to a question by then Senator Olsen, the deal was almost completed. That was, I might say, without the knowledge of the tenant, the Auditor-General. He did not even know at that stage that the ALP owned the place. He thought it was Lend Lease, because they kept referring to it as the Lend Lease site, or to the joint venturers.

What is wrong with the department advising Senator Campbell as to the address of the property? What is wrong with the department advising Senator Campbell and this parliament of the net lettable area? Surely that is not commercial-in-confidence? What is wrong with the government providing Senator Campbell and this parliament with the date of commencement of the lease? These are leases in respect of property in New South Wales and Victoria where the claim was made: `We have got a higher rental than we pay to the ALP at Centenary House'. What is wrong with giving us a breakdown of the building outgoings on a per square metre basis—this is normal information that is available—and the effective value of any incentives? As Senator Campbell has indicated, over the past couple of years, with the surplus of space available, all sorts of incentives have been paid. The only incentive paid on Centenary House has been to the ALP.

TALK.START.PARA: —Not true.

—It was the only incentive. The incentive there was: `If you go and build a building, we will give you an escalation rate until the building is completed, and then we will give you a guaranteed minimum escalation for 15 years'. I indicated earlier that we are not going to go back and rehash all that old stuff. We will get the opportunity again; and I understand that there could be an inquiry into it anyway by the Auditor-General.

PARA.TAB: The point I would like to make—and it is a very important point—is that, whether this government likes it or not, it is accountable to this parliament, which is accountable to the people of Australia, the taxpayers who are paying the bill. If the government has nothing to be concerned about, why did it not provide this information to a very simple question raised by Senator Campbell? The purpose of this motion is to insist that the government provide that information so that proper and sensible comparisons can be made.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to raise a couple of details that relate to this question, and I would ask the Minister for Administrative Services (Senator McMullan) to listen very carefully to the questions I am posing because the Democrats' position will depend very much on his answer. In a brief discussion I had with the minister when this debate started—as honourable senators know, the Democrats supported this issue being brought on here and now—I was told, first of all, that the leases were still at a stage where negotiation was being carried out. In other words, they were not concluded, finished leases; they were still leases under negotiation and under discussion. I rely on that statement. Would the minister confirm that?
—No, you must have misunderstood something I said. I will speak to that.
—It says here `pre-commitment lease'. To me that tends to indicate that the lease has not yet been concluded and has not been fully signed. But perhaps the minister can explain that.

PARA.TAB: The argument was then put to me that APG, the Australian Property Group, is now in the commercial property market, similar to a real estate agent, and that it would disadvantage the Australian Property Group in its legitimate commercial activities if it were forced to disclose information at a sensitive stage. It is, and was, my view—and I put it to the minister—that, if a commercial agency concludes a contract which raises financial obligations on behalf of a government department, on behalf of the government, this chamber is entitled to ask for those details.

I do not believe that commercial confidentiality extends to a commercial contract that is concluded on behalf of, by or for a government authority. However, I am prepared to accept that, until such an obligation is finally confirmed—signed, sealed and delivered, as it were—then that obligation, that contract, that commercial activity, is still in the commercial arena. I am prepared, therefore, to accept the argument that to then disclose it would disadvantage APG in its legitimate commercial activities. I believe that is the nub of the argument, and I would like the minister to give us a clear answer to that one.

The other point raised by the minister was in answer to a question of mine as to whether the government would be prepared to supply this information asked for by Senator Campbell to the Auditor-General's nominee who is conducting an inquiry into the Centenary House matter. I ask the minister to be quite clear on that. Has the inquiry started? Is it proceeding? At what stage is it? Is there an inquiry? If the answer is that an inquiry may be conducted—I note that Senator Parer used that expression; I do not know whether he is correct—can the minister confirm that an inquiry is actually in progress or has been irrevocably committed?

If such an inquiry is in existence and if the government undertakes, through the minister today, that these materials will be disclosed to the Auditor-General's nominee conducting an inquiry, then I believe that is another and very important and weighty factor which would affect our decision.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise briefly to speak on this motion. Quite frankly, we are not au fait with the ins and outs of the issue, which is one reason why we supported the suspension of standing orders—in order to hear a bit more on the request Senator Campbell has made. I remain unconvinced that there is a good reason not to comply with Senator Campbell's request, though I am more than willing to hear what the government has to say in regard to that. However, unless I hear such very good reason, I am prepared to support Senator Campbell's request, on the principle that the disclosure of information should be directed to the public interest.

PARA.TAB: The Greens are interested in transparency in government and a responsibility to be open to scrutiny. Therefore, in the spirit of encouraging a greater degree of openness to the people of Australia via this parliament, I would like to support yet another motion that is asking the government to make available a document which, it seems from the discussion that has ensued, is a perfectly legitimate request.

TALKER.NAME: Senator McMULLAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Trade and Minister for Administrative Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —In some sense, Senator Spindler, Senator Chamarette and I have been put at a bit of a disadvantage in the sequence in which this matter has been debated. I think there was an apprehension that, if I spoke, in some way it closed the debate, and therefore everyone spoke before my argument was heard. I have to say that that is not true; it is not my motion, so my speaking to it does not close the debate. It might have been better had I been called earlier, but I did not want to have a row about that. If those honourable senators wanted the call earlier, I was happy to comply. But let me just urge them—as they have indicated they will, which I appreciate—to approach that which I say with an open mind.

PARA.TAB: I accept the commitment they have and, on the basis of the work we have done together over the years, I hope they accept that I share a commitment to accountability of the executive government to this parliament. There is no doubt that all of us, whether we are ministers or public servants, who are paid by the taxpayers have an obligation to be accountable to those people whose money we appropriate to fund services, some of which are provided to us as income—opposition, government, minor parties, et cetera.

While I have sought to argue on previous occasions, probably when I was on the back bench and certainly as parliamentary secretary, and as minister on two or three occasions, that there were times when I thought the parliament was seeking to exercise its rights in a manner that I thought was inappropriate, that is not to say that the right should not exist. I do not regard it as some breach of principle to say that a parliament has a right to do something—that right is acknowledged; but then the view is that it should not exercise it in these circumstances. That means that one has to think about the consequences of acting or failing to act.

In judging whether it is appropriate to exercise an undoubted right, one needs always to contemplate the consequences of exercising it. Would the Senate, for example, by failing to support Senator Campbell's motion, in some way undermine its right on a subsequent occasion to seek information which it desired? The answer is quite clearly no. The Senate's right to demand information is clearly established otherwise.

There are two or three issues here, and I will respond to the explicit points Senator Spindler raised. The first and primary one is the question of commercial-in-confidence. At the end of the day, it is not the most powerful argument in this particular instance, but it is the general point that is before us. I think there is a more powerful argument about how we should decide on this matter on this day, which I will come to in a moment and to which Senator Spindler alluded, relating to the independent inquiry.

I have a view which I think some, but not all, in this Senate share about the legitimate role of public enterprise and public sector businesses in a mixed economy. To take previously exclusively government departmental activities, turn them into business-like operations, free their clients—the other public sector agencies—from the requirement to use their services and make them compete with the private sector, which has undoubted efficiency advantages, is an approach that some in the opposition might wish to go further. But I think it is an approach which, while those things are in the public sector, they would generally support. They might say that the businesses should not exist—that is an ideological debate we will have on another occasion—but, for so long as they are in the public sector, I think generally they would share the view that that is a way of using the competitive pressure to deliver the best outcome for the clients and to maximise the efficiency of the public sector agency, which now does not operate from budget appropriation but which is required to meet its costs through the income and fees it generates.

If we are going to take that step, we have to give those public sector businesses fair and reasonable opportunity to compete and a reasonable opportunity to be successful. We have to distinguish here between the role of the tenant and the role of the agent. Because I do not know the detail of the contract, I cannot say this for certain, but if, as I assume, the tenants in these two cases are public sector tenants, Australian government tenants, then no such public sector agency could resist an inquiry from the Senate that it should provide the details of a lease into which it has entered. It is spending the taxpayers' money and is accountable for it.

That is not the same as saying that, because the clients happened through a competitive process to choose a public sector agent to represent them, it is reasonable that the agent should have to disclose the clients' business. If they had chosen a private sector real estate agent, the Senate would not be saying that the private sector real estate agent has to disclose his or her or their client's business. We do not do that. We do say to the public sector agencies, `You have to supply', and they do. They have to come before estimates committees and be questioned about it. But it is a dramatically different argument to say that, in a competitive environment, if one chooses to be represented by a public sector agency, one does so in the knowledge that the parliament might require the agent to supply the client's information to it. One has a choice between a public sector agent who might, if the Senate is so minded, be required to supply one's information to the parliament, and some other agent who will not have that obligation.

That is the argument I was putting. If because of the pressure of time I put it to Senator Spindler in a way that gave him a slightly wrong impression about the status of these contracts, I apologise. I do not know, but on the information that is before me, on the written face of the document, it seems to me that these are finalised contracts. I was not arguing that they were not. Because I do not know every dot and comma, there may be some element that is not finalised. But that is not part of my argument, nor is it relevant to the point I am seeking to make. I understand that there would be a different status if they were not finalised. That is not the point I am seeking to make.

I am not seeking to hang my argument on that hook. The point I am making in regard to that matter applies to finalised contracts as well as to others. It will simply lead people not to choose the public sector agency and make it unviable, and I do not understand whose interests that is perceived to be in.

The second point is whether the failure to provide this extra level of detail makes it impossible for the Senate to discharge its function of accountability. In the first instance, I think the answer is no. The information provided in response to the original question, which is listed in the material distributed by Senator Campbell on this occasion or which was certainly on the Notice Paper and given to him previously—I think he refers to it in the question—was that the two leases in respect of which he is seeking further information are examples of effective net rental. The problem for him is that they give the answer he did not want. So he is trying to dig a bit further to see whether he can undermine the accuracy of that information.

The point at issue is whether there are comparable leases to the lease of Centenary House. It is a matter of judgment whether they are reasonable leases or not. As to whether they are comparable, the answer is clearly yes. The information necessary to establish that has already been provided. It is possible, and if no other avenue is available it is reasonable, because it is of concern to the Senate, to ask, `How can we be sure that these people are telling the Senate the truth?'. I do not have any reason to doubt them. To be fair to Senator Campbell, he has never implied, in the estimates committee or anywhere else, that he has reason to doubt the integrity of the officers who supplied the information. Although there have been some slurs thrown around, to be fair to Senator Campbell, he has not done that with regard to those officers or to any other officer, in the recollection I have. So I was not meaning to imply that he had done so.

There is no reason to doubt the integrity of the information that has been supplied, but we do have available to the parliament an opportunity to scrutinise this information without putting in jeopardy the question of commercial confidentiality. If the opportunity did not exist, we would be confronted with a very difficult dilemma because there would be a conflict of principles. In this instance, there is a conflict of principle already. There are two good arguments, but I think there is a mechanism that reconciles them. That is the independent inquiry to which I referred. It has not commenced but the terms of reference have been agreed. I forget the term Senator Spindler used, but there is no possibility that it will not go ahead. Should we wish to, and we do not, it is not open to the executive government to stop it going ahead, because the Auditor-General has the independent capacity to pursue it. Even if we said, `We do not want you to do that', which we have not said, he would proceed anyway. The legislation gives us no capacity to stop him having this inquiry. We do not want to stop him.

TALK.START.PARA: —Even though Ralph Willis did his best.

—That is absolutely untrue. We do not wish to stop him. This is going at a bit of a tangent, but I will respond to Senator Campbell's point to ensure that there is no unfairness to Mr Willis. I have very strongly supported Mr Willis in this, quite explicitly. We have expressed our concern to the Auditor-General. We have said that we do not think something conducted exclusively by the Auditor-General is appropriate because one of those people under review, whose actions are involved in this matter and therefore must be under review, is the Auditor-General, and he should not inquire into himself.

PARA.TAB: So what Mr Willis put, and what is agreed between the Minister for Finance and the Auditor-General, is that there should be an inquiry conducted jointly in part by his nominee under the Audit Act and Mr MacPherson, the South Australian Auditor-General, and one by the Independent Auditor of the Auditor-General, Mr Boymal, whose integrity I think is not in question. Therefore, somebody who is seen to be independent of the Auditor-General is looking into this matter; so there is independent assessment of everybody's actions in it, which I think is appropriate.

These issues of the appropriateness of the contract are covered by the terms of reference. I give an unequivocal undertaking to Senator Spindler that I will make this information available to that inquiry so that, if there are concerns about the adequacy or accuracy of that information, they can report. One part of the terms of reference that has been agreed is that the committee will have the right to report to the parliament—not just to us so that we can shred it, bury it or do whatever people feel we may otherwise wish to do with it. Of course, the Auditor-General does report to the parliament, so if this committee wishes—and I expect it will, but we are not telling it what it has to do—to report directly to the parliament and to say that the information provided to Senator Campbell in response to his previous question in the Senate Hansard was inaccurate, it has that capacity independently to do so.

The parliament has available to it the opportunity to have on its behalf an effective, independent, confidential scrutiny of this without cutting across the commercial-in-confidence rights of APG. If we did not have that, I accept that we would be in a bit of a dilemma and that the Senate would have to resolve it. I sense from the remarks here that it would resolve it against the view I take. I understand that argument. I do not totally share it, but I do understand that.

There is a proper concern about guaranteeing and protecting the proper rights of the parliament to ensure that the information supplied to it by the executive is accurate; that is an unquestioned right. How we exercise it is a matter for our judgment on each occasion, but I do not seek in any way to undermine that right. I could not if I wished to, but I do not wish to in any way. Firstly, there is a question of principle. Secondly, I have lived with the democratic process long enough to know that nobody is in government forever. We would wish to be able to exercise the right to pursue information from the executive in the event that we were to return to opposition. I regret to say that I know one day we eventually will, and for so many years of my public life we were. It seemed that that was going to go on forever as well, and I am grateful that it did not.

So that inquiry will go ahead. Even if they do not ask for it, I will take the initiative of providing this information to those independent inquirers. They have the capacity to report back to the parliament. I expect them to. I cannot say that they will because they may choose not to for some reason that I cannot imagine. So I cannot give the Senate a guarantee. They have the right to do that if they so choose, and I expect they will.

I think the Senate's reasonable concerns can be covered without jeopardising the commercial entitlements of the Australian Property Group. A further and reasonably imminent opportunity to review whether the actions I have outlined are adequate will arise. I should have made the point earlier that the agreement between the minister and the Auditor-General is that that inquiry should report by 12 April. So if we are not satisfied with the information, or the inquiry, or the adequacy, we are not going to have very long to wait before the Senate has a further opportunity.

For those reasons, I hope the Senate will not choose to pursue this motion further on this occasion. If the Senate wishes to make it absolutely clear that it is keeping open to it the right to pursue this further, it is perhaps open to it to defer consideration until the report from this inquiry. I would not resist that motion. People can make it absolutely clear that the sword of Damocles is overhead, but I do not feel threatened by it because I am comfortable with that resolution. It is not, of course, my preferred option; I would prefer to see it defeated, but I would not resist that compromise option if—I suppose it could only be Senator Campbell because it is his motion—the Senate were minded to proceed in that way. Alternatively, it could easily, within 24 hours, reactivate the resolution after 12 April if he is not satisfied with the outcome of the inquiry.

TALK.START.PARA: —First of all, Mr Acting Deputy President, I congratulate Senator McMullan on a masterful speech. As he is very well versed in doing, he has completely ignored the question and, with a very skilful speech, moved away from the questions Senator Spindler and Senator Chamarette wanted answered. It was quite masterful, but I do not think Senator Spindler or Senator Chamarette will be fooled by it. I will quickly run through some of the points. Senator Campbell will conclude the debate, and he will go through these as well.

PARA.TAB: We come at this issue from a background of what is possibly the greatest scandal ever in Australian public life; that is, a political party in government getting from the taxpayer money to fund its political activities. The Australian Labor Party, which happens to be in government at the current time, will receive a sum reputed by some to be $35 million over the next decade.

I can understand Senator McMullan's real sensitivity to this, because it is all done by the federal secretariat of the ALP, of which Senator McMullan was for many years the federal secretary. I do not in any way suggest that Senator McMullan personally was involved in these deals, because I think at the time he had left the position of federal boss of the ALP secretariat. I think at the time he was in parliament, but no doubt he knows all about this issue. He knows the workings of the ALP federal secretariat, and he would be very sensitive to it.

Coming from that background, I refer to the three questions Senator Spindler asked. Senator Spindler was somewhat persuaded by what he thought Senator McMullan said to him, which was that the lease was in the course of negotiation and was at a sensitive stage. Senator McMullan has clearly said that that is not the case. As far as Senator McMullan is concerned, it is over and done with. That answered Senator Spindler's first two questions in a way that I think would have Senator Spindler conclude that he should support our motion.

In answer to Senator Spindler's third question—whether he would supply that information to the Auditor-General—Senator McMullan said he would. He has given that undertaking, and by doing so he hopes he can get Senator Spindler to say that the parliament does not need to get it because Senator McMullan will give it to the Auditor-General. I have no doubt that Senator McMullan will give it to the Auditor-General; but why can we not have a look at it, too, as representatives of the people? We may want to make some interpretation, some calculations, and perhaps some submissions in relation to it. There is, in my view, no reason why we cannot get it if the Auditor-General can.

I come back to the basic point of Senator McMullan's discourse—that is, that the matter is commercial-in-confidence and that it would adversely affect the commercial ability of the Australian Property Group to get into the field as a commercial enterprise. I reiterate, particularly for the benefit of Senator Spindler and Senator Chamarette, what Senator Campbell said.

TALK.START.PARA: —I certainly do not need your advice, although I am grateful for the time you are devoting to the issue. However, I can assess the situation, thank you.

—I will be even briefer, then. I was just going to say that I can confirm what Senator Campbell has said from my experience as a property lawyer for many years. If the lease is concluded, and if we know the names of the parties, we can simply go along to the New South Wales titles office, get a copy of the lease and find all this out. How does that relate to Senator McMullan's argument of commercial-in-confidence? That material, once the lease is registered, is available to anyone, so it in no way affects the commercial-in-confidence ability of the Australian Property Group.

PARA.TAB: The Australian Property Group is in exactly the same position as Jones Lang Wootton, L.J. Hooker or any of them. Once the lease is registered, all the details are there for any member of the public to go along and get them. So if we can get it from there, why can we not get it from the minister? What is his argument about commercial-in-confidence? I gather from what Senator Spindler says that he does not need my assistance any more on this. He has obviously woken up to Senator McMullan's very skilful attempt to divert attention. I think the other parties are well aware of the baselessness of his argument.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply—I will try to be as brief as I can. Senator Macdonald has very helpfully covered some of the points. I agree with the Minister for Administrative Services, Senator McMullan, in some respects: there is a very subtle balance that needs to be found in these matters. None of us would seek, regardless of our judgments about the commercialisation of DAS businesses, to jeopardise them. Indeed, that would hurt the interests of the Australian taxpayer because the businesses would be less successful, and they might need higher subsidies, property adjustment programs, staff adjustment programs and everything else to make them operate successfully. I did listen very carefully, and I know Senator Spindler and Senator Chamarette did also. I remain unconvinced that the balance falls on the side Senator McMullan seeks. He has confirmed that these are both public sector tenants—and we did not even know that until we had this debate today. We were not sure who the tenants were.
—I did not know either.

—I know, and this is the problem I am dealing with. I have diligently—to describe what I think my actions have been—pursued this matter. I have not sought to overly politicise it, to the extent that I can restrain myself. We are seeking information that is important. The frustration I have is that every time I put a question on notice to Senator McMullan about this or any other issue I get these short answers and excuses as to why I cannot get any more answers. I get to the stage where I think that, if I keep asking Senator McMullan and his department questions, sooner or later they will get the message that it is probably better to give a fuller answer in the first place, rather than having me go back every 30 days and ask for supplementary information. They might get the message sooner or later that it is better just to come a bit clean and be a little more accountable, so that we do not have to spend an hour on a Thursday morning seeking information that is readily available through other places, of course.

PARA.TAB: Senator Macdonald has dealt with the argument about private sector real estate agents. I think there is, however, some validity to Senator McMullan's argument that there is a slight difference between the two and that we are, in this circumstance, requiring the APG to provide information that people such as Jones Lang Wootton or L.J. Hooker would not have to provide. However, because they are dealing with public sector tenants, those public sector tenants could be required to provide that information to the parliament at any stage anyway. That is because at estimates we know the property operating expenses of all of the agencies and departments, and it is open to any senator to ask for the details of those property operating expenses. We can get that detail whenever we want. It just sometimes takes a bit of time, as it is doing here.

I also think this information I am seeking is not of much relevance to the inquiry that I was pleased to hear Senator McMullan announce will be occurring into the Centenary House affair. It is not information that is really germane to that inquiry. I think it is a waste of that inquiry's time to have this information. But, as Senator Macdonald said, it is information that I regard as important, and I think it is information the Senate will be interested to know. We do need to know more of these details. We do need to analyse all of these other aspects to see whether, as I contended, this was one of the highest net effective rentals negotiated in the whole of Australia at that time.

Senator McMullan raised the point about credibility. I do not suspect at all the motives of the Australian Property Group or the accuracy of the information it provides, but it has provided only a bland figure of four hundred and something dollars per square metre. Senator McMullan was indeed wrong in saying that the answer was not the answer I wanted to receive; it was the answer I suspected. But the answer is of little value to me because I cannot make a judgment as to what the figures really mean until I know the other information. I think the Senate has a right to know that.

Another point that needs to be made relates to the commercialisation of the DAS business units. In some business units there has been a very successful commercialisation; in others it has been less successful. The parliament has got a job to ensure that that whole process is accountable, but we also must make sure that those business units remain accountable. Just because they are in the commercial field, we cannot absolve them from accountability.

Unfortunately, we had this ongoing debate between Senator McMullan and me and others on Estimates Committee D about the pros and cons of the business units operating in the commercial field. Senator McMullan says that they suffer lots of disadvantages, just as the businesses they compete against in the true commercial world suffer disadvantages. Of course, one of the disadvantages of a government-owned business unit is that it has to suffer a little more accountability, but it would be very wrong for the parliament to absolve it from that accountability just because it is owned by the government.
I think they are the important points to cover, and I think that really concludes the debate. I urge honourable senators to support my motion.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill received from the House of Representatives.
Motion (by Senator McMullan) agreed to:
That this bill may proceed without formalities and be now read a first time.
Bill read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McMullan Sen The Hon R.F.

TALKER.NAME: Senator McMULLAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Trade and Minister for Administrative Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That this bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.PARA: I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.
The speech read as follows—
The purpose of this bill is to amend the Higher Education Funding Act 1988 in accordance with decisions made by the Government in respect of higher education.

SPEECH.PARA: This bill provides funding of $12.9 million in 1996, rising to $35.2 million in 1999, for an additional 1500 undergraduate student places, including 500 to be funded jointly with industry. These new places are part of the Government's strategy for dealing with the continuing strong demand for higher education and significant regional shortages in the provision of higher education opportunities. This increase raises the total of new places created by the Government between 1989 and 1998 to over 100,000.

The Government announced during the Budget that the period of rapid growth of funding in the sector had finished and that other mechanisms needed to be developed to ensure the efficient and effective use of public funding in maintaining a high quality higher education sector. As part of this strategy the Government recently foreshadowed that it will be looking to shift some currently allocated places within and across States on the basis of institutional performance. Criteria for reallocating the places will be developed in full consultation with the higher education sector.
The bill also provides for higher education funding adjustments to cover the areas of superannuation, support for redundancy payments, and the Open Learning Initiative.

The bill's provisions include financial adjustments to funding for higher education superannuation expenses of $23.3 million in 1994, $12.9 million in 1995 and $15.5 million in 1996. The additional funding is being provided to institutions to meet the costs arising from the implementation of the Superannuation Guarantee Levy.

Under another measure introduced in this bill and in line with the Teacher Education Development Strategy, the Government will assist universities by supporting redundancy payments to excess staff. The Government will advance higher education operating grants for this purpose from 1995 and 1996 into 1994 and 1995, respectively, on advice from institutions.

The Open Learning Initiative reflects the Government's commitment to increasing access to higher education. Funding for individual years will be adjusted to better reflect the cash flows in those years while maintaining the total funding of $52m over the 1993-95 period.
The bill's provisions include amendments to the Higher Education Contribution Scheme (HECS). These changes aim to improve the operation and administration of the scheme.

This bill will correct an anomaly whereby certain fully funded overseas aid students are currently liable for HECS. The bill also clarifies the classification of student's course load units incorporating work experience in industry. Guidelines will be provided to further assist institutions to clarify work experience units.

Other measures put forward in this bill will improve the arrangements for quoting Tax File Numbers (TFN), and clarify the responsibilities of institutions, students and the Commissioner of Taxation in regard to the notification of TFNs for the HECS.
All the measures put forward in this bill are designed to promote efficiency and effectiveness in higher education. They will help improve administration in the areas covered by the bill.

PARA.TAB: Debate (on motion by Senator McGauran) adjourned.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Troeth Sen J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Guidelines for Determination of Eligible Child Care Centres (Childcare Assistance), CCA/4B/93/2, made under subsection 4C(1) of the Child Care Act 1972 with respect to the Minister's powers under subsection 4B(2) of that Act, be disallowed.

SPEECH.PARA: On behalf of the coalition, I wish to initiate this debate to disallow the guidelines for the determination of eligible child-care centres. Since this matter was discussed late last year in this place, and indeed even while that debate was taking place, there has been considerable disquiet within the industry regarding child-care guidelines. I feel that it is the duty of the opposition to express this disquiet so that further consideration can be given to the impact of the legislation. For that reason I have moved this disallowance motion.

PARA.TAB: With the numbers of working parents who need to place their children in child care, cost is going to be a determining factor as to where children are placed. With the implementation of the guidelines as outlined, there will obviously be some extra cost to the centres involved. The estimates of cost increases vary from the extremely low level increases cited by Senator Crowley to the far more realistic increases cited by independent consultants. The costings we have looked at are those by J.F. Taylor and Co. Pty Ltd, sponsored by the Association of Child Care Centres for New South Wales; Johnston Rorke, sponsored by the Australian Confederation of Child Care; and Shaw and Gay Pty Ltd, sponsored by the Child Care Association of Victoria. Senator Crowley maintained in this place on Tuesday that the increase in costs put forward by Senator Boswell had nothing to do with accreditation. Why then have the consulting firms used these figures?

I would now like to indicate some of the costings involved if child-care centres are to adopt the child-care guidelines. J.F. Taylor did two cost modellings on long day care centres with 23 and 38 places. This consulting firm raised very important questions as to the accuracy of the Pitcher Partners study, on which Senator Crowley is basing her figure of a 55c increase. The J.F. Taylor study states:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the limitations inherent in the Pitcher Partners approach (which they themselves acknowledge) cast doubts upon the validity of their cost estimate. These limitations include representativeness of sample, representativeness of the survey period, the lack of adult responses, arbitrary disqualification of so-called `extreme cases' and spreading of the seven week costs over fifty weeks (and thereby ignoring requirements which need to be conducted on a daily/weekly/monthly etc. ongoing basis).

J.F. Taylor, by comparison, admits that its figures are extremely conservative and not at all exhaustive. It also notes that significant cost differences may arise due to the `subjective application of the principles, i.e. different accreditation teams may derive different standards for the same centres due to the "fuzziness" of the terminology employed in the principles'. Its conservative costings estimate that additional costs of child care per child per week will be $33 in a low case scenario and $69 in a high case scenario. I will quote from the analysis.

PARA.TAB: These are some examples that I would like to give the Senate and the Australian public of the costs that could be incurred by a child-care centre as a result of the accreditation guidelines being implemented. For a centre to maintain a full immunisation record which is updated as appropriate, estimating one hour per week for each staff member, the costing could be up to $689. For staff being encouraged to complete a first aid certificate, supposing that one staff member attends the St John Ambulance course run for two consecutive days from 8.30 to 4.30, followed by a two-hour exam two weeks later, the cost of the course could be $110 and the cost of relief staff for 10 hours, $227.

Let us suppose that the staff are encouraged to attend courses relating to adult and child health issues. Five three-hour courses on a Saturday morning, with three hours overtime for all staff, could cost up to $2,217. If staff meet regularly to discuss adult and child health issues and also consult with parents, the cost of overtime for all staff at eight hours per annum, which is indeed a conservative estimate, could be $1,064.

One of the guidelines refers to the use of picture books which are not stereotyped. Let us imagine that the child-care centre mentioned needs to throw out most of its library and obtain library books and picture books for children which do not contain gender bias. Even if it had a small number of books to buy, at $100, depreciated at 7.5 per cent, the cost would be $8. Most child-care centres, I imagine, would need to update their libraries at a vastly greater increased cost than that.

Consultation with parents regarding a realistic set of guidelines for children's behaviour would usually need to be out of hours. Out-of-hours meetings with all staff at, say, eight hours per annum could cost $1,064. Yet another accreditation guideline is for information to be translated into the home language of the families. There are 10 languages recommended by the department of immigration. The cost of a translator at $70 per page, assuming that there were 10 pages and 10 languages, would be $7,000.

I could give further descriptions of the way in which the costs will be carried on through this process of accreditation, but with application of the 52 principles involved it would be a lengthy and laborious process. I think the Senate will gather the implications of what I have been saying through some of the figures I have been quoting.

Given these costs, how is it that Senator Crowley can use the figure of a 55c increase in costs per child per week in South Australia? How is this possible? Is the government going to absorb the cost and reduce the number of places available or will this cost be passed on to parents? The consulting firm of Shaw and Gay Pty Ltd concludes:

SPEECH.PARA: All child care centres with registered places of 45 children or less will trade at a loss, resulting in a significant drop in the number of private child care places provided within a 12 month period from implementation of the Accreditation System.

If the cost is to be passed on to parents, there is every reason to suppose that parents will seek alternative avenues of child care and seek the assistance of neighbours, friends or unscrupulous backyard operators.

PARA.TAB: There are other concerns about the cost of measurement of the system. The Senate has had placed before it widely differing estimates of cost. There will be divergent estimates since the principles involved in accreditation can be subject to the widest possible interpretation. For instance, looking at some of the phrases I have used already, what does `continuous monitoring and evaluation of program' involve? How continuous is continuous? In the phrase `positive relationships', how positive is positive? Should consultation with parents be face to face or can it be dealt with over the phone? How often should it occur? We need an independent inquiry into the whole question of standards for child-care centres, not the regimented application of draconian principles.
On 10 March last year, in yet another example of Labor's broken promises, Peter Staples said:

SPEECH.PARA: No service will need or be required to put on new staff, increase qualified staff, buy new equipment or in any way incur costs because of accreditation.

In view of the material I have outlined, how could this be so? I have already discussed some specific costs that accreditation will entail. More generally, accreditation will incur three different types of additional costs. The first can be described as salary related—that is, additional wages paid to staff for duties which would have to be performed out of normal hours or paid to relief staff for duties or activities which would have to be undertaken during normal operating hours.

PARA.TAB: For example, principle 43 requires the centre to maintain a record of children's immunisations. This would require a minimum of one hour's extra work per week for each staff member. Principle 48 concerns staff and parents consulting on the program and evaluating its effectiveness together. It is very difficult to assess the extra cost this would entail as the guidelines suggest only that evaluation be done frequently enough to ensure that the program remains relevant to the needs and interests of a particular group of children, whatever that means. The lowest possible cost estimate would work out at an extra eight hours per annum for each staff member.

Secondly, accreditation will involve extra operational costs, for example, course fees. Principle 47 requires that information on health and other related issues is readily available to staff. It is suggested, among other things, that staff complete a first aid certificate. Costs then incurred would result from the cost of the course and the cost of relief staff or, if the course was done in the member's own time, overtime for each staff member. Principle 50 necessitates that staff are provided with regular learning and training opportunities. The conferences and seminars, short courses, training workshops, et cetera, which are suggested in the guidelines are ways to achieve this extra training and will all place a higher cost burden on each centre.

Thirdly, we can pinpoint areas where capital expenditure will be necessary, such as the purchase of additional equipment and increased investment in building or other equipment. Principle 3 requires that centres stock only books without gender bias or stereotyping. Principle 10 requires that information be translated into the home language of families. The Ethnic Affairs Commission suggests that public documents be translated into 10 different languages. The Taylor and Co. analysis works out that the cost of a translator is $70 per page, so just 10 pages of information in 10 languages would cost $7,000.

The Sydney Rescue Work Society is reluctant to make definite calculations about the increase in the cost per week of child care, because it feels that the guidelines are so vague as to make accurate costing difficult. However, it estimates that it will lead to an increase of between $20 and $30 per week per child. Not only that, the centre has grave reservations about the principles outlined in the guidelines.

For example, principle No. 1 says that staff must be genuinely interested in the children. How is `genuinely interested' assessed? In whose judgment? Should all staff who work at child-care centres be required to have a genuine interest in children, even if they do not interact with them? What about cleaners and administrators, who may not even have contact with the children?

The public position of the Sydney Rescue Work Society—and, I gather, of many other organisations—is that since the legislation has been passed it will go along with it. Its private position, however, is unchanged. It is still fundamentally opposed to the legislation. So we have the unhappy position of an industry fundamentally opposed to legislation but being forced to go along with it. Indeed, Mr Acting Deputy President, we have seen many examples of that in the entire government legislation program even in the short time that I have been in this place.

We are talking here about one of the fundamental tasks of a society: that of ensuring that the next generation is prepared for adulthood by caring, concerned representatives of this generation. A child-care centre must qualify under the accreditation guidelines before parents sending their children to the centre can qualify for fee relief. If the centre is forced to raise fees because of the onerous financial burden of compliance with the guidelines, many parents will be unable to afford the facilities and will resort to other forms of child care.

As with so much of this government's legislation, the law turns out to have most financial impact on those groups in the community that the government should be trying to assist. We saw that on Tuesday with the petrol tax increase which the Treasurer, Mr Willis, admitted was hurting low income earners most; and we see it today with this child-care legislation.

In spite of Senator Crowley's protestations that the costings by independent accounting firms of implementation of the accreditation scheme have `nothing to do with accreditation'—and I quote from her answer to Senator Boswell in question time in this place on Tuesday—these groups are using the figures. Why? Senator Crowley quoted in her remarks a figure from South Australia which put the cost per child of accreditation at 55c. How is this possible? There is an enormous disparity between those figures presented by the government and those presented by a significant number of groups in the industry. The disparity is such as to prompt the coalition to call for a disallowance of the child-care guidelines, and to call for a totally fresh look at the way in which child-care centres can maintain sufficient standards and the way in which parents who are in need can qualify for fee relief.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boswell Sen R.L.D.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOSWELL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President, the government has shown great ineptitude in the handling of this issue of child-care accreditation. At first it provoked outrage over the guidelines, but that is not the argument today. Criticism was levelled at their intrusiveness and so-called political correctness not only from the National and Liberal parties but from clergy, parents and child-care centres, and from former Labor finance minister Peter Walsh. Mr Walsh described the handbook as 120-odd pages of platitudes, internal contradictions, nonsense and worse.

PARA.TAB: Let us concede that, from Senator Chamarette's and the Democrats' point of view, the accreditation is something that they desperately want. Let us concede that and move into the area of cost. As we dig deeper into the whole affair, however, there are emerging very serious defects in the proposed administration of the accreditation scheme which can be considered quite independently of one shade of political correctness—the Greens, the Democrats, the National Party or the Liberal Party.

Firstly, the cost of the scheme: 88c a week per child, says Senator Crowley. The South Australian Child Care Association says that its centres will have to put on two extra staff just to cope with the paperwork. There is $16 a week per child straight off. But the minister sticks to her guns and says 88c a week.

The Queensland Child Care Association commissioned accountants to do the costing and they came up with an additional cost of $16, despite recent Queensland regulations implementing similar guidelines which have already bumped up their cost by around $30 a week. Eighty-eight cents a week, says the minister, backed up by a seven-week pilot study of 1.4 per cent of the centres' populations. The consultants, Pitcher and Partners, themselves acknowledge that the conclusions which can be drawn from the survey are limited by the relatively small sample. Further, four extreme cases which incurred significant unpaid hours were excluded from the final average costs estimate, with no rational explanation supplied other than the comment that they were difficult to understand.

The New South Wales Child Care Association also commissioned independent costings and found that its costs would rise from $40 to $69 a week per child, depending on the centre. `No', says the minister, `I am right and you are wrong. It is 88c a week'. We have pleaded with the minister, Senator Crowley, to appoint an independent arbitrator to work through the different costings and arrive at some common ground to make the thing work. I and the industry have suggested a number of times to the minister that she appoint a credible accountant such as Coopers and Lybrand to decide whether she is right or the child associations are right. Someone has got to be wrong. On the one hand, there are the minister's costings and, on the other hand, there are the four costings done by independent auditors saying that she is wrong. So we need a referee in the middle to decide.

The Victorian Association of Child Care Centres commissioned yet another cost study and came up with a cost increase of $35 a child per week to implement the accreditation scheme. At 88c a week, the minister is still hanging on like grim death to her flimsy costings.

The Western Australian association has also expressed its concern over the cost of implementing the accreditation scheme, particularly in the area of staffing. The minister still sticks to her 88c a week. Eighty-eight cents is the cost of about six minutes worth of labour.

The minister says that it is going to take only six minutes extra per week per child to make intimate diary notes of each child's behaviour and measure against an individually drawn-up program, to attend a variety of parent and staff meetings at overtime rates, and to attend, and be replaced while attending, additional in-service training—six minutes worth of staff time to complete paperwork for 52 principals. Then there is the translation and printing of numerous policy documents to be revised regularly.

In some states the continuous care requirement of only one or two staff to look after the same child will necessitate alternative rosters and putting on more staff. Nevertheless, the minister says, `We are not concerned with staffing. That is a matter for the state'. She has said that to me numerous times in this place. What will the minister say to the states when they see their regulations and legislation being trampled upon by yet more Commonwealth interference? Where the essence of these guidelines goes to good quality child care, the states already have them covered.

The minister is trying to place an umbrella over every aspect of child care. Not only that, she wants someone else to pay for it—the states, local government, the employees. I point out to Senator Chamarette and Senator Lees, who are obviously interested in the community organisations, that the non-profit organisations will have to pay for it. In fact, everyone will have to pay for it except the minister's department, because that would really blow her budget right out.

The number of families in long day care receiving child-care assistance rose to 160,000 by the end of 1992-93, according to the department's annual report. In the end, of course, it is the parents who will be asked to pay the money and, eventually, it really will be the children who will have to pay. That is, 160,000 Australian families are going to be up for more in child-care costs. I bet the minister has not even consulted the Minister for Finance (Mr Beazley) over the likelihood of boosting fee relief by $30 per week per child; someone is going to have to pay for it.

I thought this government was about creating more affordable and accessible child care. Commonwealth partnership arrangements with state, territory and local government, the private sector, employer and community groups are expected to result in 300,000 child-care places by 1996-1997. It may be possible to do that at 88c a week, but at $30 a week there is no chance. Will the minister be asking her state, local government, private and community partners to pay these extra costs? Have they agreed to absorb extra costs or will they be passed on to parents? Someone has to pay. The minister will be responsible for slamming the door on women who want to, or need to, enter the workplace.

This accreditation scheme threatens the government's estimate of child-care places and undermines the ability of women to re-enter the work force as it lowers affordability and accessibility of child care. The minister will be responsible for the rich getting child care and the poor getting nowhere. This accreditation scheme is the minister's own sandwich shop. Private child-care operators will have to work unpaid while the ALP sinks money into the scheme just to keep it going. In the end, are the sandwiches any better? Will the quality of child care be improved under such a scheme, or will it sink under the weight of detailed paperwork, and concern with the hole rather than the doughnut?

Regarding the nature of the program itself, it will not succeed while there is such a disparity between the government's and the industry's cost expectations. The child-care associations are only too happy to have their costings open to scrutiny; to sit down with an independent arbitrator and work them through. If the minister is at all interested in her scheme getting off the ground, surely this is the only sensible way. It will settle what is expected of care centres before the tonne of rules and regulations is turned into law. I am also confident that all participants in the provision of child-care services—the state, local government, employer groups and community groups, such as the Sydney Rescue Work Society—would like to see exactly what they are being committed to.

Then we come to the very important area of security of information. The National Childcare Accreditation Council is charged with administering the scheme. That will have access to incredibly detailed and sensitive information on children, parents, staff and the operation of the child-care centres. The government has said in the past how committed it is to ensuring privacy and security of information. How did it let this one slide past? There is probably no other group in Australia that holds such a diversity of sensitive information, yet there are no supporting secrecy provisions, no obligations or procedures to follow, cradle to the grave.

This government wants to have information on 160,000 children in long day care centres from how often their nappies are changed, whether they have been abused or neglected, how much their parents earn, what the family situation is, disciplinary methods, what words they can say, what toys they can play with and so on. There are also records of staff interaction with parents. Then there are the commercial records of the child-care centres, all open to the NCAC, and all items of income and expenditure.

We must legislate for those tempted to ignore the sensitivity of the information they have access to. What will the NCAC do with all this information? Does it then pass it on to the education system so that it follows a child throughout its life? Some ill-informed comment at a preschool might form an incorrect attitude in teachers at a later stage. The point is that no-one knows what happens to this information, how much is stored and for how long, how it is to be stored and how it is to be collected. There are no privacy obligations or regulations.
