It is an intolerable situation which must not be allowed to happen. The Law Reform Commission identified this lack of protection in its October 1993 report on child-care legislation—or the lack of it, as it turns out. It has specified reference to the need for the NCAC to be bound by specific privacy provisions, yet the minister has carried on regardless. Whether the government tends to introduce such legislation later on is not for this Senate to ponder on or make any judgment about. We do that when we see the legislation. We must review legislation as it is laid out before us, not hypothesise about what might or might not be legislated at some future date. We are not Nostradamus.

What we see before us today does not protect in any way the rights of Australians to be confident about the security of information that is passed on to a body like the NCAC. Our citizens' rights must be protected and secured before any such scheme comes into place. Each centre that registers with the NCAC must be confident that the NCAC is bound by privacy provisions. I know that this is a matter that the Democrats are concerned about. It has always been a major plank in their platform that privacy is very important.
When asked a question by Senator Newman about the lack of privacy provisions, the minister said:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . this matter was brought to my attention in an article in the Australian about the Australian Privacy Foundation's concerns.

This is an astonishing statement which reveals the minister's incredible naivety about her portfolio and legislative standards. Her statement reveals that she had never, before the article appeared in the Australian, read the Australian Law Reform Commission's discussion paper on child care, specifically commissioned to propose wide-ranging legislative reform in her own portfolio.

PARA.TAB: The public was expected to comment by 31 January this year. It seems that the minister is not required to comment until an issue is raised by the Australian. The Law Reform Commission paper goes to great length to describe the need for greater protection of privacy. Yet the minister was ignorant, until this week, of its appraisal and recommendations.

This is all the more astonishing because in a letter dated 10 December 1993 to the chairman of the Senate Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances the minister refers to concerns held by the Law Reform Commission on the need for access to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal. This letter was incorporated into Hansard on 15 December. I call on the minister to explain why she was aware of some of the Law Reform Commission's concerns and not others. How could the minister have remained in ignorance of such an important matter as privacy and protection of the very sensitive data which the NCAC will have access to?

Thirdly, there is the question of external review of decisions which significantly affect a child-care centre in its progress towards accreditation. This process is wide open to victimisation and harassment of individual care centres. Because of the open-ended nature of many of the guidelines, a centre might be following them but then, if a review or a moderator or someone at the NCAC bears the centre a grudge—and there are many grudges held by the NCAC members at present, particularly towards the private sector—that person could easily find something wrong with the centre or grade it lower at will, or perhaps give it only 12 months until the next review rather than three years. The centre has no redress outside the NCAC.

This process can go on and the centre can be named in parliament twice without the centre being able to appeal or defend itself. By the time the minister makes the decision to cross the centre off the list, which is appealable under certain instances, it is too late for the centre, which could have been driven out of business or into bankruptcy by then anyway.

The Law Reform Commission made a number of recommendations regarding the need for external review. The minister went only part of the way when forced to amend the regulations as recommended by the Regulations and Ordinances Committee. But the minister did not go too far out of the way to accommodate what the Law Reform Commission identified as necessary to bring the legislation up to scratch in this area.

It is difficult to understand why the minister is rushing through this inferior legislation. If she is going to do something, she should do it well. The Senate is in no position to depend on a minister's assurance that she will fix it up at a later date when she says that it will be all right on the night.

Perhaps the minister should be subject to an accreditation system, too—one that includes daily diarising of her progress to a development plan, lots of in-service training and a 12-month review period. In light of the minister's inability to read a Law Reform Commission document integral to her own portfolio, I would suggest that she would find it difficult to get accreditation herself.

These child-care guidelines are riddled with a pox of impudence: impudent to impose such a costly regime on already financially overburdened Australian families; impudent to offer so little chance to appeal the decision of a non-government agency; and the height of impudence to attempt to gain the Senate's support without first putting in place privacy provisions to protect sensitive information given to the NCAC.

This is a matter of principle for the Democrats. They will have to ask themselves whether they will stand up for their strongly held views that they pushed on privacy and that they fought for on the Australia card. Will they stand up for low-income mothers, the less affluent sector who would be unable to meet the extra cost for their child care? Will they use their balance of power to have an independent arbitrator to investigate the cost differences between the minister's 88c a week and the independent costings of the child-care associations? This is what Senator Kernot and Senator Lees will be judged on—how they used their balance of power in the Senate; whether they will make available to the Senate an independent judgment; or whether they will just blithely accept the minister's word.

It is a big challenge to Senator Lees. I know of her concern for privacy. I just ask her to do the right thing and hope that she will make the decision that these guidelines be knocked out until a private investigation or a Senate committee calls for its own independent auditor to look at the costs and discern where the differences are, and also wait until the privacy matter has been legislated for.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lees Sen M.H.

TALKER.NAME: Senator LEES
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —Here we go today, again, on an issue that we spent a lot of time on last year. Now we note that the ground certainly has changed away from Christmas carols and the banning of various sorts of toys and on to the issue, particularly of costings and of privacy.

PARA.TAB: I am not saying that all these issues should not be raised and are not relevant, but if we look back to last year we can see what was done to the guidelines by the opposition, how they were misrepresented and misquoted and what a long bow was drawn to suggest that somehow we were about to cancel Christmas. We do look with some concern now at the further claims that these guidelines are going to lead to exorbitant costs. Therefore, I am not going to go back over what we talked about last year. I believe we proved well and truly that the guidelines were being deliberately misrepresented. I will not be quoting large slabs of them for that purpose this time but will simply be going through two sets of costings that I have obtained, one, as has already been mentioned by a previous speaker, from Shaw and Gay Pty Ltd, and the other from Johnston and Rorke. I will then look at the issue of privacy which, as Senator Boswell has already said, is a matter of major concern for the Democrats.

I will go first to the costings of Shaw and Gay. I do not want to suggest in any way that I am criticising the company involved; I am not. This is no reflection upon that company. It can work only with the information that it is given. It can rely only upon what it is told. The information was prepared from what the company refers to as its clientele base. I presume it is talking about the Child Care Association of Victoria, an organisation which represents one-third of the private centres in Victoria. I must stress here and remind senators that the major private child-care association in Victoria, the one headed by Mr David McAuliffe, has been very vocal in support of the guidelines.

Shaw and Gay also interviewed three—that is right, only three—proprietors who are not clients. The company did not interview staff; it did not go and talk to parents; it did not visit the centres. Shaw and Gay talked to three proprietors and I would argue that that is not a very solid base. I will actually go into these costings themselves. I will go through some of the items Shaw and Gay consider just need a small amount of money. These are not the big ticket items that I will deal with later. Where it says, `Staff interactions with children are warm and friendly', that is going to need a bit more money. `Staff treat all children equally and try to accommodate their individual needs'; that is going to need some more money. `Staff treat all children equally and try to accommodate their needs, both sexes treated without bias'; more money again. `Staff use a positive approach in guidance and discipline'; more money again.

I have to ask: what are these three centres doing at the moment? We can go through this, item after item. These are small ticket items but we really do have to ask what the staff are doing now. Are we talking about centres that do not provide anything other than child minding? As we move on through this we see items that are starting to build up in cost. It says, `Staff learn some key words and phrases of the children's home language'. That is quite legitimate for a small cost, but here it is suggesting that we are going to have to send people off for special training. There is an initial 220 units, ongoing at 220 units a year, a total in any year of $502. Yes, it is fair enough to suggest that staff are going to have to do something here, but surely that is what I can best describe as an arbitrary claim for what will simply mean learning yes and no and perhaps some complimentary phrases like `Well done' in a child's home language. Some of that, hopefully, will already be part of what that centre has thought about, if it is in an area that has perhaps 50 per cent of its children from non-English speaking backgrounds, .
Let us now get to the really big ticket item in this particular Shaw and Gay account. The guideline states:

SPEECH.PARA: The program incorporates learning experiences appropriate for each child, as indicated by individual development records maintained by the staff.

This has been costed at $60,221. If we go back to the guideline, to begin with there is no mention of a day-by-day record. It is being suggested here in the Shaw and Gay account that staff are actually going to have to do this almost every few minutes. What we actually see in the guidelines is that every week staff should closely observe some children during different activities and make a record of their levels of development.

PARA.TAB: Good child-care centres now use the system of ticking boxes. They have sheets available with the child's name on the top and they simply monitor what the child does. Here this is extrapolated to a totally unrealistic amount of time. It is not a new item. It is already required under state guidelines; it is something that centres are already expected to do. So I do not expect that good centres will spend one cent more on being able to follow principle 17. I certainly do not accept, when we are looking at these costings, the $60,000 that has been added to it.

Now we get on to some of the smaller ticket items for which money has been added. `Toileting and nappy changing procedures meet individual needs and are positive experiences': they believe they are going to need more money for that. `Sleep time and dressing procedures meet individual needs for rest, comfort and self-help': again, they have costed in more money for that. What are the centres doing now? This brings me to a couple of the other larger ticket items. I go here to guideline 34 and I read:

SPEECH.PARA: All staff are able and willing to observe signs of illness in children.
Suspected incidences of child abuse or neglect are reported to the appropriate authority through the centre coordinator.
Staff know their legal and professional responsibilities in regard to these issues.

Surely we do not have centres out there with staff who do not know their legal responsibilities. In South Australia, all teachers and people who work with children have an obligation under the law to report child abuse. If staff do not know that now, who are these centres employing? In most states state regulations, if not state law, would have picked this up already; but here in these costings is a figure of $821 extra. They are suggesting a seminar for staff to know their legal and professional responsibilities in regard to this issue. Three hours for 12 staff is what the costing is based on. Surely any worthwhile proprietor would check that somebody was a trained child-care worker as a matter of course, before that person was employed. If the person did not know these responsibilities already, that would be part of the employer's responsibilities before the employee ever went into a situation where he or she was responsible for children. I simply cannot accept that these costings are anything like reasonable.

PARA.TAB: One costing with which I do agree is the one for item 32. I would question the amount, but certainly my experience is that some centres are not coping well with children with special needs. This particular costing is for $1,186 a year extra. I query that amount, but I would suggest that this is one of the positive things that will come out of these guidelines: that is, making sure centres in all states cope with and support kids who have special needs. That is one of the reasons the Democrats are supporting the guidelines. I do accept that there will be some additional responsibilities and extra money for a lot of centres there.

But let us continue. `Staff encourage children to follow simple rules of hygiene' is costed as needing a bit more money. `Potentially dangerous products are inaccessible to children' is costed as needing more money. `Buildings and equipment are safe and hygienic'. What on earth is out there now? If we are talking about a standard of reasonable care now, we surely have to take out most of these extra items.
Let us look at No. 47. This is the last one I will pick out as a specific example. What does No. 47 say?

SPEECH.PARA: Staff are encouraged to complete a relevant first aid certificate.
Staff are encouraged to attend courses related to adult and child health issues.

Yet here they have gone so far as to suggest that staff are going to be required to go and get St John Ambulance certificates, costed at four staff for 32 hours each. That is nowhere in here. All it says is that they are `encouraged'. It does not make St John Ambulance certificates compulsory.

PARA.TAB: As a physical education teacher, I had to have a St John Ambulance certificate. Without one, I was not allowed to teach in New South Wales. It was up to me to get it, and that was a requirement. There is no requirement in here but staff are encouraged to complete the relevant first aid certificate. I have not had time to look this up this morning but I suspect that in South Australia it is part of the state guidelines. I do not think it specifies St John Ambulance but it is simply a basic requirement. I think that a Red Cross course of a couple of hours or having a Red Cross manual on deck somewhere in the centre fulfils the requirement. These requirements have been costed at $7,500 per year. How that could possibly be read into principle 47 is beyond me.

I will take out the two large-ticket items that I query and leave in all the bits and pieces, all those little odds and ends that it is thought the centres are not doing, such as changing nappies and looking after hygiene. If I do that, we are left with a costing that drops back to $5 per week per child. I argue that that is still too high. If a centre is at such a low standard now that it does not meet basic requirements or if a centre now meets basic requirements but wants to get itself up to a good standard, we are possibly looking at $2 to $3 for some of the things that may need to be done.

Again I question what some centres must be doing out there now. Do they have trained staff? I ask the Minister for Family Services (Senator Crowley) whether she has any information as to how often the states are actually checking to see what is happening in some of these centres. If centres believe they have to go to these extraordinary lengths to meet basic standards, what is happening now? Are the states going out to make sure that the people who are looking after children are qualified and are not just childminders?

I turn now to Johnston Rorke and the second lot of costings. This company is obviously a very reputable company and I do not want it to be suggested for a moment that I am criticising it. The company can only work with the information it has been given. It says right up-front that, if it has been given wrong information on the issue of food—that is, whether or not children actually get a meal in Queensland—its costings basically go out the window. On checking and on reading the guidelines, I find that the company certainly has been misinformed. It has costed in as its biggest ticket item, at $33,000, the need for meals.

There is nothing in these guidelines—I am referring to principle 24—that requires centres to provide meals. Some states already require that. Queensland does not. But that does not mean that in Queensland we have children starving between the hours of eight or nine o'clock in the morning and four or five o'clock at night. I refer to my colleague Senator Kernot for information as to what now happens in Queensland, as her daughter went to a couple of centres in Queensland. Either centres are providing meals and have already built the costs into their fees or they are not providing meals but the children bring packed lunches from home. Whether or not they are now providing meals or the children have packed lunches, all of these requirements can be quite easily met. For example, good-quality care means that mealtimes are pleasant occasions for all. Surely that is not too much to ask.

If we take from these costings the big-ticket item of $33,000, which is not needed, we then come to the next big-ticket item, which is that a daily timetable is planned to reflect children's needs, abilities and interests. Again I have to ask what they are doing now if they do not have this. It is a state regulation in Queensland. Indeed, on this document it says `existing Queensland regulation, yes'. So there again we take out a large item of $12,750. If we take only two items out of this series of costings we bring the figure back from $59,000 per year for a centre of 65 kids to $45,000, and that brings it down to $5 per week. That $5 per week is for centres that are not even meeting basic requirements now; in other words, centres that should have already been picked up by the state authorities, centres that should not now be allowed to continue to operate.

I request the minister to ask her state colleagues, particularly in Queensland, whether they are checking the child-care centres now. Perhaps I can put some specific questions. How often is each centre in Queensland visited? When those visits occur, what in particular are the priorities for checking? It seems to me that, if child-care centres really believe they have to do these things, there are some very big questions to be answered as to what is happening to the kids now.

I now need to move on to the other issue, that is, privacy. I have had a number of discussions on this issue with a variety of individuals, and we certainly do have a problem. It is not a problem, I hasten to say, that will mean that we scuttle these regulations and start again, but it is certainly a problem that is going to have to be monitored. We are still waiting for several answers from the minister as to what precisely will be done and which particular path will be followed. Are we looking at a company structure? What particular measure are we going to get to make sure that there are no problems with privacy? We need to know, for example, whether the council is subject to the Privacy Act, something that I understand the minister has already been researching. I look to her speech in a few moments to sum up this debate for information on that.

I understand that the council is developing a code of ethics for reviewers. Will we be able to see that code? When will it be available? Also, we need to see what legal sanctions will be brought in if, indeed, there are breaches of privacy. What particular measures will be taken against those people who in any way breach privacy guidelines and privacy procedures? I wait with interest to hear what the minister has to say on that issue.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Lees has already given us excellent examples of reasons why this new argument about costings is insufficient to support a disallowance motion. However, I will briefly summarise why the Greens will not be supporting this motion.

PARA.TAB: As Senator Lees said, the companies, regardless of their competence and their best will in the world to provide efficient and effective costings, are reliant solely on the information they have been given. If there is a difference in interpretation that underlies the information they are given, the costings can vary considerably. These differences in the costings we have been provided with by the minister and in the costings from the other private child-care agencies and associations illustrate the well-known principle of demand characteristics. It is obvious that the different motivations underlying the request allowed for the different information and different implications of the guidelines and have led to widely discrepant results. Both may well represent extremes in motivation and both approaches in essence are hypothetical, because they are looking in advance at a system that may or may not operate in the way in which it is predicted. So I am not at this point going to defend either the costings provided by the minister, on the one hand, or the more expensive costings we have had made available to us.

While I am grateful that all the people involved have made the effort to look in that detail at those implications, the position the Greens hold is that the only appropriate way to assess it is to accept the guidelines on their merits and then to make a realistic review of the complications that may arise. Because it is a new system, it will not be perfect. It may well have costings that nobody today has even dreamt of, and it is fair to say that it could be putting people in a new situation that deserves to be reviewed.

If we regard the much higher costings as being anywhere near correct, it would, as Senator Lees has already indicated, be an indictment of the present facilities that are available for child care in our community. I believe that that is a very serious point. Is the opposition really saying that improvement in child care is too expensive for us, or that these incredible increases in costings do not reflect the fact that some basic problems exist in what we are already providing for the children of our society? This is the fifth different reason that has been given—the fifth that I know of; there are probably far more—by opponents of the government's child-care accreditation scheme.

TALK.START.PARA: —What are the other four?

—Firstly, there were the complaints about the guidelines, and I must say to Senator McGauran that there is room for improvement and criticism of those guidelines. Nobody has said that they will be perfect. However, I have looked at them, and they appear to put, in a fairly repetitive fashion, the very basic requirements any parents would expect if they were putting their children into the care of such centres for any length of time. So that concern about the guidelines was the first one. That does need to be addressed. It can be addressed after the guidelines are in place, and certainly that seems to be part of the scheme the minister has undertaken to review after a one-year period in operation.

PARA.TAB: The second reason was that there was parental disadvantage because of a connection with the fees assistance and the rebate. That argument has already been thrashed out at considerable length and I will not go into it here, but that was another one. The position the Greens held at that point was that, if the government is providing fee assistance, there would be something wrong if the only kind of accountability they demanded was simply a facts and figures one, and not one that took account of the quality of child care that was being provided. I believe that accountability factor is very important.

The next reason was the intrusion of parents into the management of child-care centres. I believe that this created concern that it might involve greater participation in the programming or management in some way of the child-care centres. But the Greens believe that it is excellent to encourage the involvement of parents. Sometimes child-care centres offer an extremely valuable service where parents cannot provide the kind of care the children need, and it should not be underestimated. However, where the child-care centres can actually incorporate parents into their work, the children can only benefit.

The next stage was the privacy intrusion. As Senator Lees has said, this is a matter that deserves to be checked out. I have already contacted the office of the Minister for Family Services (Senator Crowley). I have heard Quentin Bryce of the National Childcare Accreditation Council speaking of the willingness there is to look at any matters of privacy, which appear to be very limited, that may relate to concerns of the Privacy Commissioner. While Senator Boswell referred earlier to the concerns he and the Democrats have over privacy and the protection of confidentiality, it has to be recognised that looking after children is one of the most important tasks of our community. They are our future. When it is considered that one child in three has been abused before the age of 18 and that we do get earlier and earlier reporting of childhood violence and bullying, it can be seen that there may be some reason why this area could be of concern. However, there is no evidence that these guidelines, or any of the ways in which the scheme is being implemented, will actually assist us in that regard. I do think that is one reason why people could be concerned. However, my view would be for greater transparency, rather than greater secrecy, in our community.

The next reason that was brought up, and I think this was the final one we are discussing today, is how it is to the economic disadvantage of the owners and managers of child-care centres. I have omitted the Christmas carols because I felt that fell within the complaints about the guidelines and was not really worthy of response. But maybe, with this series of different reasons for opposing it, we are getting closer to the truth, which may unfortunately lie in the practices within our community in running child-care centres. As a parliament, we should be aware that there may be a lack of concern for the way in which child-care centres are administered, staffed and run, because we have for a long time been blind to the importance of our responsibilities in that area.

My belief, and that of my colleague, is that the way in which the quality of child care is supervised is actually more important than the kind of educational standards we impose on university and tertiary level education. Nobody queries that there should be accountability regarding quality of standards there. However, it is a recent innovation by the government that we are imposing standards of quality assessment on a fairly new and burgeoning section of our community. There is nobody to blame here, but we must be careful not to react in a very conventional and conservative way to something that is greatly needed and is long overdue. We need to provide guidelines for the quality of child care so that we will be protecting and safeguarding the welfare and well-being of the children of our community.

I close by saying that the Greens will not support the disallowance motion. We believe there has been an undertaking by the minister to conduct a full review of the improved system before July 1995, which I understand is after a year of operation. That seems to me a sensible time to assess whether it has any serious problems. I am sure that there has been a willingness expressed that, along the way, if problems occur they will be dealt with. Basically, the need is for good quality child care, for accountability for government funding, and for concern that damage caused by poor quality child care is difficult to reverse and is unacceptable both in the short and long term.

The Greens will not be supporting this motion. We believe there will be need for further refinement of the scheme. We have had extensive consultation with both people who support the scheme and have been very eager for its introduction and also those who have expressed concerns, many of which I have mentioned very briefly. I apologise if I have not done those concerns justice. I believe there is a kernel of truth in every concern people raise, but I think we do have to look at the central principle, which is that these guidelines are being introduced for the best. There is a considerable overreaction to them that I do not understand. I believe the opponents have not justified their arguments. Therefore, with the qualification that I believe it is important that a review be conducted before July 1995 and that it involve the elected National Childcare Accreditation Council and other bodies, with broad representation of all affected parties, we will be supporting the government's introduction of the guidelines and not the disallowance motion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Newman Sen J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am very sad today to hear both the Democrats and the Greens say that they will not support the coalition on this important matter of disallowing these guidelines on child care. Unfortunately, I was not present during the debate before Christmas due to my illness. I felt very frustrated at not being able to take part in what I see as a major issue in Australia, the care of Australia's children.

PARA.TAB: Senator Chamarette was quite rightly talking about quality. I could not agree more that the focus of all our attention should be on quality. The coalition does support quality in child care. Equally, it believes that there is currently a regulatory system in place in each state of Australia which is responsible for the overview and for the management of child-care centres. I think it was Senator Lees who said that, if that was not being done properly, the Commonwealth government had some sort of leadership role in pointing the finger at those states that were not fulfilling their legal responsibilities.

I have heard Senator Crowley on several occasions talk about Australia having the best child-care system in the world. If she as the minister responsible talks, on the one hand, about the best child-care service in the world being that which we enjoy in Australia, how can she, on the other hand, suggest that the states are so derelict in their responsibility to ensure good quality child care in our country that the Commonwealth must come in over the top and introduce yet another regulatory system?

I know that Senator Crowley will say, `Aha, but this is not exactly the same'. No, it is not exactly the same, but there is considerable overlap and there certainly is an additional cost. Whatever the rights or wrongs of the debate about the costs, there clearly will, and must, be an increase in costs as a result of yet another level of requirements being imposed on the child-care centres of Australia. One has only to look at the document setting out the principles to see that child-care centres can either have an unsatisfactory response to a principle, a basic response, or they can have a good quality or high quality response. We are all very pleased that the higher they aim, the better for our children, but there are going to be occasions when people are not necessarily going to have what these guidelines say is the basic standard. They may have a different standard which is just as good and maybe even better, but it does not fit the exact wording and the requirements under these principles.

I have a particular concern, having a small business background, at a requirement which is said to be basic that staff and parents are permitted to attend meetings of a child-care centre. I can understand where this came from: it clearly came from people who have spent their lives in the public sector. People who have worked in the public sector all their lives have no understanding of how a small business operates, or the need for privacy in relation to the intimate details of the operation of a small business. How would the local cake shop like it if its clients and staff were to be permitted to attend all meetings of the business?

TALK.START.PARA: —They might get some good ideas.

—Perhaps there is a sandwich shop that might have been better run under those arrangements, but mostly Labor ministers do not get involved in business, thank God, because they are not equipped to handle even a sandwich shop. God help us about our piggery! Having said that, that is a basic requirement, under principle 52 of these child-care guidelines, for the management of a child-care centre. It does not matter that 60 per cent of Australia's child-care provision is not in the government sector. These quite unrealistic requirements are being imposed upon the private or the non-government sector. That is just the basic requirement.

PARA.TAB: Turning to good quality, which is the next one up, staff and parents shall have elected representatives on any relevant management committees. Tell that to the cake shop proprietor. Why should the child-care centre proprietor not have just as much concern about that as the cake shop proprietor? We are not talking about the regulation, which is already under way by the states, of Australia's child-care centres. We are talking about an additional level of supervision and surveillance being required by the Commonwealth in which these many onerous requirements are being imposed on the non-government sector.

Senator Lees acknowledged that she did have worries about privacy, as did Senator Chamarette, but they were both prepared to allow these regulations to go through. I find that incredible. After all, the Senate, if anywhere, should be the place where people express concerns about the privacy of the citizen. This is a place designed to protect the rights of the citizen. Surely the right to privacy has to be around the top of the list in terms of citizens' rights. Yet we find that child-care centres and, presumably, the parents who send their children there, are likely to have serious problems in the protection of their privacy. That is not just the coalition saying so; it is also the Law Reform Commission saying so.

Senator Crowley, in response to my question on Tuesday, gave some assurances, and I am very glad that she has. But I say to the minister that I have been here for eight years, and I have seen ministers' assurances come and go. Frankly, I am not all that impressed until I see them in writing. When the minister is taking regulations through this chamber for the government and is not prepared to put privacy regulations in with them, I have my doubts about her assurances. I would have thought that if the minister were really genuine she would have held them over. Time is on her side; she has until 1 July this year before this all becomes a requirement. I find her attitude to this pretty cavalier, and the attitude of the Greens and the Democrats was very disappointing. I want to make it quite clear exactly what the Law Reform Commission did say. In paragraph 4.19 of its report it stated:

SPEECH.PARA: When the Quality Improvement and Accreditation System begins operating, the National Childcare Accreditation Council. . . will hold information about long day care centres including

PARA.TAB: .how staff, children and parents interact
.details of curriculum and routines
.health and safety standards
.whether a service has met or made progress against the accreditation standards.

SPEECH.PARA: The Law Reform Commission went on to say this:

The NCAC is an incorporated association. It is not a government agency. Provisions that protect information from disclosure by Commonwealth agencies or individual Commonwealth officers do not apply. If a member or employee of the Council were to disclose information without authority the only legal remedies available to a service would be those offered by the common law, for example, the law of defamation or contract. However, the effectiveness of common law remedies is limited by the cost and delay of litigation, the inappropriate nature of the remedies and the fact that the service may often be unaware that the information is being misused.
The Law Reform Commission concludes:

The interests of services could be further protected if the Council was subject to clearly defined secrecy obligations requiring that the information supplied to the council by services must be collected, used, stored and disclosed in a manner that ensures the confidentiality of the information.

These issues should be dealt with before the regulations go through. I find it incredible that apparently, as the minister acknowledged in answer to my question on Tuesday, she did not have any knowledge of this matter until she read about it in the Australian this week. She has an office devoted to child care. Where were they, and was she not asking the right questions, or are they incompetent? Where was her attention to her own portfolio responsibilities, when she had a Law Reform Commission report that dealt with child care, that she was not of her own volition doing a little homework? I am concerned that the minister obviously is relying on people who are incompetent and who do not tell her anything. The fact is that she has not the wit to ask questions herself.

PARA.TAB: She gave assurances, as she said. I am not all that impressed with the assurances. Also, in her answer she makes it quite clear that the Privacy Commissioner himself has been concerned. She said that the Privacy Commissioner has had discussions with the council and is meeting with it. That does not mean to say that it is fixed. That means to say that the Privacy Commissioner is still in the process of trying to do something about this mess the minister has got into through her indecent haste in trying to get these regulations through the Senate. Surely, if the minister has any respect for the Senate, as well as for the rights of Australians, she should be willing voluntarily to hold these regulations off until this matter is resolved.

I would have thought the minister had been long enough in the Senate to realise that the privacy of citizens is something this Senate should guard jealously. As the minister responsible, she is now knowingly putting in jeopardy the privacy of citizens' private information. She has the opportunity and she has the knowledge now. She can do something about it. All we are asking is that she hold these things over until satisfactory regulations go through which do protect the child-care centres and the people who use them.

Senator Troeth went very carefully and very effectively through our concerns over the costs of accreditation, and Senator Boswell has also addressed the very serious threat to privacy that these guidelines represent. I want to talk more generally about the implications of accreditation for those who have most to lose from its compulsory implementation, that is, the parents and children. It is unfortunate that the coalition has been forced to pursue this motion because, given the clearly unresolved issues associated with the guidelines—in particular, the cost and privacy implications—any responsible government and any minister with an ounce of credibility would have sought to have the guidelines withdrawn.

This minister knew that she would have had coalition support for such action to withdraw if she had decided to take that action. Even at this eleventh hour, I still call on her to do so. Instead, she is persisting with this set of guidelines, which are seriously flawed. She did acknowledge, as I said this week, that the guidelines are a source of concern to the Privacy Commissioner and to the Law Reform Commission.

Before I go any further, I would like to place on the record my absolute rejection of the views relating to the guidelines and accreditation which were attributed to me last year by Senator Crowley in my absence, while I was in a hospital bed. On 24 November last year, in answering a question from Senator Denman, Senator Crowley said:

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Newman made it clear in this place that she supports accreditation.
Later, during the same question time, in answer to a question from Senator McGauran, Senator Crowley said, referring to members of the Opposition:
If they care to check, they will find that Senator Newman supports accreditation and so do most of the people involved in this process.
Again, during the same question time, this time answering a question from Senator Boswell, Senator Crowley said:
I suggest again that those opposite look at what Senator Newman has said about this matter. She is in support of accreditation and that would be a very thoughtful approach for the opposition to take.

I watched Senator Crowley in that question time from my hospital bed, and I cannot say she did too much for the monitor in my ICU ward. I had Senator Herron contacted, and he put on the record my real position on the accreditation guidelines put forward by the government. I also had a press release put out under my name on 24 November. It said:
The Minister for Family Services, Senator Crowley, "disgracefully misled the Senate today" when she claimed that Senator Newman supported the government's compulsory Child Care accreditation program.

Senator Newman has consistently voiced opposition to Senator Crowley's "heavy handed attempts at social engineering" and takes particular exception to Senator Crowley's "untruthful account of her position".
On the 26th October 1993 Senator Newman released a press statement stating that: ". . . the Coalition is committed to quality child care, voluntary accreditation—
Senator Crowley should note that: `voluntary accreditation'—
and the central role of parental choice in determining quality of care for children.
Senator Newman is "appalled" that she would be so blatantly misrepresented by a fellow senator while she is absent from the chamber and ill in hospital.
Despite that clear and unambiguous repudiation of Senator Crowley's claims, she misrepresented me again, this time on 7 December. In answering a question from Senator McGauran she said:
I have to ask again—why Senator McGauran, in speaking on behalf of the opposition, is opposed to accreditation when Senator Newman supports it.

My position and that of the opposition is quite clear, and I hope this puts Senator Crowley's distortions of the truth to bed. I do not support the guidelines put forward by Senator Crowley, including aspects of the 52 principles and the fact that her system of accreditation is compulsory. The minister frequently denies that the accreditation system is compulsory; but in fact that is absolutely true, because any child-care centre that does not go through with accreditation will incur loss of eligibility for fee relief for all its parents. I cannot think of anything more effectively compulsory than that. Sadly, the guidelines will most hurt those who can least afford to pay for child care. The effect will vary from state to state because of variations in state regulations. I asked Senator Crowley a question the other day, and in her answers in question time she got herself totally confused.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is nothing unusual.

—It is not very unusual. I wonder whether she is permanently confused over this issue or, to be kind to her, whether it was a momentary aberration. She had great difficulty in understanding why there should be differences in the calculations of the extra costs that accreditation would impose, why there should be variations from state to state. It is a pretty important point, but the minister responsible seems to have a little trouble understanding the maths of the thing and the impact of her actions.

PARA.TAB: Accreditation is going to lead to increased costs largely, but not entirely, because of staff demands and differences in staff ratios. Child-care centres will have to hire more staff in order to meet the principles set out in the handbook. Staffing requirements under state regulations already vary from state to state—perhaps the honourable senator has not woken up to that. Therefore, coming from different staff bases, the final costs associated with accreditation are going to be different in different states.

The bottom line of all this is that an increase in costs will impact most harshly on low income earners. Either parents will have to pay higher fees to keep their children in an accredited centre or they will have to take their children out of formal care altogether. So, while the government claims to be setting out to improve the quality of child care via these guidelines, by linking accreditation to fee relief the effect will be just the opposite. As parents are effectively forced to leave the formal sector, there will be an offsetting greater use of the informal sector, a sector which the government claims provides a lower standard of care. The consequences for low income earners, I believe, will be devastating. I do not want to labour the point, but I do point out that that view is supported by the private child-care sector and the not-for-profit sector.

The minister has sneered in the past that only a few private child-care centres are opposed to this legislation. Whether she is living in a fool's paradise or whether that is the advice given to her and the department knows no better, I cannot judge, but I can tell Senator Crowley, with all the facts that are at my disposal, that she is seriously misguided. The opposition to her guidelines and to the compulsory accreditation system is very strong and very widespread across Australia. More than any other sector, the not-for-profit sector is concerned for lower paid and vulnerable parents.

We have heard today about the Sydney Rescue Work Society. It is a not-for-profit group of people who come from church backgrounds. It provides care for 1,500 children per day in metropolitan Sydney. That society has long had concerns with the compulsory nature of accreditation and the effects of increased costs. Representatives of the society have met with the coalition, with me, with the Australian Democrats, with the Greens and with the government. It is a widely respected, thoroughly credible organisation. It deals primarily with lower paid, disadvantaged parents. In a letter sent to all members of parliament on 15 November last year, the society argued that the guidelines should be rejected. The reasons for this position include that linkage of child-care assistance to accreditation will deny many needy families access to child care; that the costs will rise and the affluent will be insulated from the increases because they will be the main beneficiaries of the government's child-care rebate; and that most of the industry opposes the proposals.

I hope the minister listens to this. The Sydney Rescue Work Society says that most of the industry opposes the proposals. Perhaps she is deaf as well as inattentive. I will say again for the minister, while I get her attention, that the Sydney Rescue Work Society, which has a background of working for disadvantaged children and families, says that most of the industry opposes the proposals.

TALK.START.PARA: —They would say that.

—Does the minister still deny the truth of these statements? Did the minister interject and say, `They would say that'? Is that what I heard the minister say? I will give her a chance to deny it, if she wishes to.

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator West)—You should not be listening to interjections, Senator Newman. Ignore interjections, please.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wonder whether the minister would like to say whether she believes that the Sydney Rescue Work Society would be telling lies on this matter.
—Dear, oh dear, Senator!

—The minister says, `Dear, oh dear, Senator!', but she is not prepared to say whether the Sydney Rescue Work Society is telling lies on this matter or not. I notice she smiles as I challenge her on this matter.

PARA.TAB: In a press statement released last Monday—the Sydney Rescue Work Society is coming back for another bite at this cherry, a couple of months later—the society again expressed concern with the implications of the guidelines for low income and disadvantaged families. The press release said that the new costings, to which Senator Troeth has already referred, would seriously harm many in the community relying on quality child-care services. The statement went on:

SPEECH.PARA: The Society is doing all it can to ensure affordable quality child care but is unable to reconcile this latest revelation which, if found to be correct, demonstrates a lack of compassion for families in the International Year of the Family—
for which Senator Crowley also has a responsibility—
The Society is most concerned because it has begun work to ensure that rapid implementation of accreditation.

PARA.TAB: Debate interrupted.
The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator West)—Order! It being 12.45 p.m., I now call on matters of public interest.

TALKER.NAME: Senator KERNOT
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to make a few remarks on the government response to the report of the Senate Standing Committee on Environment, Recreation and the Arts on the Australian environment and tourism. The government response to this report has taken 18 months to arrive. That is not unusual in this place, but I regret to say that I find it totally inadequate. Of the committee's 31 recommendations, just 12 have been accepted by the government; and most of those recommendations that have been accepted are simply those which preserve the status quo. Eleven recommendations have been rejected and eight are under consideration.

PARA.TAB: The Senate report covered two vital issues in the development of Australia's tourism potential. The first was the effect of tourism on the local physical and social environment. People care about this in places where they live; when proposals come along which impact on their lives, they care about it. Secondly, the committee looked at the impact of foreign investment on the tourism industry. I have to say that on both of these major issues the government response is nothing more than a cop-out or a squib of a response.

It is totally unacceptable that the government has refused to consider strengthening its environmental impact statements to include the social impact. When one sees the massive social effects that a growing influx of tourists has had on communities, such as at Byron Bay in New South Wales and at Cairns in northern Queensland, the straight-out rejection of the committee's key recommendations on evaluating the social impact of new development I find appalling.

Even more galling is the government's rejection of key recommendations to bring some reason and sanity back into the consideration of applications for foreign investment in tourism. The committee report found the current consideration of foreign investment applications by the Foreign Investment Review Board to be inadequate. The committee report calls for clearer criteria to identify the impact, particularly the social impact, of foreign investment and to identify its likely economic benefits, if any. The report calls for a restructuring of the FIRB to make it more independent, particularly of Treasury. It calls for the Foreign Investment Review Board to require progress reports on developments. It calls for the Foreign Investment Review Board to have sufficient resources to do its job and for its decisions to be based on proper market and economic material. I am not on this committee, but these are things that I have been saying for quite some time. But all of these recommendations have been rejected by the government.

Much of the report is consistent with longstanding Democrats' policy. We support foreign investment as long as it is demonstrated to be clearly in the public interest. Our policy goes further than the report. We favour joint ventures between Australian and overseas investors, and we favour majority Australian ownership. We want to make sure that Australians are able to obtain the benefits of market access and technology transfer from a foreign partner, without ceding national economic sovereignty.

Adoption of this Senate committee report by the government would have gone a long way towards our policy goal of assuring the Australian people that a loss of ownership of part of their economy would deliver a real benefit to the community. The current Foreign Investment Review Board process provides no such assurance.

In my state of Queensland there has been massive public concern about foreign investment in tourism. Virtually all of the international hotels in Cairns are foreign owned, as is much of Surfers Paradise. Even Brisbane's oldest wildlife sanctuary, Lone Pine, is now in foreign hands. The government has decided to deny people who live in these communities the assurance that projects will be approved only if there is an economic and social benefit to the community. Such a small ask, is it not?

In the four years to 1992, applications for investment in tourism was the third largest category considered by the Foreign Investment Review Board after real estate and mining. Some $9.1 billion of investments was approved in tourism. Virtually none were rejected. Two-thirds of the 3,000 applications approved by the Foreign Investment Review Board in 1991-92 were approved with conditions attached, but the catch is that the Foreign Investment Review Board has no staff, or has insufficient staff with insufficient time actually to follow up the conditions that were imposed.

Under Mr Keating as Treasurer and now as Prime Minister, the ability of the Foreign Investment Review Board properly to consider the economic and social benefits of foreign investment has been progressively clipped. Foreign Investment Review Board staff reductions have reduced the time spent considering each application. In the 1980s, each staff member considered about 35 applications annually. In 1991 to 1992, that rose to 160. So that is 35 to 160. In 1992 to 1993, it rose again to 250. So that is 35 to 250. I do not think the government can assert that it is the public's interest that is being protected when less and less time is being spent on considering applications and no time is being spent on following up the conditions attached.

What a surprise it is that the government should reject the key recommendation of the committee, that the Foreign Investment Review Board should be independent of Treasury and provide independent advice. The very few times the Foreign Investment Review Board has displayed such independence and recommended against applications, such as Mr Conrad Black's original application for John Fairfax, it has been overridden by the Prime Minister and the Treasurer. The Senate select committee tomorrow will be looking at the Conrad Black case. We will look at the Foreign Investment Review Board's processes and the relationship between it and the Treasurer and the Prime Minister.

I hope that the people of Cairns, of the Gold Coast, of Byron Bay and of other communities which have expressed strong concern about the level of foreign investment in their communities will take the government to task over this appalling response. I look with interest to see the opposition's foreign investment policy. I notice that it is having a review of its current policies. I think that primary in our consideration should be ensuring that the interests of Australian people are represented in foreign investment decisions, not just the wishes of entrepreneurs and malleable politicians.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Woodley Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise today to speak on the domestic meat premises charge and the export inspection charge regulations which have been tabled in the House of Representatives and are due to be tabled in the Senate shortly. The tabling of these regulations completes the introduction of the two-tier charging system for various meat establishments. It was and is part of a package of reforms undertaken by the Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service. We supported this legislation and certainly support the regulations as well, but I want to put on record some concerns we have that we have discussed with the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, Senator Collins. I am very thankful that he is willing to take on board our concerns and has already acted to do something about that. What I want to do today is simply to record the concerns that we have so that we can ensure that those concerns are on the record.

PARA.TAB: We recognise that the legislation was designed as a reform of AQIS, to reduce the cost to industry by providing a more efficient inspection service and at the same time maintaining the integrity of the service.

In addition to the introduction of a two-tier charging regime, other changes to be undertaken by AQIS include the shedding over the next three or four years of some 750 AQIS staff. I want to encourage the minister in this because I am sure that is not going to be easy to do or to achieve. But we would encourage him in that, and certainly would encourage the industry to adopt quality assurance practices.

The legislation provided for AQIS to impose a per premises charge on meat establishments in those states where it is responsible for the inspection service. Thus, the new two-tier charging regime was comprised of the old inspection charge, which is now set at a level that more directly reflects the cost of AQIS providing a field inspection service, and a newly-introduced—and I think this is the one where there is some debate—registration charge designed to recover the cost of maintaining administrative support to that field service. This is the new regime that we are faced with, and it is here that I want to raise some concerns.

At the hearings of the Senate Standing Committee on Rural and Regional Affairs last year we heard that the overall effect of the reforms being undertaken in AQIS would mean a reduction in the cost of inspection service to the industry of some 20 per cent. I believe, from talking with the executive members of AQIS, that they are certainly going to achieve that. But on the way there have been some problems which I want to refer to, for the new charging levels strongly favour large operators: with more inspectors on their premises, they are far better able to offset the new registration fee, a registration fee which for most categories of establishment will be the same regardless of the size of individual operations.

Over the last few weeks I have received a number of letters from the smaller and medium-sized meat establishments highlighting the problems that they have had with the increases that they are now facing with this new system. Let me give a couple of examples. One small export sausage casing plant in Tasmania will see a reduction of its inspection fees of just $17 a year, accompanied by the introduction of a registration fee of $7,740 as of 1 January this year, a fee which will rise to $9,500 in July this year and then rise once again to $12,700 on 1 July 1995. This operation employs 16 local people and the effect of an increase in annual charges from $770 to over $8,000 could be devastating.

Another example is that of a small independent export boning room in my home state of Queensland which employs 25 people whilst in full production. This company has been in operation for just 12 months and will see its AQIS bill go from around $77,000 for its first year of operation to around $110,000. In that first year this firm produced about 27,000 head of cattle and exported over 3,200 tonnes. In reference to the $35,000 registration fee that it must now pay, the company points out in its letter that, if it were to employ 400 extra people and produce 20 times the output, its registration charge would still be the same. I need to perhaps point out here, as the minister has indicated to me, that, if we had gone for the three-tier system as it had been proposed by the government, the company's concerns would have been covered. But the industry advice we received was that a two-tier system was preferred, and so we are now faced with this very problem.

When the original legislation was being dealt with by the committee I, along with several witnesses, raised this issue of the differential effect the new charges would have on small operators. To its credit, in response to those concerns the government agreed to broaden the number of establishment categories and, specifically, to introduce a lesser level of charge for those domestic abattoirs with fewer than three food service officers. This was a very welcome concession for the domestic abattoirs. However, it made no provision for the operators of all those other types of establishment, including those of which I have just given examples and which are now coming to me with their problems.

Originally, when I consulted the previous minister's office, the response I got was that the effect on the smaller operators was not a concern for the industry bodies. It seems to me that those industry bodies either did not fully comprehend the effect the charges were going to have or they may not have been representing the interests of the small to medium sized firms within the industry very well at all. I am not sure which it is; perhaps it is a bit of both. At the committee inquiry I raised concerns over the smaller operators. One of the responses I got from the director of AQIS stated:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . there is no intention in this legislation to use it as a device for restructuring the industry. That has to be considered in the light of the Industry Commission report. There is absolutely no intention to do that.

I am sure that the director was very genuine. But the problem is that the quite unintended result of what AQIS is now doing in the restructuring of AQIS is that, in reality, that may be the very effect that it will have on the smaller and medium sized operators. The larger operators will simply absorb the registration fee and offset it through the reduction in inspection fees, but the smaller operators will not have the opportunity to do this.

PARA.TAB: It is important to recognise that these are small businesses, primarily Australian owned, employing local labour in our rural and regional areas, and that they are doing their best to contribute to our level of exports. These firms will not be able to wear the sorts of increases in AQIS charges that these regulations will impose. I want to put on record to all of those in the meat industry that the Democrats are concerned about the possible forcing out of smaller operators. I assure the government and the new Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, Senator Collins, that we will be looking to work with them and the opposition to avoid this outcome at all costs. Preliminary conversations with the minister indicate that he is aware of our concerns and is willing to act to ensure that smaller operators will not be destroyed by these charges.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Knowles Sen S.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Today I want to talk in a little more detail about the sports rorts of the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories, Mrs Kelly, because the sports rorts affair has not only exposed the gross ministerial mishandling of public finances, taxpayers' money—
—Which we warned about in this chamber two years ago.

—That is exactly right, we did warn. Senator Baume was the one who raised this subject some two years ago because, as the then shadow minister for sport, he found what was happening through the department and alerted the government and this parliament to the problem. Now, of course, we have seen the magnitude of what Senator Baume predicted. It is important to note that Senator Baume did pick this up and tried to get an explanation, albeit unsuccessfully.
—Through Senate estimates committees, yes.

—That is right, through the Senate estimates committee system, and there was just absolute and utter stonewalling. I think we have now seen the magnitude of what Senator Baume was talking about at that time and, with further and further examination of it, the closer we get to it the more clearly we see how this was politically manipulated to the ends of the Labor Party, to ensure that some of the electorates that were recipients of this money were favoured so positively by Minister Kelly.

PARA.TAB: It also gives an interesting indication of how the government believed that it already had some voters in its pockets. When saying that, I refer to the seat of Fremantle. The seat of Fremantle has been traditionally a very safe Labor seat, but over recent elections Labor's majority in the seat of Fremantle has slipped and slipped and slipped. In the recent ones it has slipped by over five per cent. Yet this is a seat that has been held by the Treasurer of a Labor government and, therefore, taken for granted. Figures from the Auditor-General show that the seat of Fremantle received $225,350 under the sports rorts—less than any other federal Labor-held seat in Western Australia.

The degree of electoral bribe was much less, as I say, in Fremantle than anywhere else; and that just typifies the way in which this government operates. Its grant to the seat of Stirling, I have to say, was not all that flash, either, because it had given up hope of winning the seat of Stirling—absolutely given that away. The seat of Fremantle has some very needy areas within it that just got nothing. In the light of further admissions by the federal minister, Ros Kelly, that she was responsible for selecting the $30 million worth of projects, I think it is ironic that Fremantle was put a poor last behind the rest of Western Australia's Labor seats.

By the look of these figures, winning the seat appeared to be seen as some lay-down misere whereby the government did not have to worry. Labor could take the people of Fremantle for granted and politically target the funds at seats such as Swan, which were hanging, and still hang, in the balance. Of course, with the recent announcement that the current member for Swan, Kim Beazley, will be going to the seat of Brand, the people of Swan have seen the last of any money from this federal Labor government. Quite clearly, it is now throwing Swan away and Swan will get the same treatment as any of the other seats that were not considered winnable by the Labor Party.

Let me draw the distinction with some of the other seats. The seat of Perth, for example, which was contested and won by Stephen Smith, the former adviser to the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) and Labor Party apparatchik, received over double the amount of money—$604,035—that was allocated to Fremantle. Why? It was a new candidate who needed support—`Let us make sure we win it'. The Liberal Party had a very good candidate in that seat and Labor knew that it was going to be a very tough seat to win. So what did it do? It poured money into it. Mr Beazley's seat, the Federal Finance Minister's seat, the seat of Swan, received a staggering $317,000 more than Fremantle. That is not surprising because, as I have said before, it is an increasingly marginal Labor seat. The seat of Brand received $432,673 and the seat of Canning got $406,592. The latter, being held by the Assistant Treasurer, George Gear, also received vastly more funding than Fremantle.

The average value of grants given to Labor-held seats was $257,000, but Fremantle received $31,650 less than the average Labor seat in Australia and $100,650 less than the average Labor marginal seat. It is quite clear that Fremantle has been totally and utterly given the flick by this government, but it will be interesting to see what happens in the next few weeks. Only 5.7 per cent of the $3.9 million Mrs Kelly decided to give to Western Australian electorates went to Fremantle. Amid the scandalous mishandling of this major public expenditure by Mrs Kelly, which saw the biggest grants going to five Labor-held seats in Western Australia, Fremantle was just left out in the cold as not being important.

Even more appalling is the fact that Fremantle people will never know why they did not get a level of funding similar to that of other Western Australian Labor electorates. In her inimitable mishandling of this whole affair, Mrs Kelly has admitted that few records on allocating the grants were kept or even made. It is beyond comprehension how any minister can start dishing out public money—taxpayers' money—and not keep a record. It is not only me and all my colleagues who cannot understand this, but the people of seats such as Fremantle, who will never know.

The Labor-held seat of Kalgoorlie fared a lot better than Fremantle—as, of course, did every other Labor seat. Kalgoorlie picked up $375,200 under Mrs Kelly's sports rorts program. Some towns in the Kalgoorlie electorate did relatively well out of the grants; but when it comes to some of the areas in the Kalgoorlie electorate, Mrs Kelly should look at her claim that she has allocated this money as a `needs based' funding source.

An Australian Bureau of Statistics survey has found that there are dramatically varying levels of affluence and poverty in the goldfields; but this Labor government does not worry about that, because once again Kalgoorlie is a seat it holds. It is a seat it does not fear it will lose while it puts up with a member like Graeme Campbell speaking against the Prime Minister and against Labor Party policy on every issue. The survey found that the towns of Wiluna and Menzies and the trans-Australian railway communities were amongst the most socio-economically disadvantaged areas in Western Australia. Did it matter to Mrs Kelly? Did it matter to any of the ministers in dishing out public money? No, it has not mattered to them at all. The Kalgoorlie Miner newspaper this week quoted Goldfields Esperance Development Authority director Rob Walster as saying:

SPEECH.PARA: If you live in Menzies you choose not to work. The only thing that keeps Menzies going as a town is that people choose to live there for historical reasons.

This Labor government has simply left many of those goldfields towns out to dry, and that is it. It has just left them there. Towns like Wiluna and Menzies and the trans-Australian railway communities were very conveniently forgotten, in spite of their socio-economic disadvantage.

PARA.TAB: Why is this Labor government treating people in Labor's own seats so poorly? While Mrs Kelly was handing out the $315,000 in her own affluent electorate, many of the people in Wiluna, Menzies and the trans-Australian railway communities were, and still are, living on the bottom rung of the ladder. Does this Labor government worry? No. She handed out money in her own electorate, and even in her own electorate many people believe that that was improper.

Mrs Kelly should be made to go to places like Wiluna and Menzies and other communities in rural Australia. She does not bother to go anywhere where there is not a camera flashgun going off somewhere or a television microphone that can be conveniently put at her mouth. It is often said about Mrs Kelly that she will hear a biro click and smile because she thinks a photograph is being taken of her. Why does she not get out to some of these electorates? Why does she not get out to some of these towns which are in the same shocking socio-economic position as Wiluna and Menzies, and explain her own slipshod funding priorities and the way taxpayers' money has been used and distributed by the federal government?

These are the sorts of desperately needy communities which could use the $100,000 Mrs Kelly gave to the ACT Touch Football Association for an office, creche and meeting room. I am not saying that that particular group did not need money. What I am saying is that some of these disadvantaged communities need special attention. But because the government thinks it has got their votes—though, believe me, many of these people do not vote Labor—and because it holds the seat, they suddenly become unimportant.

I think that the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories presided over a most morally corrupt financial scam which, as we said earlier, Senator Baume tried to alert this parliament to some two years ago. Even in her haste to give the majority of the money to Labor electorates, Mrs Kelly ignored the traditional Labor voters. The traditional Labor voters I now refer to, of course, are those in Fremantle and particularly Kalgoorlie. She left them last when handing out grants to Labor seats.

What will be interesting to watch is how many of the ministers go and unlock their departmental bank accounts and start handing out money to the seat of Fremantle now that a by-election is going to be held in that seat. It is by no means a lay-down misere for the Labor Party. No matter what they think of Dr Lawrence, she led the Labor Party to a devastating defeat in Western Australia last year. We will now see federal ministers, making up for the fact that there is no state government to pork-barrel Fremantle, doing it from Canberra.

I can assure this parliament that many of us will be watching very closely how much money is poured from federal taxpayers' pockets into the seat of Fremantle over the next five weeks. Somehow or other, this Labor government is going to have to make up for what it has done to the people of Fremantle in ignoring them for so long and taking them for granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am overjoyed to hear Senator Knowles remind the House that it is two years or so since I first alerted this chamber, and the Senate estimates committees, to this problem. It is astounding to me that the media at that stage found it not worth reporting, and yet we had clear evidence of absolutely disgraceful bias in the distribution of these funds. Certainly the amount was a lot less then because the government was not quite as blatant, but can I say this to the media: their failure to report this blatant abuse, this misuse of public money, gave Mrs Kelly a clear feeling she could get away with it. I believe the magnitude and the disgraceful nature of these sports rorts, now revealed by the Auditor-General, are partly the responsibility of an indolent media which decided that this kind of behaviour was totally acceptable and should not be reported. I invite the media to go back and have a look at those Senate estimates hearings and look at the nonsense that was responded to.
—Typifies their Labor bias, too.

—I acknowledge Senator Knowles's interjection. For some of them, it typifies either a bias or the fact that so many of them have been terrorised by this government with vulgar threats of non-access to information if they dare run articles attacking, particularly, the Prime Minister. We have seen evidence of the former editor of the Sunday Age being told that his employees would not have access to prime ministerial press conferences because of a story they had written which was critical of the Prime Minister.

PARA.TAB: So we have here a situation where, basically, the Auditor-General was alerted to what was happening because of what the Senate estimates committee system revealed. That is why it is absolutely vital that there be no further diminution of the powers of Senate estimates committees, or the capacity of this chamber to debate their reports and recommendations or the matters that come before Senate estimates committees. That was one of the major reservations I had to the changes that have already taken place to limit debate in this chamber on what happens before Senate estimate committees. I think it is a trend in the wrong direction and I am very concerned about it. Maybe the media can take the credit for the fact that, because they helped give Mrs Kelly a false sense of security, she behaved in this incredible way which has now been revealed, in respect of $30 million or something like that.

I remind this chamber that, as part of my sports policy when I was shadow minister for sport before the last election, I said that we would cancel this program because it was so crooked. All that happened then was that Mrs Kelly attacked me for proposing to take money away from sports people. It was removing a Labor Party slush fund paid for by the taxpayers of Australia.

Now I want to deal with another matter. The Maitland Mercury has issued a front-page story announcing `Piggery partners rate debt'. Basically, it is a strong criticism by the Mayor of Maitland that a company partly owned but run by a Mr Achilles Constantinidis owes three years in back rates to the Maitland City Council. This is not the company that is involved in the piggery venture of which Mr Constantinidis is a half-owner with the Prime Minister. This is another of Mr Constantinidis's companies. But he obviously has a reluctance to meet his bills, whether they are in Mr Keating's jointly owned venture or in his own companies. We all know, for example, that the Keating piggery companies have not paid workers compensation insurance for three years and that writs had to be issued in the Supreme Court of New South Wales before they eventually, on the steps of the court, paid their bill.

What intrigues me about this matter is that the company in this case which has not paid its rates is called Poyntell Pty Ltd. I have had this paper since last September, although the latest story is only this week. The council papers of last September revealed that Poyntell owed the council $92,533.85 in unpaid rates. But since September, an additional $32,291 for the 12 months to June 30 has been levied against the company and only about $7,000 of that bill has been paid off. There is something like $117,000 still owed to a country council. That is a lot of money, Mr Acting Deputy President, as you would well know from your local government background.
