It is the biggest debt owing to the council. That is one thing. Mr Constantinidis is a big man; he is the biggest debtor in unpaid rates to the Maitland council. The Mayor of Maitland, Councillor Bob Gee—and I do not think anyone can accuse that area of being ultra-conservative; it is in the coalfields of New South Wales—said that, quite frankly, the council would like the outstanding rates to be paid in full before Mr Constantinidis launched into another investment, like the $80 million piggery joint venture which involves his and Mr Keating's companies somehow magically being able to borrow $30 million against assets which certainly do not appear to be worth anything like that, on any reasonable valuation. In fact, on the basis of existing accounts, there appears to be a clear deficit in real values on assets as against liabilities. So here is Mr Constantinidis, Mr Keating's partner, once again being involved in a debt which this local council is in no position to sustain. The ratepayers of Maitland, quite rightly, should feel as offended as their local mayor.

What is extraordinary about this—and this is what I find fascinating because it fits a pattern of behaviour—is this company, according to the Maitland city records, owes Maitland all this back rate money. I would not call those records into doubt. One would think that if it owes that money that would be a liability in the company's books. Naturally, I have had a look at the latest annual return of Poyntell Pty Ltd at the Securities Commission. The Senate will be astounded—or maybe the Senate will not be astounded—to know there is no such debt recorded in its books. There is the annual return for the year to 30 June 1992 signed, of course, by Mr Constantinidis, but signed, I might say, on 31 December 1992—allegedly signed. It has to be signed by then because they have got to have their annual meeting by then under the law. Curiously, that signed document was not filed with the Securities Commission until 5 July 1993. I wonder why it sat on Mr Constantinidis's desk for so many months before he actually got around to filing it, particularly as there had been no annual accounts for this group filed for six years.

As a result, Poyntell received a deregistration notice from the Securities Commission for failure to put in annual returns. It is like the Brown and Hatton Group, Mr Keating's half-owned piggery group, revisited. Most of them got notices for failing to put in their annual returns on time. When I first raised this matter, not one of those companies had put in annual returns to the ASC even though they had been registered since 1988.

What interests me is: who is right? Is the council right that Poyntell Pty Ltd owes it money, or is the company right in saying, `Oh, no, we don't owe anyone anything on 30 June 1992. We have got current assets of $400 and total assets also of $400 because they are the shareholders' funds contributed by the shareholders. There are four lots of $100 each'.

What also intrigues me is that this pattern of failure to meet the requirements of the Australian Securities Commission is not the only significant matter relating to this company because a couple of the other directors of this company are Mr John Scoufis and Mr James Scoufis. They interested me because I can remember looking at the Olympia Refrigeration Group that is part of Mr Keating's half-owned piggery enterprise where there are three Olympia Refrigeration companies. There is another one called Olympia Refrigeration Pty Ltd which is not in the Keating group because it has been delisted, apart from anything else. It was wiped out on a creditor's petition from Manufacturers Mutual Insurance Ltd when it was owned by the Scoufis family. It had failed to pay—surprise, surprise—workers compensation insurance premiums.

I do not know whether this is all some terrible, quaint, unfortunate coincidence, but it does seem extraordinary to me that Mr Achilles Constantinidis has this close relationship and is on the board of one of his own companies with these people, Mr John Scoufis and Mr James Scoufis, whose company went broke failing to pay workers compensation insurance premiums.

Frankly, I feel that Mr Keating's partner in his venture clearly has some commercial problems, some financial problems, and they are up to him to resolve. Clearly, he has some difficulty in meeting the requirements of the Corporations Law, which is that you should put in accurate annual returns, and timely annual returns—in fact, put in annual returns at all. It would seem to me that the person who is in partnership with the Prime Minister should be seen to be behaving in a proper and legal way. It further seems to me that Mr Constantinidis, on the face of it, does not appear to be meeting the sorts of high standards one would expect of a partner of the Prime Minister in a multimillion dollar, multinational joint venture which involves huge indebtedness, which Mr Constantinidis assures us is not to be secured by any kinds of personal guarantees.

It seems to me that Mr Keating obviously has great confidence in Mr Constantinidis to allow him to be the person who looks after the financial affairs of all the piggery group companies that Mr Keating has this almost half million dollar investment of his own money in—at least, we assume it is his own money. Why would Mr Keating put such confidence in a man who, even in the piggery group, has demonstrated that he cannot readily—until nagged by me, or by the Australian Securities Commission as a result of my pressure—put in proper returns. They had to be massively corrected and they were massively late—multimillions of dollars of overstating of profits or understating of losses, and millions of dollars of overstating the real values, the net assets of the group, when five of the seven companies of the group had a deficit of assets against liabilities. I think Mr Constantinidis should smarten up his act, and I am astounded that the Prime Minister should be in partnership with a man who so consistently flouts the requirements of the companies law and the requirements of the Australian Securities Commission.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Administrative Services. I refer to the employment contract between the former industry minister, Mr Griffiths, and Mrs Harrison. I ask the minister whether Mrs Harrison in fact signed that contract and, if she did not, who signed it on her behalf?
—I was asked this question yesterday. I declined to answer it yesterday for the same very good reasons that I decline to answer it today.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I ask the minister to explain the reasons—because he did not do so yesterday—particularly in the light of the fact that he was prepared to say that Mr Gordon Lennox, a staff member of Mr Griffiths, signed on behalf of Mr Griffiths. Why is the minister willing to tell us who signed for one party and not tell us who signed for the other party? As I understand it, the police investigation has been completed. Will he table the contract of employment?

—The reasons I gave yesterday are in the Hansard. I am not aware that the police investigation has concluded. Until all the investigations have been concluded it is not my intention to provide any further information other than to the people conducting the relevant investigations.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy. The imperative to extend and improve Australia's export performance will need to be a primary focus of government policy for some time to come. Can the minister advise what action the government has taken to further develop the export performance of rural based industries?
—Petrol prices are up; how does that help?

—Senator Kemp might like to listen to the answer to this question, as an encapsulated demonstration of the degree of initiative that is being demonstrated by a range of Australian companies that I think most Australians are not even aware is going on. The government supplies an extensive program of financial support for innovation and development, particularly of value added industries, in Australia. We are exploring the globe for market opportunities, both great and small, to improve Australia's export performance. Senator Kemp might be interested to know that our rural entrepreneurs actually do have the skills to capture these opportunities by some very innovative marketing.
—Whack some more taxes on them, why don't you?

—These are all programs that Senator Kemp's party was proposing to close down, to its shame. The government actually provides a range of agribusiness development programs, greatly appreciated by rural Australia, I might add, that provide individuals or groups with $15 million worth of support for direct funding or consultancy resources.

—I am pleased to advise the Senate that yesterday I approved a further five projects—some in Senator Kemp's home state, if he would like to keep quiet for just a second—that will benefit this country greatly. I would like to list the projects to give senators an idea of the range of innovation that is being developed in the rural areas of Australia.

PARA.TAB: Two seafood processors in Robe, South Australia, will receive $200,000 in grants to develop markets in Asia for live lobsters. Stahmann Farms of Moree will get $155,000 from the federal government to develop the export of pecan and other nuts to Singapore, Malaysia and Indonesia. Crown Lamb in West Footscray, Victoria, will receive a grant for a one-year project to develop markets in North America for retail packs of lamb.

I was very pleased to see that Detect Spray International of Albury, New South Wales, will receive a grant of $227,000 of federal government funding to develop markets in America and Europe for its technology—which is world class and I think world first—which electronically selects vegetation to be sprayed. This reduces the waste and the cost of agricultural chemicals and also minimises the environmental impact of agricultural chemicals. Merino Gold of Coburg, Victoria, will receive $252,000 to develop markets for its range of ultra fine and superfine wool garments in the United States and Asia.

I have listed this range of grants simply to indicate something that I think all senators should be aware of, and that is the degree of technical and technology expertise that is being developed by rural entrepreneurs that will greatly add to the value of exports from Australia. I wish all the companies that I have just mentioned—and I am sure I am joined by all honourable senators, particularly those with an interest in rural electorates—success in their ventures.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Administrative Services. Has the hitherto unknown existence of an account known as Australian Labor Party B and B account—it sounds like Brian Burke—resulted in the Victorian ALP submitting incomplete financial disclosure returns to the Australian Electoral Commission, thereby breaching sections 314AC and AD of the Electoral Act, which state that a party's financial returns must list all sums in excess of $1,500 received by or paid on behalf of the party to a person or organisation? If so, what action has been taken against the Victorian Australian Labor Party?

—I have seen the press reports that are the basis of Senator Campbell's question, as I am sure most honourable senators have. If there is a breach of any law, it will be the subject of report, either by the police investigation or the subsequent investigation. I can assure honourable senators that, if any of those indications suggest a breach of the Electoral Act, the Electoral Commission will not need my encouragement to pursue it. But, if it did need my encouragement, I would give it to it.

—My question, which is directed to the Minister for Health, refers to recent reports that brain shrinkage is associated with moderate alcohol consumption. Are steps being taken by the government to educate people about the risk of adverse consequences of alcohol consumption, even at a moderate level?

—I hope that the laughter is not coming from those who ought to be listening more carefully than others to the answer to this question. The question concerns brain shrinkage from alcohol consumption, and I would have thought that would be of interest to all senators. Having looked at some of them over time, I am sure it would be of particular interest to a few.

PARA.TAB: Given that brain shrinkage and impaired brain function are usually associated with heavy drinking and alcoholism, the study by Professor Harper, to which Senator Zakharov referred, does raise questions about what a safe level of alcohol consumption might be. Obviously, when we look at liver disease, strokes and brain damage that are often associated with excessive alcohol consumption, this kind of study is something that we all ought to consider.

Alcohol is second only to tobacco as the major cause of drug related mortality in Australia. Approximately 6,600 deaths last year, or more than a quarter of all drug related deaths, were attributed to alcohol. The national campaign against drug abuse estimated that alcohol abuse in 1990 cost Australia almost $7 billion—more than three times the total Commonwealth and state government revenue from alcohol.

Alcohol is responsible also for the majority of drug deaths in young persons aged 15 to 34. On the other hand, studies have indicated that low to moderate consumption may in fact be associated with health benefits—for instance, a lowered risk of heart and circulatory disease.

TALK.START.PARA: —Oh good!

—Senator Calvert is happy with that line. I am glad to hear that. Estimating levels of consumption which are safe for all people, though, is a pretty complex, if not impossible, task. Factors such as gender, age and existing health nutrition as well as the manner, frequency and circumstances in which alcohol is consumed all have health consequences.

PARA.TAB: The NHMRC has addressed the question of whether there is a safe level of consumption of alcohol for men and women. It has recommended that education campaigns be continued. It emphasises that, in any given situation, responsibility involves a number of environmental factors, as well as other factors, and the recognition that no absolutely safe level of consumption can be recommended.

The NHMRC also recommends that strategies be adopted by governments to encourage a change in community attitudes towards drinking, including the recognition that responsible drinking involves the concept of an acceptable level of risk. It has also recommended that the following guidelines be promoted as being consistent with responsible drinking. For men, consumption should not exceed four units or 40 grams of absolute alcohol a day on a regular basis, or 28 units a week. For women, that consumption should not exceed two units or 20 grams a day, or 14 units a week on a regular basis.

It has also recommended that binge drinking is potentially hazardous and that people should have at least two alcohol free days a week. I might indicate that I have been managing this of late. The job of Minister for Health is great; it does change one's perceptions! It is also recommended that abstinence be promoted as desirable during pregnancy. I hope that an adult alcohol education and awareness campaign can have as an overarching component a national, comprehensive and ongoing alcohol education strategy.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Trade. Following the suggestion in the Australian Financial Review yesterday that we might not need a minister for industry, I hasten to assure the minister that, in the view of the Democrats, we do. Not only that, but also we need a Minister for Trade with `high quality new ideas'. I ask the minister: Firstly, does he agree that yesterday's trade deficit of $1.76 billion shows a continuing trend of imports rising faster than exports? Secondly, does he agree that the rising dollar will hit our exports, and that imports are likely to rise even faster as we come out of the recession? Thirdly, does he agree that on the figures for the last six months the much publicised increase in manufactured exports is unlikely to slow down the rising trade deficit? Finally, can he offer any thoughts on how he intends to tackle that imbalance?

—All that, and in only four minutes, too! It is the time equivalent of the Prime Minister's `around the world for sixpence', but I will do what I can in the four minutes which I have available to me. I certainly do not accept that the trade deficit figures show a continuing trend of imports rising faster than exports. It depends on the time period, but whichever time period we take, it does not show those results. In the long run, over the last five years, if those are the sorts of trend figures Senator Spindler is looking at, merchandise exports have recorded an average trend growth of about twice that of imports—7.9 per cent, whereas the figure for growth in imports has been 4.8 per cent.

PARA.TAB: A similar picture is evident when we look at trade in services. Exports of services have recorded an average growth rate of 8.7 per cent, which is, as I say, close to double that of services imports. If we look at it over the medium term of five years, the statistics do not bear out Senator Spindler's particular indication. However, if we take a more immediate look at it, for the six months ended December 1993, Australian exports of goods and services grew by about eight per cent while imports grew by a little over 7 1/2 per cent.

Nobody who has a trade deficit can say that the trend is exactly as he would wish, but my advice is that, with regard to the six months ended December 1993, the current account deficit is slightly down from last year's, in accordance with expectations, and that exports of goods and services grew by about eight per cent and imports by a little over 7 1/2 per cent.

So, firstly, those figures—either in the medium-term perspective or in the shorter term—do not bear out those concerns. I do not want to get into anything that could even remotely constitute speculating about the dollar, but there are, of course, trade and other impacts of the rising dollar. It has an impact on the Australian dollar value of our debts, on our payment of those debts, on interest payments and on competitiveness. But if going beyond that would create even a remote possibility of its being interpreted as speculating about the dollar, I will not do that.

The honourable senator referred to the much publicised increase in manufactured exports. Although it may not have sounded like it, I know that the honourable senator would have welcomed that great increase, as I do—that continuing and very successful product of the policies of the government, not just in the trade area, led by Senator Cook in the past, but also in the area of industry policy and other economic policies.

I suspect the honourable senator is aware—but perhaps not everyone in the chamber is, and it is very important to know—that a recent comparison of 32 major trading nations showed that Australia had the fastest trend growth in elaborately transformed manufactured exports of any OECD country since the mid-1980s and the eighth fastest growth overall. This sector is growing quickly and is now becoming, as the honourable senator knows, a very substantial part of our exports.

The implication of the honourable senator's question was: will manufactured exports by themselves close the trade deficit? No, they will not; they are making an important and welcome contribution but they will not by themselves be sufficient. That is why the forecasts coming out of the Outlook conference from the Bureau of Agricultural and Resource Economics have been so encouraging for the future in the whole balance of trade.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. The ABS publication released at 11.30 a.m. on 2 February—yesterday—stated that merchandise exports for the last six months rose at the rate of six per cent, and merchandise imports rose at the rate of 10 per cent. That is the reality that we live with now and that is the reality that the minister has to cope with. In view of the fact that the minister did not seem to contemplate any direct action, I am asking him whether he is willing to institute changes in Australia's anti-dumping laws which are currently skewed against Australia's producers and manufacturers. Secondly, would he favour a more intensive use of the exemption clauses in GATT when that becomes necessary if this trend continues?

—I do not think that traversing extreme options like that is in any way warranted by the data. Australia's export performance in a range of areas has been very successful. It has been successful, as I said, in relation to the manufactured goods area, it is booming in the services area, and the prospects look encouraging on the commodities front as projected at the recent Outlook conference.

PARA.TAB: One can get very excited about immediate or monthly figures because of their volatility, or even about very short-term trends. But it seems, on the basis of the last six months, particularly if we take services into account—which the honourable senator excluded from the figures which he mentioned—that we are on track to have the sort of trade deficit numbers that the Treasurer alluded to in his most recent forecast, and certainly not worse figures than those which we foresaw in the budget. I think the signs indicate that trade performance can and will continue to succeed. In the more open economy that we have now, there will be a higher proportion of exports and imports in the overall balance of our economy. That is actually a good thing, but it is important that we continue to focus on the export effort. I will not be taking those two steps to which the honourable senator referred in his question, but I will be taking steps to encourage the export efforts of Australians.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister representing the Minister for Justice. It arises because of the close ties which exist between Australia and Papua New Guinea and reports of increasing crime problems being experienced by our near neighbours. I therefore ask the minister whether consideration has been given to upgrading the arrangements for law enforcement liaison between Australia and Papua New Guinea.

—The premise of Senator Colston's question is right. There is a close relationship between Australia and Papua New Guinea. In that context the Australian Federal Police has been considering a range of issues relating to our relationship with Papua New Guinea as well as our relationship with other South Pacific countries. In doing so, we have decided to establish a liaison office in Papua New Guinea. The office will open on 7 February and will be staffed by a detective superintendent from the AFP. It will be operating from the Australian High Commission in Port Moresby. The person involved is experienced. In fact, he has established experience in Papua New Guinea over a number of years, having assisted the Royal PNG Constabulary as a police adviser.

PARA.TAB: The overall objective of the Australian Government in this area is to facilitate the exchange of criminal intelligence between our country and Papua New Guinea. Its objective is to foster cooperation in combating criminal activities and, in doing so, combat activities which affect the social and economic structure of both our countries. The decision to place an officer in Port Moresby builds on activity already existing within the South Pacific region. It will complement the already existing position of AFP liaison officer in the South Pacific region. The person in Port Moresby will work closely with that particular law enforcement officer as well as working closely with law enforcement agencies of the region.

There are two threats that we are concerned about. We are concerned about threats by criminal elements to South Pacific countries. We are also concerned of course about threats by criminal elements, particularly international drug traffickers, who may be using such countries as transit posts into Australia. The AFP's commitment is to cooperate with local law enforcement agencies, particularly the regional ones, and to continue to build on our international network. It is worth noting here that this appointment will be an important link in that network. We currently have 15 officers in 13 countries in other parts of the world, though the majority of those officers are in the Asia-Pacific region. This, being so close to us, will be an important addition to that international link.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy. I refer to his speech at ABARE's annual Outlook conference this week at which he indicated that there was a need for taxation reform to assist exporters, and that he may soon speak to the Treasurer, Mr Willis, about this. I ask: does this mean that he is finally admitting that the heavy burden of taxation, particularly the indirect taxation that our primary producers bear, is a major factor in the current rural crisis? What type of taxation or what areas of taxation does he consider need reforming? In view of the pressing financial crisis facing some primary producers in my own state and in other areas of Australia, how soon will he be speaking to the Treasurer?

—The only difficulty with the question is that I did not say anything of the sort. Unfortunately, one of the peak bodies that was represented at the conference put out a press statement attributing remarks to me that had been made by one of the questioners at ABARE. At the conference I said that taxation policy is a matter which, at the end of the day, is for the Treasurer and not for me, and it has to be legitimately considered along with all other government policy in terms of its effect on regional Australia. This was in response to a statement made that taxation changes in respect of fuel excise, for example, were `being targeted at rural Australia'.

PARA.TAB: As I pointed out to the conference, that is a nonsense, because taxation measures, of their very effect, have to be delivered fairly across all of the population. But obviously they have effect in different areas of Australia. The most horrendous problem that could ever be visited on rural Australia would be the introduction of a point of sale tax or consumption tax. That is why I have opposed that particular measure. The farther away we get from the point of supply the worse we are hurt disproportionately. It is an inequitable tax, as we have pointed out again and again. A classic example is my own regional area of the Northern Territory where the residents of the city of Darwin would pay in excess of $100 a year more in federal taxes for using precisely the same amount of electricity as people living in Sydney.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I rise on a point of order.
—I know that the honourable senator does not want his policies discussed.

—I raise a point of order under the standing order dealing with relevance. The question had nothing to do with option C from the tax summit of a few years ago and the Prime Minister's proposal to have a consumption tax, so I ask you, Mr President, to direct the minister to get back to Senator Ferguson's question.
—There is no point of order. The question related to taxes and that is what the answer is about.

—I do know that Dr Hewson has said publicly that Fightback is dead, although I cannot understand how he could say that, since fighting back is all he seems to be doing these days. But it is a fact that nothing could hurt rural or regional Australia more than a point of sale tax. I could not understand—this is shameful—why all of those lackeys in the National Party of Australia, who are supposed to represent the bush, toed the line and put their hands up for that inequitable tax, along with everyone else in the coalition. They should hang themselves for doing so, and rural Australia should hang them for doing so. In fact, at the last election rural Australia did hang them for doing so, which is why the majority of rural seats are represented by Labor members of parliament.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. The minister spent at least three minutes telling us what he did not say at the Outlook conference. Perhaps he could tell us what he did say at the Outlook conference. Or is the minister telling me that he does not believe that there is any need for any taxation reform to assist exporters in Australia?
—I have just told the Senate—

PARA.TAB: Senator Ian Macdonald interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —I should be annoyed by those interjections from Senator Ian Macdonald; but in respect of the advice we just received from Senator Richardson, and knowing that Senator Macdonald's brain at this stage is probably the size of a peanut, I will not get angry about it. I repeat what I said at the ABARE conference: taxation policy is as legitimate an area to consider as all other government policy in respect of its effect on rural Australia.

—I refer the Minister for Foreign Affairs to a statement by Yasser Arafat, Chairman of the Palestine Liberation Organisation, that he hopes to sign an accord with Israel next week in Cairo. I ask: has the Australian government been advised on talks between Israel and the PLO on attempts to break the impasse over security which has delayed the start of Palestinian self-rule? What is the Australian government's assessment of the progress of these talks?

—We have been encouraged both by the media reports and by our diplomatic reporting from Australian posts in the region that the PLO chairman, Yasser Arafat, and Israel's Foreign Minister, Shimon Peres, achieved a breakthrough in Davos last weekend. We very much hope that it will prove possible for Arafat and Peres to sign an agreement in Cairo next week, as has been foreshadowed. But at this stage it is not entirely clear how much work remains to be done on all the various security issues that have been the subject of recent negotiation. The key disputes are the question of control of the border crossings between Gaza and Egypt and between Jericho and Jordan, the size of the Jericho administrative area and the security of Jewish settlers in Gaza after the Israeli withdrawal.

PARA.TAB: The declaration of principles that was signed in Washington on 13 September last year was the major breakthrough so far in the search for a comprehensive settlement, providing the framework for further negotiation and more detailed and complex agreements on withdrawal, and on the nature of Palestinian autonomy. Australia has recognised from the outset that that declaration of principles was only the first step in clearly a long and difficult journey. We see, however, the delay in the Israeli withdrawal from Gaza and Jericho, originally scheduled for 13 December last year, as being disappointing, but as not undermining the accord.

The most important consideration is that the leaders on both sides do still seem committed to the process. The government is confident that the remaining security disputes will soon be resolved in that atmosphere. We continue to urge all sides to maintain flexible negotiating positions. We are encouraged by the fact that neither side has said that the 13 April deadline for final withdrawal from Gaza and Jericho cannot be met. We will certainly continue to impress on both sides the importance that we in Australia attach to the timetable that was set out in the declaration of principles.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Communications and the Arts. I refer to yesterday's report in the Australian Financial Review, which I note has not been denied by the latest minister for communications, Mr Lee, that Telecom admitted to the minister almost three weeks ago that it has hundreds and hundreds of hours of tape recordings of conversations involving a number of small business operators—known as COT cases—with serious complaints against the organisation. In view of the seriousness of these reports and the frightening implications for the privacy rights of citizens, rather than Mr Lee privately passing the parcel to his colleagues, why has he not made a strong public statement clarifying the situation, making it clear that the government will not tolerate any unauthorised telephone interceptions or information gathering, and spelling out what action the government proposes to take to ensure that no similar conduct can occur in the future?

—The Minister for Communications and the Arts has advised me that he is aware of the allegations that Telstra has monitored telephone conversations of some members of the group known, as Senator Alston says, as COT—casualties of Telecom.

PARA.TAB: The minister raised the allegations in discussions with the chief executive of Telstra and the chairman of the board. As a result of those discussions, he wrote to the Attorney-General asking that he investigate whether a breach of the act had occurred, because that legislation which is administered by the Attorney-General permits interception of telecommunications by employees in the course of their duties.Yesterday he received a reply from the Attorney-General that indicates that the Minister for Justice has been asked to refer the matter to the Commissioner of the AFP to determine whether an investigation is warranted. The minister has also made a request to the Attorney-General. The Attorney-General has, in response to that request, directed that the legislation be examined to assess whether amendments are necessary to limit the breadth of the exception given to carrier employees.

The minister has requested a full report from Telstra. He has received an interim report which he is presently considering. He has received the assurances which one would expect from both Austel and Telstra, indicating full cooperation with any investigation. The minister's advice to me is that he considers it would be inappropriate to make any further comments on details of the allegations while the matter is before the AFP.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Given that the minister has been sitting on this matter for at least three weeks, why is the public not entitled to know what is going on? What is the nature and extent of any unauthorised interceptions? Whether or not that results in police prosecutions is surely immaterial to the facts of the matter. Why cannot the minister tell the community what is happening and whether all the statements and denials from Telecom are accurate, and at least make sure that the public is party to what is going on, rather than in the minister's usual way, trying to stitch up a deal in private?
—To describe the very proper actions which the minister has taken as `trying to stitch up a deal in private' is attributing Senator Alston's motives to Mr Lee. It is entirely inappropriate.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Transport and deals with the Tasmanian freight equalisation scheme. I acknowledge publicly the extra funding that the scheme received in the last budget. The regional development task force in its report said that the scheme could be cut up by executive government action and that this created uncertainty which meant that bankers and shareholders would not allow companies to take the subsidy into account when considering expansion or new development proposals. The task force recommended that the scheme be legislated and that a review be undertaken. Is the government committed to the continuance and enhancement of the scheme; is it prepared to make sure that it is legislated; and, in the review, will there be opportunity for submissions and input by the public and groups such as the committee for transport equality for Tasmania?

—Obviously the Minister for Transport and I are aware that the Kelty committee has recommended that the federal government examine the structure of the Tasmanian freight equalisation scheme and also that it legislate for its continuation. Nobody on behalf of the government is going to respond piece by piece to individual recommendations of that very comprehensive report. We will be giving very careful consideration to those issues in the context of preparing the response to the Kelty committee recommendations; that will be part of the bigger statement of which Senator Harradine and the Senate would be aware because of the public statements of other ministers and the overall publicity surrounding that matter.

PARA.TAB: I think it is reasonably fair to say that there is a fair bit of evidence to support the view that the government is committed to the continuation of the freight equalisation scheme. After all, in October last year the Prime Minister announced the provision of additional funding in 1993-94 and each of the following three years. I think Senator Harradine will probably remember that announcement. If I am not mistaken, he probably was aware of it at the time, as I recall. That statement did refer to funding in each of the following three years to enhance the operation of the scheme, for the reasons to which Senator Harradine alluded.

I think there is a fair bit of evidence that the government has a commitment to the continuation of the scheme. Whether we will take the particular course of action recommended by the Kelty committee will have to be considered in the context of the overall government consideration of that report and the parallel reports on employment, et cetera.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the minister for Minister for Primary Industries and Energy to statements by ABARE's Executive Director, Dr Brian Fisher, at the Outlook conference this week that, firstly, the value of rural commodities is expected to fall in the current year by two per cent; and secondly, the rural adjustment scheme will not be sufficient to cope with the 20 per cent of farmers hopelessly struggling from the effects of Australia's worst recession. In the light of those statements by Mr Fisher, can the minister inform the Senate what value of the Australian dollar against the US dollar was used in the preparation of ABARE's gloomy forecasts? Can the minister tell us what steps he intends to take, as the new minister, to address the inadequacies of the rural adjustment scheme?

—I will ask ABARE to provide me with the details of the methodology used. Contrary to Senator Crane's assertion that ABARE provided gloomy forecasts at the conference, the facts are quite the reverse. As has been noted widely in the rural press and in the industry publications that have been reporting extensively the proceedings of the conference, for the first time for some time, rural Australia does have grounds to be cautiously optimistic about the future. I think rural Australia is starting this year on better grounds across the board than for some years, certainly in the recent past.

PARA.TAB: The issue of commodity prices generally across both the resource and agricultural sectors is firming up. The situation even with industries such as wool—an industry with which Senator Crane and several other active primary producers who are also senators are involved—is positive. Senator Baume, of course, does not think that Labor members of parliament should have any interests in primary production. Senators would know that the outlook for cattle, for sheep production, for wool, for industries such as the dairy industry and the wine industry—one of our most rapidly growing value added export primary industries in Australia—is very positive. The general message being delivered at the ABARE conference is not one of pessimism at all; it is one of cautious optimism. Underlying that, of course, is the significant achievement of the completion of the Uruguay Round.

As I said at the conference—I say it again here; I am sure that most people in the primary sector would agree with me—an enormous amount of work now has to happen in terms of cementing the detail of that round and getting it operational. The benefits that will be received from it will be gradual and will need a great deal of vigilance by the Minister for Trade and all other ministers to ensure that our trading partners fulfil their commitments under the round. I conclude by saying that the outlook for rural Australia in both the resource area and the agricultural area is probably looking more optimistic now than it has for some time.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I think it is very sad that the minister for primary industries obviously does not know what Dr Fisher's forecasts were with regard to agricultural commodity prices.
—Yes I do, Senator.

—No, the minister does not. They fell by two per cent. The minister talked about optimism. Can the minister confirm or deny that the position of ABARE has changed so that the rural adjustment scheme will now be used to provide more aid for farmers to leave their farms rather than debt reconstruction to allow them to return to a position of viability? The loss of viability is the result of the worst recession in the history of this nation—a recession created by his government.

—The level of support that is being given by this federal government to rural Australia is unparalleled. It has reached levels that would never have been achieved by those opposite. We are implementing schemes that those opposite were proposing be closed down. The level of support for the scheme that Senator Crane has mentioned has increased to in excess of $400 million. That is a level of expenditure in terms of assisting the reconstruction of rural Australia that the coalition would never have delivered.

—My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. I refer to the decision taken last year by the London Dumping Convention to end the disposal of industrial waste at sea by the end of 1995. Pasminco Metals EZ is urging the government to extend the deadline until at least 1997. The government has until 18 February to make or not make that extension. Is the minister of the opinion that Pasminco is able to meet the 1995 deadline set by the London Dumping Convention? Given the minister's strong support of the London convention's 1995 ban on the ocean dumping of radioactive waste and the support given to clean production by the Prime Minister, will he assure the parliament that Australia will not file a declaration of non-acceptance of the London dumping ban? Finally, if Australia does file that declaration, would it be true that Australia would then join Russia to be one of only two countries still abusing the oceans in this way?

—As my office advised Senator Bell's office this morning, Mrs Kelly, who is the relevant minister here, will be making a full statement on this question later this afternoon. In those circumstances, I think it would be quite inappropriate for me to pre-empt her.

—Congratulations on your election, Mr President. I direct my question to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy. In light of concern about the build-up of mouse numbers in parts of South Australia and Victoria, will the government urgently implement the recommendation of the Grains Research and Development Corporation's national rodent workshop to establish a national mouse plague commission to provide the capacity for early preventative action against mice, thereby avoiding in the future the disaster of last year's plague?

—This is a serious issue. When mice plagues occur, they cause agricultural Australia to lose heavily. I assure Senator Chapman that were I convinced that setting up yet another body under my portfolio—which is already profoundly overloaded with bodies, something I will look at shortly—would result in the death of one additional mouse, I would do it tomorrow. But I think there is considerable doubt about that being the case.

PARA.TAB: I was involved in this area years ago when I worked with CSIRO. Just in the last week my information was updated as a result of what I acknowledge to be the very keen interest that Senator Chapman has shown in this matter. One of the difficulties is that the most widely used rodenticide in Australia is strychnine. The data that I have seen does not really convince me that it has made any particular impact on mice plagues. The anti-coagulants that are available are frightfully expensive, as Senator Chapman would know. The CSIRO is presently conducting trials on a parasite in the Victorian mallee but it will be some months before the results of those trials are known.

Instead of setting up a commission, I am convening a meeting, hopefully next week, of the relevant officers of my department, experts from CSIRO, and representatives of that organisation's rodent task force to examine this question. Dr Hewson would be very welcome to drop into that meeting if he is looking for any advice on how to exterminate rats because all of the experts who could help him will be there.

TALK.START.PARA: —Ha, ha!

—It is not a laughing matter. It could actually work. A strategically located tube of strychnine-flavoured toothpaste, for example, might have some affect. An aerosol spray can of hair spray that has been loaded with napalm could be very effective. I am sure that we will be able to help Dr Hewson if he wants to call in and talk to us. I know from past experience that one method of dealing with rats which never works is going outside—

—Mr President, I rise on a point of order. The minister is now referring to rats. My question was quite specifically directed towards mice and the detrimental impact of mice on rural Australia. It had absolutely nothing to do with rats or with the remarks that Senator Collins has directed towards Dr Hewson. I am particularly concerned about the impact of mice on rural Australia. I ask you, Mr President, to ensure that the minister directs his attention to that very important subject.

—I referred to Dr Hewson because, at the moment, he would probably know more about how a mouse feels than I would. One method of dealing with rats which I know does not work is to go outside and say to the head rat, `Don't run around outside in the cold; come in'. That sort of control method for rats is never successful. What I will do—

—Order! I thought you were speaking to the point of order. I was going to make the point that mice and rats are both rodents, but my concern is that you were straying to speak about other animals. I ask you to get to the point.

—All in all, mice are only small rats. When I convene that meeting of experts and discuss with them the proposition of setting up such a commission, if their collective view is that it would assist, I will do so. One of the things that I am keen to do is to talk to CSIRO about the ways in which forecasting can be improved and whether a cost-effective procedure of dealing with mice might exist at some time in the future.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Defence. I refer the minister to his announcement late last year of the intention to purchase two landing ships from the United States Navy. Can the minister advise the Senate of the progress on this project?
—Last December I did announce the government's intention to purchase two surplus ships from the United States Navy, and we will use them for the purposes of training and as helicopter support ships.
—How old are they?

—Senator Hill has already asked Senator Foreman's supplementary question. The age varies. The United States has 14 ships it is retiring and has given Australia the first choice of two ships, so we can take the two best.
—How old are they?

—They vary—the 14 were built between 1968 and 1973. Senators might recall—although I do not think Senator Hill will because as shadow defence minister he never asked a question; I really should congratulate him at least on his maiden supplementary question, even though he did not get to his feet—that in 1991 the force structure review indicated that the possibility of a dedicated helicopter support ship purpose-built at a cost of $450 million would not fit the priorities of the Defence Force. However, it was then argued that if we could combine both a training ship such as the Jervis Bay and a helicopter support ship the economies of scale in the use of that would make it a worthwhile project.

PARA.TAB: The Newport class landing ship is a very capable ship. It has at least 20 years of life remaining in it. It has things such as the Phalanx anti-aircraft gun, which alone in cost would about equal what we will be paying for each of these two ships.

TALK.START.PARA: —Huge maintenance costs.

—Senator Hill again starts to bleat on. We were all disappointed when foreign affairs was taken off him and he was demoted, in his own eyes, to defence. I must congratulate him. He now heads a policy committee as a shadow minister. Here he is, the Leader of the Opposition in the Senate, lost two shadow portfolios in a row and now put in charge of a policy committee. Now he feels he can finally pluck up the courage to intervene on defence issues when he no longer has a responsibility.

PARA.TAB: Each of these ships will have the capability of carrying three or four helicopters; they are charged with diesel engines; and in the long term one of them will certainly be suitable for part conversion as a hospital ship. This follows similar decisions to purchase the Goldsborough which we are using for spare parts, and additional F111s. I think it is very important that the Australian Defence Force continues to keep its eyes on options other than purpose-built brand-new at the moment, and this will release resources for other essential areas in defence.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy. Will the minister confirm that since assuming his new portfolio responsibilities he has had discussions with miners, Aboriginal leaders and other interested parties with regard to the government's three-mine uranium policy? Will the minister restate his previous position on dropping this stupid policy, and will he argue for changes at the Labor Party September national conference?

—I think in order to do that I would first of all have to become a delegate. I am not, so I probably will not be. I was, along with my esteemed colleague Senator Loosley, a member of the ALP's policy committee which was set up to examine this question, I think in 1991—it seems an awfully long time ago. The recommendation of that committee, which was extremely public at the time, was that there should be a change. That has been my public position for a very long time. At the end of the day it is a matter for the ALP's conference to determine its view on uranium.
—They have to tell the government what to do, do they?
—In response to the interjections opposite, it is interesting that the coalition is very proud of the fact—

PARA.TAB: Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —It boasts all the time about the fact that the rank and file members of its parties delegate all of the responsibility to this group of Rhodes scholars and brilliant political strategists opposite, led of course by the ultimate political strategist, Dr John `Fightback' Hewson. We in our party look at where that kind of framework in terms of party deliberations has led the coalition—10 years now in opposition, so it is a brilliant structure! I concede, and I have always conceded that—
—That's something to boast about!

—That is right, something to really boast about. If the rank and file of the Liberal and National parties ever want to get out of opposition, I would not think they would want to see this situation perpetuated for very much longer.

PARA.TAB: This issue is a matter of active debate. As Senator Tambling knows full well, I have been involved in that debate for the entire time that I have been a politician, which has been something like 16 years. Yesterday I addressed the party's policy committee on this subject. There has been some news about that this morning. Clearly, one of the members of the policy committee decided that he would release it to the press. Senator Tambling knows that my public position on this issue could not be clearer.

In respect of Aboriginal opinion on mining generally, it is not often related to the actual commodity being mined; it is a question of mining itself. It would not matter whether the mine was producing iron ore, marshmallows or uranium. Aboriginal people are extremely concerned—and rightly so—about the potential impact that mining has.

I have said in this house on many occasions that there has been a significant shift of opinion in Aboriginal communities over the last decade in favour of mining in many places. Principally, the reason for that is that Aboriginal people are in a position of being able to negotiate in real terms, courtesy of having a Labor government in Canberra. That situation would never have been achieved otherwise. Aboriginal people have seen the benefits that can be brought from mining, whether it is uranium or anything else. This government will continue to encourage those projects where local Aboriginal people in the area support them.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. The minister failed to address the first part of my question, that being: what discussions has he had with miners, Aboriginal leaders and interested parties since assuming this portfolio? I also ask: what commitments and expectations has he given to those people that there will be a change in the three-mine uranium policy?

—I did answer that part of the question. I repeat: I have been having that dialogue nonstop now for 16 years. As I told the ABARE conference in my opening address, there have been times in my parliamentary career where I felt that I have in fact dealt with nothing else but resource access, traditional rights and the rights of indigenous people.

—My question, which is directed to the Minister for Science and Small Business, concerns the quality of press reporting of scientific research in Australia. Is the minister aware of recent media reports of the alleged discovery and excavation of Noah's Ark by Mr John Gray. Is there any scientific basis to these claims? Are the reports indicative of the standard of scientific reporting in Australia?

—In mid-January—during the holiday season, which is often referred to as the silly season in the coverage of stories by the press—a particularly absurd story appeared in my own paper in South Australia, the Adelaide Advertiser. I understand it also appeared in the Courier-Mail. It was a major feature piece written about the discovery of Noah's Ark in Turkey.

PARA.TAB: This story was written as though it were fact. The journalist made no effort to check the science of the story or the background of the people who provided the material. In fact, what was particularly astonishing was that the Courier-Mail actually wrote an editorial in favour of the discovery of Noah's Ark as scientific fact.

I must say that I feel sorry for the people of Queensland that the Courier-Mail could write that sort of editorial without checking with reputable scientists in Australia or elsewhere. The story in both papers quoted a Mr Jonathan Gray, who seemed to indicate in the body of the story that he regarded himself as some sort of latter day Indiana Jones, discovering these sorts of historical cases.

It struck me as being a bit of a worry if the media is going to report these matters as fact without checking. I believe it is misleading to the people of Australia and also denigrates the standing of real science in Australia. I pay tribute to people such as Professor Plimer, the Professor of Earth Sciences at Melbourne University, who has conducted a campaign to point out the absurdity of these claims that Mr Gray and others have made—that they have discovered not only Noah's Ark but also, apparently, Christ's crucifixion site, a pyramid building machine, Sodom and Gomorrah, the real Mt Sinai, and so on. All of these claims are made without any scientific authentication. Professor Plimer and others have consistently exposed these people as scientific charlatans.

I place on record my support for the work of Professor Plimer and others in pointing out that these people are scientific charlatans who are trying to promote their religious beliefs as science. Unfortunately, newspapers in Australia like the Courier-Mail and the Advertiser which run the stories as scientific facts do no credit to science in Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —They're holding the presses for this!

—I must say that it is interesting that honourable senators opposite are willing to support people such as Mr Gray. I ask them to support the work of Professor Plimer and others who go around exposing the fact that this is not science. I am placing on record as science minister that there is no basis or foundation for these claims.
—Mr President, I ask that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper.

—I have an answer to a question asked yesterday by Senator Tierney on the issue of a grant to the Eastern Suburbs Cricket Club in Maitland, New South Wales, through the community cultural, recreation and sporting facilities program in 1992-93. Since 1988-89, when I, as the then Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories, introduced direct funding by this government of community level sport and recreational facilities, over $60 million has been provided for such developments.

PARA.TAB: In 1992-93 my colleague the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories, Ros Kelly, offered a grant of $49,000 to the Eastern Suburbs Cricket Club in Maitland for the construction of enclosed turf and practice wickets at Metford oval, Schanck Drive, Metford. The successful application was the first lodged by the club for Commonwealth assistance. It was submitted by the closing date of applications of 3 September 1992. According to departmental files, the club has never applied for funding in any previous round of grants.

The grant was one of 188 offered to organisations in New South Wales, the total value of which was over $7 million. Departmental files show that, as a result of discussions between the club and the Maitland City Council, the club has sought and received permission to change the location of the project to Melbourne Street, East Maitland.

It is my understanding that the change of venue was sought because the Metford site, although partially developed as a recreation area, is now being used by Landcom as a building dump site. Landcom had given an undertaking to the Maitland City Council in 1988 that it would develop this site as a sporting oval. As I said, this had not happened, so the council and the club decided to seek a change of venue for these much needed facilities. Maitland City Council identified Melbourne Street as the site for a new sporting complex and, together with the cricket club, agreed to develop the cricket facilities there rather than at Metford for the reason I have just stated.

Part of the new location is an old gasworks site. The New South Wales Environment Protection Authority has indicated that possible contamination may also exist at that site. The Maitland City Council currently has a proposal with the EPA—awaiting approval—for testing on the site. Subject to this approval, the council has a development application pending. So Senator Tierney was wrong about the council, as usual.

Mrs Kelly has indicated to me that, should any difficulties be encountered with the proposed site, she is willing to consider an alternative site. The minister's main concern is that the residents of the region have access to the proposed facilities. Similarly, officers of the Maitland City Council have shown a strong commitment to the project, indicating that, in the event of insurmountable problems being detected on the current site, an alternative location will be found by the council. There is no question of the grant being lost to the people of the Maitland area.

As for Senator Tierney's accusation of political bias in the awarding of this grant, this is pure fantasy on his part. Mr Peter Blackmore, the Liberal member for the state seat of Maitland, debunked this myth after the issue was first raised by Mr Ronaldson in the House of Representatives. In an interview with the Newcastle Herald on 27 November 1993, Mr Blackmore said that he did not think that Mr Tony Keating—who was, in fact, his ALP opponent—`had done anything wrong'. The area represented by the East Maitland Cricket Club is one of relatively high growth and with a lack of adequate sporting facilities and obviously one deserving of this grant. As I said yesterday, Senator Tierney should stop picking on the people of Maitland.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ferguson Sen A.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Senator Collins) to a question without notice asked by Senator Ferguson this day, relating to taxation of primary industries.

SPEECH.PARA: Earlier this week when I read what Senator Collins was reported to have said at the ABARE conference I took some heart from the fact that I had read that Senator Collins had indicated that there was a need for taxation reform to assist exporters, and I think particularly of those exporters who are involved in primary production. One of the main elements of the coalition's policy prior to the last election was to ensure that people involved in exporting, particularly those in the primary production area, would have some relief from the current high taxation, particularly indirect taxation, that is levied by this government.

PARA.TAB: I was disturbed to hear Senator Collins say in his answer that taxation policy is a matter for the Treasurer and not for the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy. I would say that that is not a particularly encouraging start for our primary industries minister if this means that he will not be examining the effect of taxation on our export industries, particularly primary producing industries which would be a lot more competitive on the world stage if it were not for the high indirect taxation that they are currently forced to pay. He said later on that it was a nonsense to suggest that increases in fuel excise were targeted at rural Australians; that they applied to the whole of Australia. They might apply to the whole of Australia but it is an undeniable fact that people in rural Australia and those involved in rural industries spend a far greater proportion of their time driving—and included in this is the cost of transport—than their city counterparts because they have to cover such long distances. Therefore they are disproportionately affected by hidden indirect taxes such as fuel excise.

Senator Collins tried to avoid the question by talking about a consumption tax. He said that the Nationals should hang their heads in shame. None of us on the coalition side are hanging our heads in shame because we are sticking up for our rural constituents, who really have had a gutful of indirect taxes like sales tax and fuel excise. It is a pity that the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy will not take this into account when formulating what needs to be done. I asked the minister whether he was saying that there was not a need for any taxation reform to help Australian exporters and he replied that taxation policy is as legitimate an area to consider as any other government policy in respect of its effect on rural Australia. Really, if the minister tackles nothing else while he is primary industries minister, he will serve rural Australia well if he tackles the issue of taxation, and particularly indirect taxation, on our primary producers.

I was somewhat disturbed to hear the minister later talk about a revision of the number of bodies involved in the primary industry department. A lot of the people affected by this indirect taxation are also affected by other things over which they have no control, such as the mouse plague that was mentioned by my colleague Senator Chapman. One of the recommendations brought forward was the establishment of a mouse commission similar to the locust commission. I sincerely hope, when the minister is looking at reducing the number of bodies, that the locust commission is not on his list.

Because of the effectiveness of the locust commission, it was decided after a lot of consideration that something similar should be done to try to avoid mouse plagues that we have experienced in the past. I notice that a lot of those opposite thought it was very humorous when my colleague Senator Chapman asked a question about the mouse plague, but there is nothing funny about living through one. Having lived through a plague in the middle and at the end of last year, I can say that it is one of the most terrible things anyone in rural Australia or elsewhere could live though. It is not a laughing matter.

I can assure the minister that people living in areas affected by mice plagues would not be heartened by his answer to Senator Chapman's requests. The things that afflict rural communities in varying degrees over a period of time have serious effects, as they did in South Australia and other parts of Australia last year.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to respond briefly to the concerns that have just been raised. The question of taxation is a vitally important issue not only to primary industry or rural Australia but to every Australian. It is essential that people in public life constantly look for ways in which taxation measures can assist industry. I simply reiterate that at the end of the day the person who is responsible for determining government policy on taxation is the Treasurer, and correctly so. I reiterate—because I hope that the lesson has been learned by those opposite—that the worst forms of taxation for people in the bush are point of sale taxes. We have had some experience of that. For years in the Northern Territory we have paid sales tax on the freight component of goods. One does not have to be a Rhodes scholar or have an economics degree to work out that if one imposes a point of sale tax on a certain commodity, the further away from the point of supply people get, and the higher the price of the goods when they are purchased in a normal retail fashion, the more disproportionately higher is the level of taxation. I have been living with that situation now for nearly 30 years; it is one that I am very familiar with. I condemned the National Party vociferously at the time—the record shows it, so I am not being wise after the event—for the mouse-like support that it gave to that outrageous proposal to impose a consumption tax on rural Australia—
—What about option C?

—Senator, have a look at the Senate Hansard. I opposed option C. I am glad to receive that interjection because I said publicly—I will dig it out for Senator Campbell if he is interested—that I vociferously opposed a point of sale tax `even when it was proposed by people in my own party'. I declare my personal regional bias in that regard. I do not flinch from that.
—Did you oppose the fuel tax?

—An interjection coming from somebody who grossly misrepresented the impact of consumption tax in northern Australia is a bit cute. Someone who told people that their white goods would end up being cheaper under a consumption tax when they were going to be more expensive should not open his mouth in this debate at all.

PARA.TAB: The mouse plague is a serious issue. I do not think rural Australia will be anything than encouraged by what I said at question time today. The difficulty is this—and I am sure that both Senator Chapman and Senator Ferguson are very well aware of this: the last mouse plagues in both South Australia and Victoria were actually forecast by the CSIRO but the extent of the plagues was much more serious than anticipated.

TALK.START.PARA: —What did you do in the CSIRO?

—In terms of the idiot interjections in this debate by Senator Ian Macdonald and his derisory comments about the three years that I spent working for the CSIRO division of wildlife research, as it happens, one of the CSIRO's mouse experts—
—Were you the mouse expert?

—Why does Senator Macdonald not shut up just for five minutes. When I worked for the CSIRO at its research laboratories in Darwin, I had the privilege of working with a person who became an expert in that area. This person, who is very familiar with the forecasting methods, told me that the big difficulty of forecasting plagues is what to tell the farmers to do about them when they arrive. He told me that the old traditional methods of dealing with mice plagues—physically ripping up the surface where the burrows exist—did not appear to be very effective; that the data on strychnine was not very persuasive at all in indicating whether at the end of the day it actually affected the plague or whether the plague simply died out through natural causes; and that one of the problems with anti-coagulants was their cost. (Time expired)

—I was fascinated to hear what Senator Collins did at the CSIRO. If it was anything like the rest of his history, it would have been a complete and abject failure. He was a failure as a Leader of the Opposition in the Northern Territory—
—A failed law student.

—He is a failed law student. He failed at waterfront reform. He was an abject failure at transport and communications and pay TV. Now he has shown today that he will be an abject failure as Minister for Primary Industries and Energy. On the resources side, he tells us that, as the minister, he is opposed to the three-mine uranium policy. When asked what he is going to do about it, he says he has to go and ask the faceless men in the Labor Party, and he is the minister.
—And he's a wimp—he's walked out of the chamber.

—He is a wimp, and he has walked out of the chamber. I was going to ask Senator Collins, if he had the intestinal fortitude to hang around and hear these things, just how he thinks the fuel tax impacts upon people in his constituency in the Northern Territory and in every other part of rural Australia.

PARA.TAB: Senator Collins does not seem to understand that if one lives in Katherine, Kununurra or Hughenden and wants to see a specialist, one does not just get in the car and drive a couple of blocks, as in Darwin, Brisbane, Sydney or Melbourne; one has to drive 500, 600, 700 and 800 kilometres. The effect is that every litre of fuel used generates a tax to the general revenue in the order of 25c a litre. That tax does not go to roads; it is not going to what one uses. That tax goes to the general revenue.

The people of Katherine, the people of Broome and the people of Hughenden pay their income tax, the same as every other Australian. They put their money in to pay for the services that we all have to pay for. But those people in remote areas have to pay more to the general coffers simply because they happen to be disadvantaged enough to live in the country.

At the last election the coalition recognised that. We proposed to completely abolish fuel tax—a saving of 33c a litre on what one pays now for fuel. Not only did the Labor Party reject our proposal to abolish the fuel tax, but also, subsequent to the election, it has increased it again. This simply means that people in the country have to pay more in general tax for the privilege of living in country areas. The fuel tax is the worst possible thing that could happen to primary producers and those living in remote and regional Australia.

If Senator Collins wants to in any way try to redeem himself and stop that run of failures he has had throughout his life, then he could do something about that fuel tax for country people and primary producers. If he could get rid of that fuel tax, as we proposed at the last election, he would go down in history as someone who has genuinely done something for rural and regional Australia. But I fear that Senator Collins will wimp that challenge and will not be interested in it or the people who have to live in rural and remote Australia. He will, as I have already predicted, become—and be—an abject failure in his handling of this portfolio, as he has been in every other portfolio.

TALK.START.PARA: —To the extent that this debate has drifted into Senator Collins's answer to my question on mice, I simply reinforce the need for the institution of a national mouse plague commission. The minister in his answer to me said that if he thought such a body would lead to the death of just one mouse, then he would be in favour of its establishment. Let me assure him that it will. It is not just another body to be established along with the myriad of bodies which he referred to as being part of his department, and the existence of which he wants to review; it will have a very positive role in the future in dealing with the problem of mice in rural areas.

PARA.TAB: There are two main areas of concern with mice plagues. The minister alluded to these in his response to Senator Ferguson. The first is the capacity to predict the likelihood of a plague. The second is the need for an effective rodenticide to be developed.

With regard to the first matter, the capacity to predict the likelihood of a plague, there is a much greater need for national coordination of the monitoring of the build-up of mouse numbers. This is done in isolated areas and in an isolated way at the moment. It is not done on a national basis or with adequate national coordination.

The experts to whom Senator Collins referred, both in his answer and his further response in this debate, are clearly of the opinion—and this is evident if we consult the report of the national rodent workshop that was sponsored by the Grains Research and Development Corporation—that an effective monitoring program will make it possible to develop a highly sophisticated predictive capacity which will allow us to predict when a mouse plague is imminent. Early preventative action can then be taken to prevent the numbers of mice increasing to plague proportions.

That is one very strong argument for the establishment of a national mouse plague commission. The second is the need for better coordination of research into effective preventative methods, particularly the development of an effective rodenticide.

The minister referred to the use of strychnine as a rodenticide. He questioned its effectiveness. It is certainly the only effective counter measure against mice that is available and proves effective, but it is obviously not an ideal counter measure. Indeed, it is passing strange that after more than a century of mouse plagues in this country, with all the scientific advances that we have had here and internationally over that period, we are still relying on a rodenticide, in the form of strychnine, that is more than a century old. With all the developments in science and technology we have not developed a more effective poison or alternative method of killing these rodents.

Research is being conducted in various quarters but there is a need for that research to be coordinated and focused so that an effective rodenticide that can be brought into use in the very near future is developed. There is an important role for the commission in that regard.

The matter certainly needs to be effectively managed. As Senator Macdonald mentioned a few moments ago, considering the history of this minister one doubts whether he has the capacity to manage anything within his department effectively. This commission, if structured and managed properly, need not be the traditional, ineffective bloated bureaucracy. It can operate on a very lean and mean basis and bring in the expertise needed from time to time. My proposal is that the actual monitoring process be undertaken by farmers themselves because they are the best people equipped to monitor the development of mouse plagues—the growth in mouse numbers—and to report back on the development of that situation so that effective preventative action can be taken.

There is an urgent need for this commission to be established because mouse numbers are again building up in Victoria and South Australia. The potential for a plague exists and we need an effective coordinating body to be put in place to take over the monitoring role and the development of effective counter measures urgently so that another plague does not develop, which would be to the detriment of not only rural producers but all Australians who benefit from what is produced by our rural producers. The mouse plague cost in the order of $175 million last year. We do not want that to occur again to the detriment of rural producers.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tierney Sen J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the further answer given by the Minister for Health (Senator Richardson) this day, to a question without notice asked by Senator Tierney on 2 February 1993, relating to the allocation of sports funding.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Richardson yesterday came up with an almost laughable answer to the questions raised by me about the sports rorts in Maitland. He got his facts totally wrong, and said that I should be happy with the facility being developed in the city. He was missing the entire point, of course, which was that East Maitland was about to lose the grant totally.

PARA.TAB: Obviously Senator Richardson's department or Mrs Kelly's department pointed that out to him and he had another try today. I am amazed at the answer provided by him today. I wonder where he has got his information from, because there were supposed to be no records of these grants. Yet he spelled out chapter and verse the history of this particular grant. He spelled out what happened when the club moved from one field to the other, and he had dates and all sorts of things for this application.

It must have been the enormous brain power of the minister that provided him with this information. She claims that she can keep 2,800 different applications in her mind—all the particular cases, including all the circumstances and the histories. She did not need any paper work. Yet today all this information was displayed. One wonders where it came from.

One wonders also about why Senator Richardson, a former minister for the environment, played down the real problem with the site that has been chosen for this sports facility. The real problem is that it is being developed on a former gasworks site. Senator Richardson told us that there might be a few environmental problems with this site. There is so much concern about the East Maitland cricket club site that a fence has been built around it to keep people out.
