He tried to give the impression that East Maitland was still going to receive the grant, but it is very obvious that time will run out because of all these difficulties and East Maitland will lose this facility.

One could ask why the grant was given in the first place. East Maitland was totally unprepared for the grant. It did not have a DA or a BA and there were environmental concerns, yet the money was rushed to it. Why? One would think that one of the major players in the East Maitland cricket club, Tony Keating, the chief staffer of Mr Horne, the local member, and a candidate for the state seat of Maitland, obviously had something to do with this group getting the money in an inappropriate way. There is a real question to be answered.

It is a perfect case study of allocating money to sports facilities not so much with the community benefit in mind but with political benefit in mind. This occurred in all the marginal seats on the north coast of New South Wales. While the three poorest seats of Richmond, Page and Cowper in the far north did receive grants, the marginal seats received twice as much as the safe National Party seat. It was obviously a rort. It is something that the minister has to answer. Today Senator Richardson gave yet another inappropriate answer. We will see whether he can do a little better on Monday.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crane Sen W.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Senator Collins) to a question without notice asked by Senator Crane this day, relating to the rural adjustment scheme.

SPEECH.PARA: There are a number of issues that I would like to raise with regard to the question I put today. The question was in three parts: first, what value of the Australian dollar against the US dollar was used by ABARE to arrive at commodity prices, particularly for agricultural export markets; second, what steps will be taken to address the inadequacies as identified by Dr Fisher, the executive director of ABARE, with regard to the rural adjustment scheme; and, third, has ABARE shifted emphasis with the rural adjustment scheme away from debt reconstruction towards phasing farmers out of the industry?

PARA.TAB: The last part of my question—in some respects, the most important part—was totally ignored by the minister. An adjustment process has occurred in agriculture over the last 20 years, with increased pressure over the last few years—particularly since the engineered recession of the Prime Minister, Mr Keating, while he was Treasurer. I find it alarming and disappointing that we are now seeing that emphasis coming through. It is highlighted by what Dr Fisher had to say to the ABARE conference. Dr Fisher said that the magnitude of the required adjustment was beyond the scope of the federal government's existing rural adjustment scheme, reflecting a view held by ABARE that the scheme's emphasis should move from keeping farmers on the land to providing more aid for them to leave.

The point I want to make about this change of emphasis is that we will again see farmers, through no fault of their own, on the merry-go-round of falling into hard times and getting into difficult financial circumstances. Through a build-up process, one property debt will be transferred to another. We only have to wait another four or five years and the cycle will repeat itself. We have seen that happen regularly, particularly since the late 1960s and early 1970s. That is a matter of history.

In my view, the rural adjustment scheme has failed to address the pressures on agriculture that exist at the present time. Those pressures result from the high costs being faced by the industry. That was highlighted today by Senator Ferguson's question on the matter. The minister has failed to address that issue. He talked about the amount of money that the federal government has put into the rural adjustment scheme since it has been in power. I do not deny that, but it has been misplaced and misdirected money. It was only needed because of the failed economic policy of those who sit on the other side of this chamber and on the government benches in the House of Representatives. It would not have been needed if we had had proper policy and if the government had addressed some of the structural problems we have in this country, including taxation, transport and the work practices in place on our wharves and in other areas. That is where the real adjustment has to be made. Those are the areas that need to be addressed.

I want to raise another point in terms of these figures. The minister was quite wrong when he said that there was an improved outlook for agricultural products. It is borne out by the figures. We do not have to look very far. We just have to look at the wool industry, for example. Its forecast for 1993-94 was 475c. The figure for 1992-93 was 488c. If that figure is not going down, I do not know what is going down. It is said that wool looks sweeter than sugar, and wool is falling. One can only assume from that that sugar will be worse. As we work through the figures, we find that is a consistent approach. That is done—might I add, because the minister did not know the answer to this question—at an averaging of the dollar of 67c. The dollar has been sitting at 70c or a little higher for some time. I know that is a fluctuating thing. The problems were borne out by the announcement yesterday of a blow-out in our current account to $1.7 billion. One acknowledges that that is a one month figure, but it is a symptom of the lack of policy direction of this government. The government addresses one thing and it blows out somewhere else because the government's focus is so narrow.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Australian Centre for International Agricultural Research

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALKER.NAME: Senator ROBERT RAY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Defence)

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to make a statement on behalf of the Minister for Development Cooperation and Pacific Island Affairs (Mr Bilney) relating to the annual report of the Australian Centre for International Agricultural Research and to incorporate the statement in Hansard.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.
The statement read as follows—

SPEECH.PARA: MINISTERIAL STATEMENT TO PARLIAMENT
TABLING OF THE ANNUAL REPORT OF THE AUSTRALIAN CENTRE FOR INTERNATIONAL AGRICULTURAL RESEARCH
3 FEBRUARY 1994, PARLIAMENT HOUSE, CANBERRA
Introduction

The Australian Centre for International Agricultural Research (ACIAR) is one of the Australian aid program's "quiet achievers". The Centre commissions and promotes research aimed at improving sustainable agricultural production in developing countries—principally in the Asia-Pacific region. By doing so it contributes to their well being—particularly benefiting rural areas where most people in developing countries live. By increasing general economic growth amongst many of our neighbours, the Centre's research in turn assists Australia's economic growth and its security.

ACIAR was set up as a statutory authority in 1982. Its mandate was broadened in 1992, following a highly favourable review of its operations by the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade. Some of the many complimentary remarks made about the Centre following the tabling of the report included that of Committee Chairman Senator Chris Schacht, who said, `In my view ACIAR is one of those good news stories that does not get the coverage in the Australian media that organisations like it should get'. Australia's Foreign Minister, Senator Gareth Evans, described it as a `lean, professional organisation with an excellent approach to its task'.
ACIAR's new mandate is to:
commission research into improving agricultural production in developing countries
fund some project-related training (both informal and postgraduate)
commission some development of results from its research programs
administer the Australian Government's funding contribution to the International Agricultural Research Centres.

Promoting bilateral research collaboration between Australia and developing countries remains ACIAR's primary aim. It mobilises Australian agricultural research expertise to help developing countries help themselves. It achieves this by commissioning research groups in Australian universities, the CSIRO and the state agriculture departments to carry out joint research projects in partnership with their counterparts in developing countries. The commissioned research focuses on high-priority problems in developing countries in fields in which Australia has particular scientific and technical competence—and there are many. Research takes place both in Australia and in the partner countries, and it is a feature of ACIAR projects that they are specifically chosen to maximise the benefits to both our developing-country partners and Australia.

It is sometimes argued that international agricultural assistance simply helps our competitors and reduces markets for Australian agricultural products. In reality the reverse is true. By increasing incomes, it enables people to purchase more, and experience demonstrates that one of the first things they buy more of is food. In Indonesia, for example, as agricultural production increased during the 1980s Australian wheat exports to Indonesia increased by over 200,000 tonnes.

ACIAR research helps Australian farmers directly as well as indirectly. It is conservatively estimated, for example, that the international agricultural research to which Australia contributes through ACIAR has increased the earnings of Australian farmers by more than $2 billion over the last two decades, principally through the use of high yielding varieties of wheat.

Australia is rare among aid donor countries in that it shares with most developing countries a similar location in tropical, subtropical or `mediterranean' latitudes. As a result, Australia's agricultural scientists find themselves working within an extensive and very successful network of agricultural research establishments, dealing more often than not with agricultural problems similar to those of much of the developing world. It is ACIAR's contribution to have given Australia a more effective focus for its research collaboration with developing countries.
Research
During 11 years of operations ACIAR has commissioned around 240 projects, usually over 3-year periods, 170 of which have been completed.

It has tackled the critical problem of agricultural land degradation and the associated spoilage of natural resources. The Rio Earth Summit's Agenda 21 calls for action to safeguard agricultural production by protecting natural resources and minimising environmental pollution. ACIAR has responded in a number of ways, including mounting a coordinated effort to alleviate the physical problems arising from poor farming practices on hilly lands in the Southeast Asian region. The research complements studies to determine how best to introduce suitable technologies to smallholder farmers with little understanding of the need for change.

It has discovered new varieties of Australian trees and shrubs that will help meet the fuel wood, agroforestry and industrial needs of developing countries. Seven years' research to find better adapted trees for China has led to the planting of 17 000 hectares of high-performing acacia and eucalypt species and the provision for further plantings of acacias in China's 5-year plan. In Indonesia propagation techniques for acacias are now being applied to large-scale forestry. In addition, Pakistan, Thailand and Australia, together with many other countries with salt-affected agricultural lands, stand to benefit from the identification of salt-tolerant trees and shrubs that can restore some productivity to otherwise useless land.

It has developed environmentally safe, appropriate technologies that have improved the health and productivity of animals owned by smallholder farming communities. In India, farmers have had milk production increases of over 10 per cent in dairy cattle and buffalo, as a result of the combined effect on their nutrition of giving them nutrient blocks with medication added to control internal parasites. In the Pacific Islands scientists have found that goats need almost no medication for internal parasites if they are moved through a rotational grazing system that prevents infection from pastures.

Many of the traditional crops of Southeast Asia, Africa and the Pacific, such as coconut, banana, sweet potato and cassava, suffer from viral, bacterial and fungal diseases. ACIAR research has developed more productive, disease-free lines of some of these crops. For example, banana varieties with resistance to black sigatoka disease have been identified. This disease is a potential scourge of banana crops world-wide, including Australia, and was recently isolated and contained in north Queensland as a direct result of this project. The possession of resistant varieties is a good insurance policy to protect our multi-million dollar banana industry.

Biological control and integrated pest management have been encouraged and progressed through ACIAR's crop protection program. Last year two ACIAR publications on biological control containing some outstanding examples of successful programs to control pests and weeds in Asia, Africa and the Pacific Islands. In addition, researchers have compiled a large body of data on fruit flies in Malaysia, Thailand and four Pacific countries that will lead to better control of fruit flies and improved quarantine protection. Associated with this is the development of bait spraying for preharvest control of fruit flies in orchards and field crops. When cover sprays are used for control they often kill pollinating bees and other beneficial insects, but bait spraying uses a tiny quantity of insecticide mixed with a substance such as hydrolysed yeast that attracts only fruit flies. The method is not only safer but cheaper in materials and labour. The investment of $800,000 in this project is projected to yield an overall benefit to Australia of $176 million through local application—a staggering 220:1 return.

ACIAR has become a major player in the arena of safe postharvest handling, processing, storage, transport and marketing of both durable and perishable foods in the humid tropics. Much of the increase in food production in Asia over recent decades can be attributed to early maturing varieties which enable two crops per year to be harvested instead of one. This has presented producers with the challenge of storing grains during the wet season with high humidity and heightened pest activity. The Postharvest Program works closely with national, regional and international agencies concerned with food handling. Smaller-scale operators and farmer cooperatives are specifically targeted in the program's current work on outdoor storage and grain drying, with high potential to deliver the benefits of new technology to the poorer sector.

Concern world-wide about dwindling fisheries resources is mirrored in the ACIAR Fisheries program. Ongoing studies in countries of the Indo-Pacific have given a clearer understanding of the effects of commercial baitfishing on traditional fishing grounds and provided a better basis for effective co-management arrangements between traditional owners and industry. A current study of the seasonal abundance and distribution of billfish, such as marlin and sailfish, will assist Pacific countries to preserve the habitats and regulate the catch of these fish, which are of particular interest to game fishermen.

In association with its applied research, ACIAR funds economic studies to ensure that new technologies are implemented and that national agricultural policies are appropriate for the promotion of economic development. One research project devised a computer model of the Philippines economy that focuses on interactions between the agricultural sector and the rest of the economy. Application of the model revealed that one third of economic growth in the Philippines over recent decades resulted from technological advances in agriculture, and that the economic gains primarily benefited lower-income groups. This study is the most comprehensive of its kind to date, and is likely to have international influence in promoting agricultural research as a means of achieving both economic growth and poverty alleviation.
Training

Part of ACIAR's mission is to enhance the research capacity of institutions in developing countries. This is achieved by visits from Australian scientists who spend time with their colleagues in their home-country institutions, by the conduct of project-related training courses both overseas and in Australia, and by the awarding of ACIAR Fellowships for project-related postgraduate training in Australia. The effects of these activities are becoming evident as ACIAR's programs mature and diversify in its 25 or so partner countries. There is a true sense of international partnership, and evidence of the increasing confidence of partner country scientists is reflected in the increasing number of authors from Southeast Asia in the published scientific literature. Furthermore, countries that once looked to Australia for expertise are now sources of information to assist their neighbours. For instance a recent forestry research initiative in Laos went ahead because the Thai partners bridged the cultural and language gap and conducted training in Thailand.

ACIAR, with funding assistance from the Crawford Fund for International Agricultural Research, has staged a number of master classes associated with specific projects to give advanced training to developing-country scientists. One on molecular genetics held at Monash University involved 14 senior researchers from seven countries; another on plant virology held in Thailand attracted 20 scientists from nine countries. Response from the participants has been overwhelmingly enthusiastic.
International standing

In February 1992 ACIAR took over responsibility for administering Australia's contribution to the International Agricultural Research Centres, previously undertaken by AIDAB. ACIAR has reinstated the Special Purpose Grants program which is designed to aid research collaboration of the international centres with Australian and developing-country institutions. ACIAR's familiarity with the operations of the international centres make it well placed to administer Australia's commitment to them, both in terms of development assistance and enlightened self interest.

ACIAR is now held in high regard internationally and frequently cited as an model of excellence for others to follow in institutional planning. Recently the Centre acted as implementing agency for the establishment of the new Centre for International Forestry Research, which is now up and running in Bogor, Indonesia. ACIAR research coordinators regularly undertake short-term advisory consultancies for other international bodies such as FAO and the World Bank.

In tabling the 1992-93 Annual Report of the Centre, I hope I have demonstrated to honourable members that ACIAR continues to be a "quiet achiever" among Australia's successful international initiatives. Like AIDAB, the other aid agency within the Development Cooperation portfolio, it is staffed by dedicated men and women who have a commitment to excellence which ought to be a matter of pride to all Australians, as it is to me.

I conclude with an observation from one of the Centre's overseas partners, the Agricultural University of Malaysia. When ACIAR was reviewed in 1991 Professor Syed, a Deputy Vice Chancellor of that university, made a submission to the review committee. He praised ACIAR for helping to advance agriculture in the tropical and developing nations, and pointed to manifold benefits arising from joint research. But while Malaysia appreciated the solutions arising from the research, Professor Syed said that the enhancement of expertise amongst project scientists was of equal significance. He believed involvement in ACIAR projects was one of the few means by which local scientists could gain access to foreign expertise and participate in technology transfer.
This is, in the end, what ACIAR exists for—to help other countries help themselves. I believe that it does so out of all proportion to its cost. I commend the Report to the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —I table the speech and the annual report of the Australian Centre for International Agricultural Research for 1992-93. I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the documents.
Debate (on motion by Senator McGauran) adjourned.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Commonwealth Superannuation Board of Trustees No. 1

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the document.

SPEECH.PARA: The report is in respect of the year 1992-93. I remind the Senate that this year was the first full year in which the PPS fund was managed separately from the original fund. The investments have grown quite remarkably—from $926 million to $1,291 million, a 36 per cent increase. Interestingly enough, the best performing sectors were those of overseas shares and overseas fixed interest. The fund performance—9.25 per cent after tax and fees—exceeded that of the target portfolio. All of this is refreshing news.

PARA.TAB: The fund is of significant size. It has 98,710 members, an increase of 9.4 per cent over that of the previous year. My colleague Senator Newman will be interested to hear that women comprise 56 per cent of its membership, so they are significant members. This raises the question about the need for women who have significant part-time employment to be able to top up contributions. For example, under a lot of the arrangements it is difficult for them to get, say, 40 years continuous services, which is a bit of a yardstick for determining what will be a satisfactory level of retirement income.

When we consider that 16 per cent of members contribute below five per cent of salary, it means then that 74.9 per cent of members pay five per cent of their salaries into the fund. The new arrangements through additional death and invalidity policy with National Mutual came into effect on 1 July 1993. As of June 1993, only 194 members were paying premiums for additional cover on death and disability.

I wish to use this opportunity to raise an issue of some concern—the tax on superannuation of medically retired public servants. The tax treatment of lump sum superannuation payments was raised in the press as a matter of some concern. The problem arose from a clash between the New South Wales legislation on how the scheme was to be administered and the Commonwealth legislation on how benefits would be controlled. Specifically, the problem relates to how invalidity benefits are measured.

I might remind the Senate that invalid benefits are taxed at a more generous rate than other retirement benefits. In order to receive the more generous tax rate certain criteria must be met. The state scheme seems to provide for a benefit that unfortunately at the time did not meet those criteria. I have been advised that an interim solution has been found by way of using the Insurance and Superannuation Commissioner's discretionary powers to have the benefit treated as though it were an invalid pension even though it does not meet the Commonwealth criteria.

I am not aware of any long-term solutions in terms of the new reasonable benefit rules to be administered by the tax office. I thought it significant enough to use this opportunity to raise this question of invalidity and to clarify the position in respect of a number of public servants who I know are aware of it. I am pleased that an interim arrangement has been established to overcome the problems they were faced with.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Australian Institute of Health and Welfare

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Patterson Sen K.C.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the document.

SPEECH.PARA: I rise to comment very briefly on this first report since the institute's role was expanded in May 1992 to include welfare. These documents will be produced biennially. This document is a consolidation of welfare related data that is collected both nationally and on a state-territory level. It concentrates on those welfare services to which the institute's legislation relates, namely, housing and community services, and in particular children's services, aged care and disability services. However, data from the wider welfare sector is also incorporated into the document.

PARA.TAB: As someone whose portfolio responsibilities relate directly and indirectly to the areas in this 400-odd page report, I wish to recommend the report to the Senate as an extremely useful resource document. In saying that, my reading of it has only been cursory since we received it only today, but I believe it should be commended as it provides an easily read summary of the histories of these welfare programs as well as very useful statistics relating to the demographics of the consumers of these programs and the services provided to them.

Because of my portfolio, I was interested to look at the aged care sector. I read about CAM and SAM funding. For those of my colleagues who think they are the names of two residents living in a nursing home, I advise that they are in fact two types of funding. The document is very factual; in fact a residents' rights agreement is talked about as well as the fact that the government brought in legislation relating to residents' rights in nursing homes.

The document does not discuss how many nursing homes or how many residents have actually signed residents' rights agreements so one will only get factual information about the policy and the implementation of that policy to a point, but there is no information on other points which ought to be addressed—though not necessarily in this sort of document. I would sound a note of caution in the sense that the document really provides factual information.

Other things need to be addressed apart from the factual information. Nursing homes and hostels should be asked about the details of the programs outlined in this document. One will then actually see a somewhat different story. That is my only note of caution. It gives good factual information, but should honourable senators really want to know what is actually going on they need to talk with service providers to find out how it is being implemented.

The factual information is important and, as I said, I think it will prove to be a useful resource for politicians, public servants, lobby groups, the welfare sector, community agencies, teachers and students. I congratulate the institute on having produced what appears to be a quality document that has obviously entailed the compilation, collation and consolidation of a vast array of statistical data and other information.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the document.

SPEECH.PARA: I note first of all that the document was signed by my distinguished cousin Professor Peter Baume on 1 November 1993; the financial accounts were signed on 26 November 1993; the Senate business sheet tells us that it was received by the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories (Mrs Kelly) on 16 December but for some curious reason it did not come to the Senate by the time it rose, 22 December. We eventually get this annual report in February. The amount of time taken is disappointing, but at least it gives me the opportunity to deal with it. I was not here when it was being dealt with as I was fortunate enough to be representing the Australian Parliament at the United Nations General Assembly in New York.

TALK.START.PARA: —And you did a very good job too.

—I thank the senator for that interjection. I think the Sports Drug Agency is a very worthwhile and well-run operation. But I am concerned about the fall off that the annual report reveals in the level of user-pay tests that has taken place. In 1991-92, for example, there were 817 user-pays tests; in 1992-93 there were 743. That is a fall of 74, almost 10 per cent. I do not know the reason for it. As my quick flip through the annual report does not indicate the reason to me, I may be doing an injustice.

PARA.TAB: As you would know, Mr Deputy President, the proposition that you and I have been putting in this place for many years has been that ASDA should seek to maximise the user-pay tests so that the burden does not fall entirely on the taxpayer.

SPEECH.PARA: It is disappointing to see this fall off, particularly as the five-year target for the user-pays drug testing service has been one of continual increase. In fact, by 1995-96 there is an expectation, or a hope, that there will be 1,300 user-pay tests at ASDA. That compared with, say, 2,500 government user-paid tests makes it a pretty healthy proportion. At the moment it involves an increase in the user-pay target of something like a quite substantial 50 per cent.

PARA.TAB: The key is that unless ASDA has users paying more for the services of ASDA, this requirement to test people for drugs will fall more and more heavily on all Australians rather than just sporting Australians. It seems an unfair burden. I might say that this general question of revenues does not look terribly good. We have seen a fall in operating revenues from independent sources compared with the total revenues, including governmental revenue, from 10 per cent in 1991-92 to about only 7.6 per cent in 1992-93. I notice the forecast for 1993-94 is back up to 10 per cent, and I hope that that percentage will increase.

It was also interesting to note—I am certain many people will be keen to see this—that the table on drug testing statistics shows which sports are in fact being heavily examined. I commend the rugby league, for example, for the fact that it is, on a paying basis, getting many drug tests done. I think this has been to the benefit of the Australian rugby league, as is clear from the fact that penalties have been imposed. I hope that this will discourage young Australians from being foolish enough to undertake excessive drug consumption.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the document.

SPEECH.PARA: I commend the Australian Sports Drug Agency for this document. It notes:

Sport is about participation, performance, competition and achievement. Above all, it is about building character and improving the health and well-being of the nation. Drugs to enhance physical performance undermine the essential values of all that sport is about. The Australian Sports Drug Agency is committed to reducing the harm associated with drug use in sport in order to enhance the well being of individuals and the value of sport to society.

I agree with that statement. That is why I was very disappointed to see an article in today's Australian in which Mr Neil King from Athletics Australia was very critical of the Australian Sports Drug Agency. The article quotes Mr King as saying that athletes who were caught using drugs would escape punishment on technicalities unless changes were made to the Australian Sports Drug Agency's practices and regulations.

PARA.TAB: Quite frankly, I hope Mr King has been misquoted. Having read that article, it appears to me that Mr King has some major misunderstandings about what sports drug testing is all about in terms of the people being tested. The requirement under the Privacy Act is that the first thing to be done if someone rejects a test is advise that person—I think that person has three weeks or so; I assume that is right because that is the situation if there is a positive test—of the consequences before anyone else is advised. That is only right and proper.

Athletics Australia is saying that its policy in the last few months has been that, if ASDA does not advise Athletics Australia immediately of a refusal to accept a drug test—in other words, does not give the benefit of the Privacy Act to athletes—Athletics Australia will not follow through with penalties against athletes. That is a disgrace, and I hope Mr King withdraws that comment. The point is that we are obliged, under the law, to give athletes that level of privacy. I think they have three weeks to respond before anyone else is told.

If Athletics Australia is serious, all it has to do is require its own athletes to sign a membership form which acknowledges that Athletics Australia has to be advised in the event of their having got a refusal or any communication from the Australian Sports Drug Agency. It is up to Athletics Australia to do that. But I am darned if this parliament, which passed this law, should be dictated to by Athletics Australia about how our drug policy should be implemented and what sorts of privacy standards should exist with athletes. I think Mr King should go away, scratch his head and decide the best way to fix this problem. For him to say that because the organisation has changed its policy and will not penalise athletes by banning them—by the way, they normally get rubbed out for four years for refusing to take a test—and that, therefore, it is the Sports Drug Agency's fault, is an absolute nonsense.

I acknowledge the fact that Athletics Australia has had some problems in its relationship with the Australian Sports Drug Agency, or it may be the other way round, but, on my understanding of these matters it has largely emerged from the fact that some senior officials in Athletics Australia—you, Mr Deputy President, would be aware of them—had in fact connived with some athletes to alter samples. I do not want to become involved in any kind of slanging match with people but this is a major issue. It is vital that Athletics Australia cooperate properly with the Australian Sports Drug Agency. It is simply wrong for Athletics Australia to say that ASDA had refused Athletics Australia's request to test specific athletes. I have checked that with ASDA. It is simply not true.

Athletics Australia has to get down to cooperating properly with what I believe is a well-run organisation—and I do not say that simply because my cousin is the chairman of it. This organisation has a good set of objectives and is playing a major role in clearing Australian sport of the horrific consequences of drugs. Athletes are dying as a result of drug taking. This kind of sniping in today's article in the Australian is not in the best interests of athletics and it is not in the best interests of the campaign against drug taking.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Department of the Arts and Administrative Services

DEBATE.SUB2.TITLE: Annual Report on the working of the Protection of Movable Cultural Heritage Act 1986

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the document.

SPEECH.PARA: The removal of cultural heritage is an important matter which received a fair amount of attention at the United Nations during my period there. Many countries are extremely concerned about the manner in which they are being stripped of their cultural heritage by illegal means. I am glad that we have this structure which is supposed to protect that heritage. Every now and again there are glitches. I think the Senate will remember the curious situation of the Titan, the former Sydney-based floating crane which was allowed to be exported. It expressed its displeasure at the fact by tipping up and sinking on the way to Taiwan or wherever it was going. I guess it won in the end.

PARA.TAB: This annual report was signed on 8 December 1993. It appears to have been shuffled around a fair bit. There is no doubt it could have been presented to the Senate before Christmas, but at least we have it now.
The only other thing I want to mention in passing is that over the 12 months of this report to June last year we seem to have lost a large number of motor vehicles.

TALK.START.PARA: —Because of leaded petrol being taxed.

—Because of leaded petrol getting a higher tax—I like that! They include: a 1909 Talbot; an incomplete and unrestored 1908 Talbot four cylinder motor vehicle; an incomplete and unrestored 1914 Hotchkiss four cylinder motor vehicle; a restored 1907 Russell motor vehicle; a 1910 Straker motor vehicle; a 1912 SCAT 15 horsepower motor vehicle; and a partially restored 1911 Rolls Royce tourer. They disappeared along with some aircraft: a World War II Japanese Nakajima K143 fighter aircraft; a pair of World War II Mustang aircraft wings; a dismantled Canberra bomber; and the remains of a World War 11 mark IV Mosquito aircraft. I do not know why these were given permission to be exported but, on the face of it, it seems to be disappointing that so much memorabilia of the war by way of these aircraft should have been leaving Australia.

PARA.TAB: Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Patterson Sen K.C.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the document.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Baume has just referred to a report dated last December. This report was dated 10 December 1993, and it is now being tabled in the chamber. Had it been tabled at the end of last year when it was ready, it may have been received by the same minister to whom it was addressed—Senator Bob McMullan, as the then Minister for the Arts and Administrative Services. Now that the report has been tabled in February, it is not the responsibility of the same minister.

PARA.TAB: I read this report with amusement. So much for the commitment of the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) to the priority of the arts—a priority which seems to have escaped his attention in the recent cabinet reshuffle. I thought that the ALP was keen to maintain the myth that it had this solid contact with the arts community. I suppose some of the arts community would be pretty furious that they have established this relationship with Senator McMullan and spent hours briefing and talking to him, only to find that suddenly, because he has done what may appear to some people to be a reasonable job—yet we have got some doubts about that—in the administrative services portfolio, he dumps the arts portfolio, and Mr Lee has been given the arts portfolio.

Notwithstanding that, I want to speak about the report. I also mention that Film Australia has made some quite significant changes over the past 12 months in terms of its staffing. It has acknowledged that that has not been easy and has actually impacted on some individuals who have served the organisation for some time. Obviously, it felt that was necessary because of the financial situation. The use of space was also rationalised within the Lindfield premises and it sought successfully to lease large portions of the excess. It should be commended on seeing that opportunity.

I was interested also as to the way in which it is marketing and distributing Australian films. By commenting on one film one may omit others and I do not wish to do that, but the report mentions Kangaroos: Faces in the Mob. On page 24 one can see the long list of awards that documentary has received already. If any of my colleagues in this chamber have not seen that film, I commend it to them. In order to market it, Film Australia has located this film in ABC shops, zoos, national parks, wildlife kiosks, Australiana shops, airport outlets, and a number of other areas. It is looking to try to sell it through Readers Digest, Avon, Amway, Doubleday Book Club, SBS catalogues, et cetera. It is using innovative and creative techniques to market this wonderful film—Kangaroos: Faces in the Mob.

In looking at this report, one's attention is drawn also to the fostering of trade relations with Asia which Film Australia is engaging in. This is demonstrated by, firstly, its partnership with a Japanese company, NHK Japan, on the children's project Escape from Jupiter; and, secondly, the marketing and distribution contract with a group in Japan for the television, video, merchandising and publishing rights to Johnson and Friends. These are two examples of a movement into the Asian market.

Another innovation which needs to be brought to the Senate's attention occurs on page 15 and relates to special projects. We see that Film Australia is involving itself in a relationship with the National Museum of Australia to look at ways in which innovative means can be used to transfer the experience of collections across time and space in order to enable access to films by people in remote areas. The aim is to create the opportunity for all Australians to participate in the nation's cultural heritage. One has only to look at the changes in technology that are about to occur to realise how organisations such as Film Australia need to be almost ahead of the game in order to benefit from those changes. It is heartening to see that it is projecting itself forward and looking towards changes in technology to facilitate the promotion of Australian films. I commend the report to the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support the commendation of this report and congratulate Film Australia on another year of success. I think that the policy on this side of the House some years ago that it should either be sold off or broken up was not an appropriate one at that stage. I would hope that the developments that are proceeding at Film Australia on a very commercially oriented and artistically alert level should proceed. Whether or not ultimately its nature and style should change is another matter. What Film Australia is doing, freed from the shackles of the Public Service which were in fact limiting its scope and capacity in the past, is outstanding.

PARA.TAB: Johnson and Friends, which Senator Patterson mentioned, is an outstanding commercial success and also an outstandingly successful show as far as children are concerned. My granddaughter regards it as her favourite program. I have had to buy various cassettes of it, which are available from ABC shops.

I have one slight problem with this report. It relates to a joint venture. Film Australia had a 40 per cent interest in the output of a joint venture with Soundfirm Pty Ltd. This joint venture ceased on 30 November 1992. On 1 December 1992 Film Australia entered into a licence agreement with Soundfirm for the operation of sound facilities for film and video production.

This has been one of the very successful elements of Film Australia. It has done the sound for many international films. It is a first-rate venture and something of which Australia should be proud. We have managed to earn a great deal of foreign exchange. I note that it did the sound for Black Robe out of those studios. I end by saying that although the company appears to have made a loss of $4 million in the latest year, this was almost entirely due to a revaluation of the property which has a specific purpose limit on it and it does not in fact reflect any bad management there. I commend the report and support Senator Patterson's motion that it be noted by the Senate. I do ask that Film Australia advises us further about the significance of the change in the nature of what was its joint venture with Soundfirm Pty Ltd.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Newman Sen J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before the luncheon adjournment I was speaking about the Sydney Rescue Work Society, which is a non-profit group providing care for 1,500 children a day in metropolitan Sydney. The children for whom they care come largely from the most disadvantaged groups in society. They have expressed serious concerns about the accreditation guidelines. I was referring to a statement put out by the society last Monday. I quote from it:

SPEECH.PARA: The Society is doing all it can to ensure affordable quality child care but is unable to reconcile this latest revelation—
that is the privacy one—

which, if found to be correct, demonstrates a lack of compassion for families in the International Year of the Family. The Society is most concerned because it has begun work to ensure that rapid implementation of accreditation. If our clients and families in general are going to be faced with cost increases which they can't afford, then nobody benefits.

I am informed that the society has now had to employ two part-time employees to start implementing the accreditation guidelines for the society. It has found that the government's handbook is very vague and difficult to use for implementing the accreditation process and it is still waiting for the work book to come from the authorities. In addition, the Sydney Rescue Work Society has today issued a media release which may do more to convince the Democrats and the Greens than did the material provided earlier by other people who had been looking at the cost of implementation. This media release, dated today and signed by Mr J.B. Robinson, the chief executive officer, says:
A detailed costing from the records of The Sydney Rescue Works Society now confirms other recent estimates of the cost of the Government's accreditation scheme. . .

PARA.TAB: I also draw to the Senate's attention a letter which I received during the luncheon break from the Privacy Commissioner, Mr Kevin O'Connor. It states:

SPEECH.PARA: Dear Senator Newman
