I understand that the regulations are being considered today in the Senate. I have given advice to the Minister (Senator Crowley), which I understand she will be referring to in debate.

I agree with your concern that the exceptions to the statutory definition of "agency" not be used to evade the application of laws such as the Privacy Act. I do not have information to bear out your suggestion that incorporation was calculatedly used in this instance to avoid the operation of the Act. I had in fact had some preliminary discussions with my former colleague, Quentin Bryce, now the executive director of the Council which proceeded on the mutual assumption that the Act was applicable. I was not aware at this stage that the Council was an incorporated body.
My understanding is that the central office of the NCAC, based in Sydney, will only keep a register of accredited child care providers confined to basic particulars.

In the light of the concern that you and the Foundation have raised, I will seek more detail from the Department on the question of what degree of personal information about families and children may be required to be held by accredited providers, and what rights the Department or the NCAC may have in obtaining or inspecting that information.
Yours sincerely
KEVIN O'CONNOR
Privacy Commissioner

Once again, here is confirmation that the opposition's concerns on both cost and privacy are serious matters not satisfactorily addressed to date by the government, and a delay will do nothing but give these serious matters time to be more carefully addressed. What is the government saying to Australia's families? It is saying, `We don't care if you face higher child-care costs; we are going to implement our flawed accreditation and guidelines and you can suffer the consequences'. It is saying that privacy is just a word to this government. And what if the private sector boycotts accreditation? In a climate where demand for formal child-care places is largely outstripping supply, how would the government face up to thousands of parents being denied fee relief because their child-care centres refused to comply with these flawed guidelines? The government must come to its senses.

PARA.TAB: Our concerns are with privacy, with the cost increases and with the impact that this will have on low income and disadvantaged parents. Our concerns are about the effect on the eligibility of parents to fee relief if the non-government sector decides to stay outside the system. We are also concerned that the review in 12 or 18 months time by the minister is worthless because it is a joke for the minister to be reviewing her own program. At the very least, a review of the guidelines must be conducted by an independent person or body. If there is $11 million to spend over four years on accreditation, it could be spent in more practical ways, including greater assistance for special needs children, such as those from a non-English speaking background or those with behavioural disorders. Yet the government drags its feet on meeting these very important needs. I urge all honourable senators to reject the guidelines currently before us.

TALKER.NAME: Senator CROWLEY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Family Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —The debate—which I think we will be concluding now—to disallow these guidelines is actually a second run at exactly the same issues. In the space of a few days the opposition has decided to attack from a different point of view. What is particularly concerning is that the anxiety that has been engendered by the misinformation circulated in the lead-up to the previous debate is not at all assisted by trawling yet again across the same kind of ground, giving some people in the industry a concern that they may not have to proceed with accreditation, even though it is the law and much is already under way for the accreditation process.

PARA.TAB: Much of what Senator Newman said would suggest that there is united opposition by non-government child-care centres to the process of accreditation. It is absolutely important that Senator Newman understands—as she leaves the chamber—that the private centres are not of one voice on this matter. Very large numbers of them are already registered and in the process of trying to tackle the opening stages of the steps that they need to take for the accreditation process. The latest figures that I have to hand are that, since registration started on 1 January, over 500 centres have registered with the Child-care Accreditation Council, and about 48 to 49 per cent of those are private centres. One could say that near enough to half of the centres that have registered come from each sector of the industry.

If this Senate is seriously going to deliberate on this, it is important to know that the objections to accreditation are not coming uniformly from across the industry and they are not coming uniformly from across the private part of the industry; they are coming from small sections of the industry. Indeed, the persistent objections are based in large part, as in the first debate, on misinformation. This is not assisted by Senator Newman's contribution, which perpetuated some of that misinformation. Unlike Senator Newman, I will not say at this stage that she intends to do it deliberately—the sort of accusation that she passes about the rest of us.

Two points in particular need to be raised today. Firstly, I thank my colleagues Senator Lees and Senator Chamarette for their contribution and for their consistent view. I particularly draw the attention of honourable senators to the speech made by Senator Lees, in which she has, in a very thoughtful and detailed way, debunked most of the claims about the extraordinary costs that will be held against child-care centres if they implement the accreditation process. It seems impossible for the opposition to understand and accept what I say—that matters of state regulation are not part of accreditation and therefore are not able to be part of the costs of accreditation. Indeed, they insist that I am a liar. That, I think, shows a very insufficient understanding of what state regulations are about, and I would commend to the opposition a reading of Senator Lees' paper. She makes it very clear, spelling it out in a very useful way. If it is listening to me that upsets opposition members, they should read Senator Lees' contribution and follow thoughtfully the issues she raised and the statements she makes.

The cost issue has got legs, and I am rather pleased to say that we now have some better understanding of the basis for the claims made by the opposition about the costs. We in the government had been waiting for any of those documents to be provided. I am pleased to say that we have access to some of them following the tabling of some documents by Senator Boswell, although the documents he tabled were very insufficient. I do not know whether they were the documents that were provided to him, but certainly as they came to us from the tabling they were insufficient.

We now have the opportunity to examine some of those documents. In light of our examination of the Taylor report in particular, and with the analysis by Senator Lees of other reports, quite clearly the claims that I have been making about costs are very much substantiated. In particular, it is more important to try to wait until the beginning of the implementation of accreditation and to see the process in action rather than rely on hypotheses that people can conclude either from advice given to them or on the basis of the decisions they make from reading the guidelines. Let us remember that, notwithstanding the limitations of the study, the Pitcher findings of costings was based on the actual process of accreditation being implemented in real live centres, in real live time, with real live people; it was done across a variety of private and public centres.

Neither the government nor I has ever claimed that it is a perfect document and that those figures are absolute, but they are a very useful basis for a working document from which one could begin to estimate or `guesstimate' the costs of the accreditation process in centres. I very much endorse the comments of Senator Lees that, if centres are going to worry about the cost of smiling at children or having a warm relationship with children, or learning to speak to children differently, then one can only wonder about the standard of care that would be in those centres at the moment. I also wonder how one could begin to understand why it would cost anything to help people smile. I am concerned that centres would feel that they have to introduce a cost for such processes. As Senator Lees says, they make one worry about what might be the standard of care out there. I do not believe there is much more I should say about cost—I might come back to it—because, as I have said, this matter has been very well canvassed, and refuted, by Senator Lees.

In recent days the issue of privacy has emerged as something on which a further attack against these guidelines could be made. It is important to place on the record some of the facts, the rulings and the evidence we have about privacy, as well as information relating to the accreditation council. The National Childcare Accreditation Council has been having discussions with the Privacy Commissioner since last November to ensure that all its procedures are conducted under privacy guidelines. The council started those discussions as a result of conversations it had with the department. Essentially, the concerns that the department had that came up in discussions with the National Childcare Accreditation Council led to further discussions with the Privacy Commissioner.

As Senator Newman commented, Quentin Bryce was a colleague of the Privacy Commissioner and is extraordinarily well placed to be aware of concerns about privacy. So suggestions by Senator Newman that the government has deliberately tried to construct this council in a certain way so as to dodge privacy issues is drawing a very long bow; it is a very poor attempt by Senator Newman to make much of nothing.

Let me return to the concerns about privacy. National Childcare Accreditation Council material produced for the purpose of gathering data includes a notation approved by the Privacy Commissioner. That notation indicates where the information will be available, where it can be used and by whom, and so on. All of the staff of the National Childcare Accreditation Council sign confidentiality agreements and all departmental officers involved in the accreditation are subject to the Privacy Act.

I wanted to pick up this interesting point in a certain way, but in light of the letter that Senator Newman read, it is important to say that the Privacy Commission has sent advice, firstly, that of course the National Childcare Accreditation Council and the information involved would be a matter of concern from the privacy perspective; and, secondly, that if there were the prospect that the way the National Childcare Accreditation Council had been set up meant it could then fall outside the Privacy Act, that would be of concern. Today I have received advice from the Attorney-General (Mr Lavarch) that makes it absolutely clear that, constituted as it is, the National Childcare Accreditation Council is covered by the Privacy Act, and all the obligations and responsibilities pertaining to information and data that go with that act. So the concerns that have been raised can be laid to rest. The Attorney-General's advice makes it quite clear that the National Childcare Accreditation Council is subject to the provisions of the Privacy Act; that is, the Attorney-General rules that it is covered on the ground that it is defined as an agency under subsection 6(1)(d) of the Privacy Act.

So I am very pleased to be able to assure senators with honourable, and senators with perhaps not quite so honourable, concerns about matters of privacy. I can give that assurance to the Democrats because I know it has consistently been a matter of concern for them as well as the Greens.Privacy is a matter of concern which I think has been honourably raised by many of those opposite. I would like to be able to give them the assurance that the National Childcare Accreditation Council is covered by the Privacy Act.

The guidelines have been on the table for four months. This is not an issue of concern that has been raised by anyone previously. I have to say that those who have been most concerned about it have been the department and the National Childcare Accreditation Council. Processes have been put in place to make sure that the proper behaviour about all and any information coming to the National Childcare Accreditation Council is established.

I want to raise another point about privacy. The National Childcare Accreditation Council is covered by the Privacy Act. However, I am advised that the proposed reviewers who will be appointed to review the self-assessment of centres will not be covered by the Privacy Act. The National Childcare Accreditation Council is developing now a code of ethics for reviewers in close consultation with the Privacy Commissioner. The reviewers, I assure the Senate, will not be doing any work at all, and will not exist, until after July 1994 at the very earliest. So we do have a good lead time to make absolutely sure that the privacy provisions covering every other part of the national child-care accreditation process will also cover the reviewers; and, as I have said, the code of ethics will be well in place before that time. I cannot stress too strongly that those centres that have concern about matters of privacy—and properly so—can be assured by the information and the advice that I have received from the Attorney-General about this matter.

It is interesting to note—and there are many examples of this—that when systems are established people sometimes see things that, with the best will and intention in the world, were not picked up earlier by any number of people canvassing such matters. The issue of privacy has been under the cover of the Privacy Act since it was established. I am very pleased to give the assurance to people who have raised the matter that the Privacy Act is in place and, with the exception of the reviewers, its requirements do cover the areas of the National Childcare Accreditation Council. The requirements in respect of reviewers will be in place by the time they come into operation in July.

I want to make a few points about costs. I am not sure whether Senator Lees covered the cost of translations. One of the claims under the Taylor costings assumes that every service would have to translate information into every one of the 10 languages suggested. In fact, that is not the case, and anyone with commonsense and understanding would know that that is not the case.

There is no need for translation facilities for parents and children of centres needing no language other than English. A centre with children largely from one ethnic background would clearly need a translation facility for that one language requirement. It is important to know that some of these claims are either maximum or hyper-inflated. There is no requirement on centres to translate into either every language or into 10 languages; but there may well be a need for more than one language. To suggest that the costings can be worked out on every centre having to produce translation in 10 languages leads to wrong conclusions about the costs.

It is important to consider the estimate of 88c. For the benefit of Senator Troeth, I want to make it clear on the record that I was not claiming any tested authorship for 55c. The government's consultant estimate is 88c. I was merely referring to a centre in South Australia which had tried to go through the accreditation process as best it could, and its estimate was 55c. I place no more store on the figures provided by a well-intentioned senator than what I said publicly in this place. I understood Senator Troeth to have represented those figures differently this morning.

I remind honourable senators that the 88c is based on the independent consultant's assessment of services that were actually participating in the pilot scheme. All other costings that we have had so far are based on a number of assumptions of what is expected of centres in accreditation. Those assumptions made no reference to the National Childcare Accreditation Council. There have been no phone calls asking whether the assumptions were right, or seeking reflecting information—indeed, no-one in these centres has actually experienced the process.

The costs incurred by centres during the actual process will probably differ from the guesses in just about every way. For instance, if the guess is about translation costs, as I read out, then clearly it will be different. It is very important to allow accreditation to get up and running and to allow the cost estimates to emerge from the actual cases rather than assumptions claimed from reading the guidelines.

I repeat my commitment that I will evaluate the system after the first 12 months of the process. That evaluation will clearly include an assessment of costs, particularly the cost impact on any centres. In the meantime, I have made it very clear to the National Childcare Accreditation Council that I want it to closely monitor the experience of services participating in the system.

I do not believe that this accreditation debate will be assisted by prolonging the possibility of disallowance. Since the guidelines failed to be disallowed in December, a sense of, `Let's get on with the process' has emerged from the child-care industry. Already, over 500 centres have registered with the childcare accreditation council and almost half of that number are private centres. I have confirmation in many letters to my office of the number of private centres that have been appalled at the misinformation in attacking the guidelines and accreditation. Those centres are eager to participate and to make their contribution because they know very well that involvement in accreditation—the ability to say, `We are an accredited centre'—is just the sort of assurance a good, private business would like to have said about itself. That is exactly what those private centres want.

It is very important to note that one of the speakers today from the opposition suggested that with accreditation people will withdraw investment in private child care. I can assure the Senate that at the moment child care is a very favoured area for investment. Those people who are looking for somewhere to put their money are being advised that investment in private child-care centres is a very good option.

I understood Senator Newman to say that many such investors are concerned at investing in a good small business, a good private child-care centre. One of the best hallmarks of a good private child-care centre is the assurance to all potential parents and their children that the centre is a quality one—`With our accreditation process we can assure you that we are providing a very good service. We are concerned both for our business and for the care of our children that we are accredited'. Many private centres are pleased to get into this area as soon as they can.

I am very concerned that genuine objections and difficulties encountered by people confronting accreditation are dealt with and not lost in this hype of awful furphies about accreditation. I am comforted in knowing that, since the disallowance was not successful last December, many of the centres are now getting on with the business of addressing the process and many of their concerns are being laid to rest. I hope that is the way we can proceed from here, rather than have today's claims in the child-care area causing more anxiety and confusion.

It is important to remind Senator Troeth that if there are salary costs as a result of state licensing requirements, then that is not part of accreditation. Senator Newman thought it was interesting that we should add something to the state licensing requirements. I am not absolutely sure but I think it was Senator Newman who challenged me by saying, `Ask your state colleagues'. I will certainly give due consideration to that request. I can imagine Senator Newman saying, `How dare you interfere with the states' in any other debate in this place—`What do you mean? Why is the Commonwealth poking its nose into state licensing requirements?'. If Senator Newman wants me to take that request seriously, I will take up the issue and make inquiries sensitive to the state licensing responsibilities. It is not a bad idea, especially in light of the information provided to the Senate by Senator Lees from her examination of some of the claims by centres in Queensland. Claims are being made by centres across this country, most of which would be assisted by fact and not a proffered fiction.

The state licensing regulations are not part of accreditation. The costs of state licensing cannot be used against accreditation. We assess the cost of accreditation of a centre as 88c plus or minus a little bit per child because we are realistic about the need to implement some of those changes at some stage.

Senator Newman said that accreditation, by and large, does not duplicate state licensing requirements. Senator Newman is absolutely right—it does not duplicate state licensing requirements. It is a matter of grave concern for the government, which is why we are introducing accreditation for staff ratios and guidelines for the physical environment of children, the relationship between staff and children, the content of a child's day, and safety and health matters. Those matters go to the heart of quality child care.

Some of the objections are very amusing for any of us who have been around for a few years and visited pre-schools, child-care centres and kindergartens where these practices have largely been the name of the game for very many years now. Indeed, the Lady Gowrie centres were established by Lady Gowrie in 1939 as a result of concern for quality care of children. The government believes that child-care centres should practice that kind of comfortable and loving care for our children. The primary concern is for quality care for our children in those centres where they can spend very long hours. Also, as Senator Chamarette said, very large amounts of money are being spent now on child care. Properly, the government wants to be able to account for those dollars being appropriately spent.

I do not believe we have been assisted in the accreditation process by re-running this disallowance debate. It is very much a re-run. The issue was put to bed last December. It allowed the industry to shake itself down and get on with the process of accreditation. I hope we can vote and finish this debate in a moment, once and for all, and allow the accreditation process to start. We will then be able to evaluate it on the run, in real life experience, in real centres.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply—Let me say to Senator Crowley that, as responsible opposition senators, if we had just one objection to the guidelines, we would voice it. I would feel it my responsibility to do so. As we have had more than one objection, that is exactly what we are doing.

PARA.TAB: Our concerns, as evidenced by the speeches of the other two coalition speakers, Senator Newman and Senator Boswell, have been to do with the costings that I evidenced this morning, privacy and the impact on low income earners. We are talking about people's livelihoods. We are talking about the people who run the centres—they act as small businessmen—and the welfare of the children and families who use them. Both those groups of people have considerable concerns with what has been introduced in this legislation.

I am glad that Senator Lees did appreciate the substantive nature of our arguments. The reason we did decide to have a re-run of this debate, as Senator Crowley has put it, is that sufficient doubt has been cast on the costings since we last had this debate for us to raise the matter again. That is why we have done so.

With regard to staff needing language training, I point out to Senator Crowley that in some primary schools, particularly in the inner Melbourne area, something like 13 to 14 languages are spoken in the playground. Unfortunately, primary schools, secondary schools and day-care centres do not slip easily into a preconditioned mould of conveniently having one, two or three languages. In the melting pot that is our civilisation in Australia today we have many languages to cope with. Day-care centres should not be any different in that role from primary or secondary schools. We will need at least the 10 languages and probably the 10 pages of instructions.

Senator Lees also mentioned the professional and legal responsibility that day-care centres will have. From some of the press reports of the non-education of professional staff these days in areas such as legal responsibilities generally and rights in harassment situations or under harassment charges, for example, I believe that day-care centre staff will need to take a great deal of professional and legal responsibility, particularly as we seem to be moving into a society that takes litigation very seriously.

More education is needed. It would have to be of such a standard that I could not imagine it taking place in the workplace. I can only imagine that extra professional courses would be required. All of that would add to the cost.I agree with Senator Lees that special needs should be catered for. That is one area in which very professional training is required.

Senator Lees also agreed with me that an increase of $5 a week is too high. Five or six dollars a week extra money for child care can make or break the economic budgets of many low income families. Many of these parents, both mothers and fathers, place their children in day care because they need to earn a second income to get their family budget to balance, particularly over the last couple of years in the recession that we had to have. If they are faced with paying extra money for child care, and as we have seen this morning $5 or $6 is an extremely conservative estimate, they may well consider other avenues of child care. It is all very well to say that is a very low amount. For some families it is not a very low amount. I would like to remind Senator Crowley of that.

I am sure Senator Chamarette is well intentioned, but she does appear to be hoping for the best. We are saying that onerous guidelines will impose financial burdens on centres and parents. How do we address the concerns after the guidelines are in place? The proper place to express our concerns about the guidelines is here and now, while this legislation still has the chance to be amended. I would not like to be trying to address the concerns and change the guidelines in 12 or 18 months' time.

Child-care centres are the very last places that should be thrown into turmoil as far as administration and the way they should be run. To say that we will do this now, and then change the system if it does not work properly, is one of the worst administrative ideas I have ever heard.

The government apparently is unable to realise that acquiescence and compliance with the guidelines will impose financial burdens. This is what we should be looking at. If costs rise, parents will seek alternatives and place children at further risk.

Senator Newman outlined very well our concerns about privacy. As she said, the guidelines illustrate the government's cavalier response. We believe there is strong and widespread opposition. The bodies that have expressed their concerns to us are responsible bodies that look after child-care centres. They would not be expressing these concerns if they did not feel strongly.

Of course Senator Crowley could cite the number of child-care centres that have registered for operation. As I said in my remarks this morning, they have no option. They do not like it, but they have to go along with it. That is why large numbers are registering. I am glad that Senator Crowley admits that there are some objections.

We are talking about concrete changes, not intangibles. Senator Crowley mentioned that it does not cost much to smile or talk positively to children. It does cost to change the structure of a child-care centre and to start reversing the way in which it has been operated for years. It all costs money. I will not go on further, because I think I have well established the coalition's concerns. We would like to see these guidelines disallowed. I therefore ask honourable senators to support me.
Question put:
That the motion (Senator Troeth's) be agreed to.
Question so resolved in the negative.

DEBATE.TITLE: DEPARTMENT OF IMMIGRATION AND ETHNIC AFFAIRS

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOLKUS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Multicultural Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —There has been some discussion about documents relating to an AFP investigation into the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs, or certain aspects of it. The documents—which were sought by Senator Short and which can be tabled in the manner requested—consist of two letters from the AFP to the secretary to the department. I will also table a circular from the secretary to staff relating to the issue.

PARA.TAB: The second letter from the AFP to the secretary states that if any action against the two officers, the subject of the correspondence, is to be taken, disciplinary action might be more appropriate. On the basis of the letter, the secretary decided not to pursue disciplinary action against the officers who made the allegations. I table the two letters, together with the circular from the secretary.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I thank the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs (Senator Bolkus) for complying with the return to order as required by the Senate. Through you, Madam Acting Deputy President, I seek confirmation from the minister that the two letters tabled by him constitute the Australian Federal Police report in its entirety, the tabling of which I had sought. In other words, I assume from what the minister has said that there is no other report from the Australian Federal Police relating to this matter and its investigation of it.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOLKUS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Multicultural Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I am informed that the documents in the possession of the secretary to the department are the only documents in the possession of the department that can in any way be described as being reports of the investigation.The AFP conducted its investigation—I do not know what working documents or otherwise it would have had—and I am informed that the only documents that came to the secretary to the department from the AFP are these two letters. While they cannot be called formal reports, they are correspondence from the AFP by way of report to the secretary.

—by leave—I thank the minister for that information. I therefore take it that the letters tabled by him constitute the only material or advice from the AFP on which the secretary to his department made his decision not to proceed with the matter further. I ask whether that is correct?

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOLKUS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Multicultural Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—My advice is that they are the only documents coming from the AFP on which the secretary has relied.

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator West)—We now come to the consideration of government documents. There are 85 government documents listed for consideration in today's Notice Paper and there is a limit of one hour for their consideration. To expedite the consideration of the documents, I propose, with the concurrence of honourable senators, to call the documents in groups of 10. Documents called in each group to which no senator rises will be taken as being discharged from the Notice Paper. Documents not called today will remain on the Notice Paper. There being no objection, it is so ordered.
Debate resumed from 25 November 1993, on motion by Senator Reid:
That the Senate take note of the document.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to deal with document No. 1, the Australian Securities Commission annual report for 1992-93. I do not want to deal with it at length, but the first point I want to make is simply that I am glad to see that in its annual report the Australian Securities Commission expresses great regret that two of its senior executives were found by the Senate Standing Committee on Privileges to have committed a contempt of parliament which, by the way, resulted in no penalty being recommended. The annual report states:

SPEECH.PARA: The ASC has apologised to the Senate and is ensuring that all senior staff are aware of the principles governing the operation of Parliament, particularly the rights and responsibilities of, and protection afforded to, witnesses before parliamentary committees.
It is unfortunate that it happened. It should not have happened, but at least now the Securities Commission is aware of its duty.

PARA.TAB: I want to deal with another matter relating to duty, and that is its duty to ensure that all the information in its database relating to companies is accurate and that the provision of that information is timely. The source of this information is company annual returns, which company secretaries are obliged to put in on time, and they should be accurate. The Securities Commission report says:

SPEECH.PARA: The ASC has actively encouraged company secretaries to ensure that Annual Returns are accurate and lodged on time.
It goes on to say:

There has been a longstanding problem in promoting compliance with these requirements, based perhaps on perceptions that lodgement was difficult, the requirements unclear or that no action would be taken for non-compliance.

That is the essence, that was the perception, and it seems to have been what encouraged people such as Mr Constantinidis, Mr Keating's business partner in his multimillion dollar multinational piggery group, to treat this requirement with utter contempt. I raised today the matter of one of his companies that has not put in an annual return for six years. Of course, the piggery group companies themselves have not put in annual returns that were timely, and the bulk of them, I understand, have received penalty notices.

PARA.TAB: The issue of penalty notices is very important. The annual report says:

SPEECH.PARA: In August 1992 the ASC started a summary prosecutions program aimed at improving the quality of the database. 118,000 penalty notices were sent to secretaries of companies which had not lodged Annual Returns for 1991.

The Prime Minister's piggery group is among that 118,000. I have a letter from Lynn Ralph, the acting chairperson of the ASC, saying that although no penalty notice in respect of late lodgment of annual returns has been sent to the Brown and Hatton Group Pty Ltd itself, penalty notices have been issued to other companies within the group. That is disgraceful. The annual report continues:

The notice stated that if the company failed to act on the penalty notice the ASC would start legal proceedings. About 50,000 penalties were paid, 12,500 penalties were cancelled, and the rest grouped into various priority categories for summary prosecution in State and Territory courts. During the year 8565 summary prosecutions were begun, with 8133 matters concluded.

I am disappointed that the ASC took the view that some of the companies in the Prime Minister's piggery group did not merit this kind of prosecution because the letter that was sent by Mr Constantinidis to apologise was simply misleading and I believe the ASC was wrong in accepting that misleading letter as some kind of justification. It is disappointing to note in the letter from Lynn Ralph the following statement:

In respect of 1990 and a number of 1991 late annual returns, the ASC issued only warning notices, including to BHG, as there had been little follow up under the former Corporate Affairs Commissions. In 1991 the ASC compliance section had to design, await the building of and test the automated follow up system and as a result action was not taken in all instances.

Because of the effectiveness of this, the ASC is expecting that next year only about 65,000 penalty notices will be issued for failure to lodge 1992 annual returns on time. I notice that, following the experience of the Prime Minister's half-owned company piggery group, the Brown and Hatton group put in its 1992 returns on time. (Time expired)

PARA.TAB: Question resolved in the affirmative.
Debate resumed from 25 November 1993, on motion by Senator Sandy Macdonald:
That the Senate take note of the document.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to address very briefly document No. 6, the 1992-93 report of the Australian Wool Realisation Commission. Senator Woodley is listed as being in continuation, and I thought he would have finished off what he had to say. I would like the Senate to note that there is a belief in the wool industry that there is an improvement. Of course there is an improvement; there is a slight improvement from the basic price that has been around for quite a few years now. Having gone down to the depths of despair, the price is starting to turn around. But it is nowhere near the figure that we need for it to be a viable industry, especially when producers totally rely on wool as an income.

PARA.TAB: I did quite a tour of the southern Nullarbor pastoral industry and the eastern goldfields pastoral industry over the break and I found that most of those stations are in a care and maintenance situation. They are keeping the improvements up and the numbers of stock up, but there are certain things that they are not able to do. They are not able to make any improvements to their structures. They are not able to do new fencing. As honourable senators might have heard, there were a lot of bushfires in the Nullarbor that burnt a lot of fencing down. Fortunately, all of those were insured and they are able to replace the fences. What the people in the pastoral industry did impress upon me—not that I did not know before—is the present price. The last price I was given was about 536c a kilo.

To have a viable wool industry, we have to return to around 700c a kilo. When we do—I can see it coming; probably in a couple of years time—that industry will be very viable, not only for the pastoral industry but for the wool industry that is run alongside the cropping situation. We had a new scheme put in place in the wool industry some six- or eight-odd months ago—maybe a little longer than that—under the stewardship of Mr Crean, who was minister for primary industry at the time. What I would like to impress on the industry and everyone is that we cannot depart from the arrangements that were made.

Wool production is down this financial year to 717 million kilos for the year. More is being sold. There is more coming out of the stockpile, and I believe that that situation, having been fixed, has to stay. There is no going back on that one. That is what wrecked the old scheme. Honourable senators may remember when Mr Kerin ran around the world and said that 700c was unchangeable, and then all of a sudden it was gone. There was a lot of damage and a lot of confidence was lost at the time. No matter how tough things are, even though the stations and others are on care and maintenance, we must stay where we are and look forward to better times.

I noticed during the week that Mr Kerin, the former Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, was appointed Chairman of the Australian Meat and Livestock Corporation. He was described in the Australian Financial Review as `the farmer's friend'. I wish Mr Kerin well in his new job as head of the AMLC, but I would not call him a farmer's friend, not after what he did to some of our rural industries, and to the wool industry in particular. While I wish him well in his new venture, those of us associated with the wool industry will remember him for the damage that he did rather than for the good that he did.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Operations of the IMF and the World Bank

PARA.TAB: Debate resumed from 25 November 1993, on motion by Senator Margetts:
That the Senate take note of the document.

TALK.START.PARA: —Essentially, this report was nothing more than a general description of the IMF. It said little about the changes that were consequent to the ninth general review. It did not talk about what the IMF is doing about the ongoing problems of international debt. It did not talk about what the IMF is going to do to promote exchange stability or to maintain orderly exchange arrangements. It did not mention how the IMF was going to promote and maintain high levels of employment and income of member nations. I suggest that this was because the IMF is actually doing nothing about these issues, beyond blindly imposing fundamentalist economic policy on poor nations.

PARA.TAB: The IMF is well known for two things. First, it demands of borrowers that they deregulate their economies in response to the cynical argument that free trade is good. Frequently, this deregulation consists of eliminating barriers to imports of consumer goods, such as imported alcohol, and opening barriers to international fund transfers. The first measure simply exacerbates international debt, while the second generally results in capital flight as the wealthy elite stash their money in banks in Europe and in the United States of America.

The second of the IMF's frequent solutions is to impose austerity programs—demanding cuts to social infrastructure such as education, health and so on—which it calls `reduction of public expenditure'. This frequently results in a decline in the ability of the work force to compete for trained jobs and an increase in political instability. It is worth noting that only rarely do cuts in public expenditure extend to cuts in military expenditure, which is often a major source of international expenditure in poor developing nations. More ominously, such cuts almost never extend to reducing internal police and paramilitary expenditure, in spite of sometimes appalling records of human rights abuses.

The Brandt report on trade and debt, North/South, produced in 1980, and the Brundtland report, Our Common Future, produced in 1987, and many other international reports have pointed out that the IMF and the World Bank are often major culprits in maintaining and reinforcing poverty, misery and maldevelopment and that they are in urgent need of reform. Yet we hear of no plans for reform nor for dealing with the international debt and its problems. Both reports have also pointed out that under the regime of deregulation and so-called free trade, poor nations have become poorer, the difference between the rich and the poor in all nations has become greater, and that this has exacted an increasing price from the local and global environment.

The primary purpose of the IMF is supposed to be a stabilisation of currencies. Today the biggest element of instability in currency is speculation—what is known as short-term financial transactions. Currency and bond speculation is a result of international deregulation of the financial markets and fund transfers. It boomed during the 1980s to a level where the scale of the market for currency speculation was about 40 times that of all real goods and services globally. It is a speculation run on the big cash holders—commercial banks, merchant and investment banks, insurance and superannuation companies, and stock brokers.

Recently we have seen this speculation destabilise European currency in the run-up to the EC attempt at creating a common currency. Again we have seen how this sector can dominate Australian and Japanese currency. What will the IMF do about this? Where is the plan to promote exchange stability? There is no plan. There is only the blind adherence to deregulation, as if deregulation was not the major source of the problem. It may not have been the source of such problems when the IMF was set up at the end of the colonial period, but times have changed. Instead of any plan of stabilisation, which is a worthy goal, we see blind adherence to deregulation.

We need to note especially that further deregulation of the financial sector, or financial services, is one of the two major goals of the Uruguay Round of GATT—the other child of Bretton Woods, along with the imposition of the US patent system under the intellectual property rights. In this context, we feel that the report tabled is entirely inadequate. As noted, it is simply a summary of what the IMF is; it says nothing about the major problems faced by developing nations and what it will do. It says nothing about the major problem of currency speculation, even though it is clearly in the IMF brief to promote exchange stability. It says nothing at all about plans to reform the IMF—in fact, it says almost nothing at all. That is simply not good enough. In the future I expect to see reports that actually convey information about how the International Monetary Fund is addressing these problems. (Time expired)
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Debate resumed from 25 November 1993, on motion by Senator Margetts:
That the Senate take note of the document.

TALK.START.PARA: —As with the report on the IMF, this report contains an account of the World Bank that is mainly descriptive. It is noted that in 1988 the bank decided that the amount of money made available to nations should be increased by 77 per cent. The bank asked for subscriptions from wealthy members. Australia subscribed to less than three-quarters—74 per cent—of its shares, following its practice of putting less than the recommended amounts into any sort of foreign aid. The aid budget, including administration costs, is 0.326 per cent of gross domestic product.

PARA.TAB: The report contains a number of speeches made by the previous Treasurer, Mr Dawkins, which are of interest and appear to acknowledge some of the problems of international development generally and the World Bank's role in them. However, the major thrust of the speeches is to reinforce the approach of the IMF. Mr Dawkins appeared to be a big fan of forced austerity measures. He cannot understand why developed nations, which are not forced to, do not impose their own austerity measures.

If we read the forward projection of the budget, we see that Mr Dawkins was apparently happy to show more consistency here and impose social austerity programs in Australia. He acknowledged the problems of instability in financial markets and called for action by others in the bank, but he appeared to think that the only answer lay in slash and burn economics or, as he put it, getting national policy settings and institutional arrangements right through reducing structural budget deficits.

His only other answer to global economic problems was the success of the Uruguay Round of GATT. He referred to the UNCED programs and its call for development without acknowledging that `sustainable' refers to `ecologically sustainable' and that the `development' referred to is of a new kind in which ecological sustainability, equity, social justice, and security are firmly embedded as major social goals.

In light of the attitude of the former Treasurer, it is worth reading the final communique of the Joint Ministerial Committee under Mr Foxley. There is hardly a better way to show up the inadequacies in the Australian government's approach than to compare this with the former Treasurer's speeches. While the communique remains very much a conservative World Bank statement, the development objectives as stated are to reduce poverty and to protect the environment.

The document highlights the need for debt service reduction and relief measures. It emphasises the need for developing fair and equitable international standards for the general treatment of all foreign direct investment and welcomes moves made in that direction. It highlights the need for bilateral aid and sets the target at 0.7 per cent of gross domestic product. Australia funds aid which is less than half that or, as I mentioned before, 0.326 per cent. It also notes the need for increased multilateral aid, and the need for environmental protection and financial support for the Agenda 21 program.

In short, it is clear that the government, and specifically the former Treasurer, took a far more narrow view than even the World Bank, which has not been known for its radicalism. It is a narrow view that sees only the reduction in expenditure, increased corporate freedom and power and the reduction of wage and price pressure as important in development and society. It ignores equity, the environment, social justice and humanitarian consideration.

We cannot feel happy upon reading the book that has been tabled. We have a new treasurer now. The WA Greens will be wishing to speak on the issues of aid and our response to development issues. We do not want to be in this rut of slash and burn economics either in our own Australian situation or in our interactions with other countries, especially in relation to poverty reduction and global environmental sustainability.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Debate resumed from 8 December 1993, on motion by Senator Tambling:
That the Senate take note of the document.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chamarette Sen C.M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Whilst the final report of the Resource Assessment Commission, the Coastal zone inquiry, is a thick document, this is not inappropriate because it covers the consideration of a very heavy matter. Australians are becoming aware that our coastal zone is an area that has been neglected. We have failed to have a detailed assessment of what is occurring in any integrated fashion right around the coast of Australia.

PARA.TAB: The Resource Assessment Commission inquiry has been useful. I believe that there are many positive recommendations for improving the current management problems that beset our coast. There is only one problem that I wish to deal with. As the ACF said in its media release, the report fails to go far enough in some of its recommendations. In some respects we welcome the inquiry. We believe that it has presented a useful set of mechanisms whereby the Commonwealth and the states can cooperate to look after an area which needs to be dealt with in a much more meaningful way.

The report is over 500 pages long. As I have said, some of the recommendations are disappointing in that they do not go far enough. To reinforce some of my comments, I ask honourable senators to take note of the dissenting report of Special Commissioner R.J. Graham. Whilst not wishing to condemn the report, he asked that some of its recommendations should be viewed with greater seriousness so that they could be taken a few steps further. The Special Commissioner said:

SPEECH.PARA: The Inquiry's recommendations focus on the "big picture"—a necessary focus, but insufficient on its own.
He said that the recommendations—
largely fail to make the connections with the litany of management problems—
that have occurred in various areas. He continued:

Broad prescriptions need to be connected directly to what happens on an everyday basis on the ground. To do so it has to be stressed that it is not resources which need to be managed. What is needed is management of the ways in which people use and develop resources. This may be an obvious point but it seems to have been missed by the Inquiry.
The Special Commissioner continued:

I have attempted to make these connections by outlining development guidelines and management proposals in considerable detail. In particular, I have attempted to build direct links between the big picture and what happens on the ground. How can the local bulldozer driver and works engineer be aware of biological diversity unless these connections are made?
I commend the entire report, and particularly the dissenting report which encourages us to go much further.

PARA.TAB: The Greens (WA) are concerned about the recommendations on water quality and marine pollution. The report recommends that state governments require all authorities responsible for the supply and disposal of water and other waste to take urgent steps to introduce charges that reflect the costs of supplying these services. It goes on to recommend the use of tradable permit systems to meet water quality criteria. We are concerned that to simply put in place two economic instruments will do very little to stop pollution of our waterways. Eighty per cent of marine pollution comes from land based sources, and one would have expected a report on the environmental problems of the coastal zone to have come up with something more than economic instruments.

There is an urgent need to develop national legislation to control land based pollution of the sea. The Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories (Mrs Kelly) should be using her constitutional powers to develop such legislation as a matter of urgency. The United Nations environment program is reviewing its regional seas program and the effectiveness of measures to halt land based sources of marine pollution. Australia could well be left behind the rest of the world if it does not take specific action to address the issue of coastal pollution.

I wish to refer to the role of indigenous people in relation to fisheries matters. It is a very useful recommendation, and I think it needs to be taken further. This is the last in a series of 15 government reports on the coast. We simply need to go much further if we are to deal with this problem. Evidence is rapidly mounting that we need to provide solutions that are meaningful at a local community level, as well as integrated on a national basis, to deal with the problems in our coastal zone.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Department of the Environment, Sport and Territories

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Knowles Sen S.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the document.

SPEECH.PARA: The annual report of the Department of the Environment, Sport and Territories raises again the issue of the Kelly sports grants affair and this government's continuing manipulation and abuse of the public purse. I think the shabbiest thing about this whole sports grants affair is that the government has been exposed as trying to bribe Australians with their own money. That is the saddest part of all. In fact, it is the most flagrant display of public vote buying ever seen in Australia. It is also a tale of flagrant ministerial abuse of responsibility by the honourable member for Canberra, Mrs Kelly, which has gone shamefully unchecked by the government.

PARA.TAB: I spoke at lunchtime on another element of this particular rort. Senator Michael Baume drew to my attention the fact that he had raised this issue some two years ago and yet nothing has ever been done about it. The fact that Labor was twice as generous in handing out its taxpayer-funded grants in its own seats as it was to the marginal seats held by the coalition smacks at the very least of gross mishandling of taxpayers' money.

Mrs Kelly became a political philanthropist in her own electorate. The only problem was that she was giving away the public's money—money that, according to the sports grants criteria, should have been spent in other seats. Labor seats in Western Australia are among those at the end of this taxpayer-funded vote buying exercise. The federal seats of Perth and Swan—occupied by the former prime ministerial adviser and now prime ministerial aspirant, Stephen Smith, and Kim Beazley, the Minister for Finance and honourable member for Swan—came in for some extra-generous funding.

The Auditor-General's report found that an incredible $604,635 went into the seat of Perth and $542,562 into Swan. On the basis of these grants, it cost the government a scandalous $1,845.44 per winning vote in Swan and $72.22 per winning vote in Perth. I should not say that it cost the government—it cost taxpayers. It was their money. It cost $1,800 to win a vote in Swan and $72 to win a vote in Perth. In the seat held by the Assistant Treasurer, George Gear, the Kelly sports grants factor was worth a massive $406,592, leaving the taxpayer with a bill of $1,666.36 per winning vote.

There is no shame among members of the Labor party. They have no shame whatsoever that they can fork out that sort of money. Former Labor Minister Wendy Fatin's seat of Brand received grants totalling $432,637—a cost of $77.80 per winning vote. Between Western Australia's marginal seats of Brand, Canning, Swan and Perth, more than $19 million was spent on shoring up Labor stalwarts, including Mr Beazley, Mr Gear, Mrs Fatin and Mr Smith. On the other hand, in the seat of Stirling—which was written off by many Labor pundits before the last election—only $80,000 was outlaid by the government in sports grants. The government made a sort of halfway bet, I suppose; knowing that it was going to lose, it did not bother to put much into that seat. In the seat of Cowan, which Labor had also all but conceded it would lose, only $30,000 was spent. This compares with $45,000 which was spent on one project alone in Mrs Kelly's electorate.

Going on figures from Mrs Kelly's own electorate, a sports club or an organisation of which the minister was a member, was in for a funding bonanza. Mrs Kelly made it quite clear that a grant of $100,000 was nothing for her. Of course, honourable senators will have guessed that, as it turned out, Mrs Kelly is a member of a number of these organisations.

The Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories must follow the lead of her colleague the former Minister for Industry, Technology and Regional Development and resign. She should have done it months ago. She has chosen not to, but this just comes out in how much she has rorted. We have only scratched the surface of this affair, which promises to continue to reveal some startling facts.

TALK.START.PARA: —I read with interest some of the annual report of the Department of the Environment, Sport and Territories to try to gain some appreciation of the gains made by the environment part of the department in particular. Unfortunately, the report tends to be a recitation of what the department has done in terms of writing reports, attending meetings, preparing strategies, et cetera. There really is no indication as to whether or not the environment was actually improved as a result of the activities of the department.

PARA.TAB: In particular, I found it rather disappointing that the report is very brief and rather uninformative on one of the major environmental issues in Australia—the protection of our old growth forests. The only reference is in relation to the national forest policy statement initiatives. This section is so short and bland that one has no indication as to the destruction of our old growth forests that is occurring under this so-called initiative.

I would like to remind honourable senators that the national forest policy statement was agreed to by all governments in Australia except Tasmania. Under the agreement there is supposed to be a moratorium on logging old growth forests and wilderness areas that are likely to have high conservation value until those areas have been properly assessed. Yet, the DEST annual report makes no mention of the fact that there are flagrant breaches of the intergovernmental agreement occurring in a number of states. Where are the performance indicators for this agreement that the Commonwealth has signed? Why have woodchip licences been issued by the Minister for Resources (Mr Beddall) with no apparent consideration for the requirements of the national forest policy statement?

The annual report also refers to technical working groups that have been established to identify criteria for developing a comprehensive, adequate and representative system of reserves in forests and to establish baseline environmental standards. I would like to stress to both the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories (Mrs Kelly) and the Minister for Resources that the draft documents prepared by these working groups must be put out for public discussion and comment before being finalised for presentation to governments. Community interest groups have considerable interest in the criteria for forest reserves and in the baseline environmental standards, and their input would be invaluable.

Generally, the minister for the environment has a good record in terms of consultation. I hope that this continues and she can put more pressure on her federal colleague the Minister for Resources and her state government colleagues to adhere to the conditions of the national forest policy statement. Both Western Australia and Victoria in particular are experiencing grave concerns about logging in old growth forests. We all know, having regard to the tragedies of the bushfires, that we need to look at the real and effective preservation of what remains of our old growth forests and take great care as to their protection.
Debate (on motion by Senator McGauran) adjourned.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chamarette Sen C.M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the document.

SPEECH.PARA: I seek leave to continue my remarks later.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted; debate adjourned.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts Sen D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the document.

SPEECH.PARA: I have not had the opportunity to examine this report in detail, but I was horrified to read in the overview the author's claim that the practical ability to manage waste comes in part from the ability to generate a surplus from everyday economic activity. It is an astounding statement. It appears that the Industry Commission is convinced that we need to continue to produce waste and pollution so that we can afford to clean up the mess. This philosophy lies at the heart of the problem facing the nation and this planet as we approach the end of the 20th century. There appears to be no commitment to address the fundamental problems.

PARA.TAB: Whilst there appears to be some discussion in the report about the need to avoid or reduce pollution, the emphasis is placed on economic instruments to achieve this end. The enormous environmental problems in this country and overseas will require creative solutions that address the fundamental problems. We cannot afford to continue to rely on half-baked solutions or the vagaries of the market. We cannot, for example, rely on waste water or sewerage treatment in isolation when there are fundamental solutions available that aim to minimise sewerage or water use and acknowledge the ecological limitations of the regions in which these systems operate.

The oft-quoted analogy with the human body is appropriate: if a person is diagnosed as having heart problems, continuous bypass surgery is not appropriate if the lifestyle issues that probably caused the heart problem are not addressed. I should stress, however, that I do not under-value the opportunities for environmental waste management equipment, systems and services, particularly with respect to export. My concern is that the government may not have the commitment to also pursue the fundamental solutions to environmental problems rather than relying on bandaid options. We see this very clearly in the pollution that is now having very detrimental effects on rivers all over Australia, and now in Western Australia as well. People are still looking for bandaid solutions. They might be putting money into authorities to look at the situation but they are not addressing some of the problems of inappropriate land use and planning that have created the problems in the first place.

We have to think more broadly. It is only when economic activities are affected by these environmental tragedies that we seem to shake our heads and realise something must be done. We have to think more laterally than that. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the document.

SPEECH.PARA: I shall take advantage of this opportunity to make some comments about the regulator of the superannuation industry, the Insurance and Superannuation Commission. The ISC has provided invaluable assistance to the parliamentary committee that oversees this process, the Senate Select Committee on Superannuation. Indeed, the close cooperation that has dominated the relationship between the Insurance and Superannuation Commission and the parliamentary committee on superannuation has meant that many of the difficulties that often arise in the passage of legislation through the parliament have been minimised. I take this opportunity of mentioning that the committee has also worked extremely successfully with industry and consumer groups.

PARA.TAB: Towards the end of the last session of parliament, the package of bills known as the Superannuation Industry (Supervision) Bills—commonly referred to as the SIS bills—passed through the parliament. As has already been noted, this legislation will commence on 1 July this year and provide greater protection to members of superannuation funds in terms of prudential controls.

The smooth passage of this legislation through the parliament can be credited to the cooperation that I have mentioned which exists among the key groups in this field. This cooperation has been nurtured and promoted by the Select Committee on Superannuation to excellent effect.

I also congratulate the ISC team on the constructive role it has played as the regulator. It has some very fine people working within it. At the same time, I think it is probably appropriate to indicate that the tone and the success of the ISC was very much set by the founding ISC commissioner, Mr Richard Beetham. During his career as ISC commissioner, he made an outstanding contribution towards the establishment and development of the commission. During his five-year term as commissioner he performed to the highest level of professional standards, often at the time with inadequate resources.

The problem of resources created a massive work overload which was only overcome through the tireless dedication of Mr Beetham and his staff. There is no doubt that without Mr Beetham the ISC would not have developed into the organisation it is today. At the same time, I wish to commend and congratulate Mr Pooley on his role as commissioner and commend him on his leadership of the ISC during the passage of the SIS bills through the parliament.

As the assets in superannuation funds continue to grow, the work of the ISC becomes increasingly vital. We heard this week concern about the loss of superannuation benefits facing the employees of the McDonnell and East retail business. Throughout the past year the ISC has worked with a judicial manager in an attempt to ensure that the financial damage, for example, to Regal Life and Occidental Life policyholders would be minimised. It appears that the work of the manager and the ISC will result in a reasonable outcome for the policyholders. It is imperative that the ISC be proactive in preventing such disastrous situations.

As many honourable senators will be aware, master trusts have been the subject of much public concern. Only recently I heard that one of the reasons for the rapid growth of these master trusts is the move to avoid much of the regulatory type of environment that has surrounded superannuation. It is activity such as this that will create the greatest challenges for the ISC in its role as regulator and protector of the country's retirement income. I therefore congratulate the ISC on its valuable work, and in particular on its cooperation with the Select Committee on Superannuation, and on its work as a regulator of the vast superannuation assets. Finally, I implore the ISC and all those involved in superannuation to be vigilant so as to provide needed security for their very valuable resource.

Earlier today I spoke to the annual report 1992-93 of the Commonwealth Superannuation Board of Trustees No. 1. In its annual report the public sector superannuation scheme indicated it did not feel it was appropriate for it to participate in industry market surveys. This reluctance of the trustees of the funds to participate in the surveys was raised during Senate estimates by me last year. I am pleased to report that following the Budget estimates the trustees have given this matter their prompt attention. The board of trustees have established an internal monitoring process in that they have adopted a range of indexes which the fund managers are expected to outperform and against which performance is measured. The result of the fund's performance relative to these benchmarks is available to members every six months by means of a newsletter and the results are published in the board's annual report. (Extension of time granted)

The trustees of the CSS and the Public Sector Superannuation Fund recently decided to participate in the new public sector survey set up by William Mercer Ltd, and the first issue of this survey is to be released with the results of the September board meeting. I therefore take this opportunity of congratulating the trustees for participating in these important survey comparisons. They are essential to maintaining confidence in public sector superannuation, particularly from the public perspective.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts Sen D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the document.

SPEECH.PARA: It was pleasing to note, when reviewing the Industry Commission report, that the economic rationalist approach that has tended to dominate Industry Commission reports to date has been softened somewhat in this latest report by an expression of concern for the social justice aspects of this very important issue.

PARA.TAB: It is also worth noting at this stage that this report should not be seen as the definitive and primary vehicle for the much needed reform of the public housing sector. There will need to be a broader and more long-term public process to pursue this reform, and I look forward to government initiatives in that regard. I think it is safe to say that many community organisations, together with the Greens, will applaud the fundamental finding of this Industry Commission report—it is not often that we are seen applauding an Industry Commission report—because it states that the provision of public housing, rather than cash payments and housing allowances, is the most cost-effective option for delivering housing assistance to people on low incomes.

There are, however, some concerns amongst social justice groups about the structural changes proposed by this report in relation to the implementation of housing policy and the role of federal and state governments in that process. In this regard I will quote from a press release issued by the Australian Council of Social Service. Its concerns include the following:

SPEECH.PARA: The changes proposed to the Commonwealth State Housing Agreement . . . which would restrict the commonwealth role to income support, leaving the states to finance housing provision. This will create the capacity for states to reduce the level of support and opens the door to a potential 50% reduction in the commonwealth contribution to public housing provision;
The proposed rent setting arrangement is too complex, and will mean that tenants living in the inner city would be worse off;
Splitting property and tenancy management functions into different departments will make it far harder to respond to tenant needs;

The proposed changes to waiting lists which appear to be unworkable because of the difficulty in weighting different needs, the additional administrative burden created by proposed assessment panels and will lead to a greater welfarisation of public housing;
Tenants paying a premium above the market rent for the security of tenure offered by public housing.
I look forward to the opportunity to participate in any ongoing review process on this issue.

PARA.TAB: Finally, with reference to the forthcoming budget, I would like to suggest to the government that it give serious consideration to an increase in Commonwealth funding under the Commonwealth state housing agreement to rectify the reduction in funding in real terms over recent years. The need for a national approach to public housing as identified in this report also necessitates proper funding of the relevant Commonwealth departments responsible for the administration of the CSHA. I trust that these matters will be given due consideration in budget planning.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate—

TAB.TAB: (a)notes the public release of the Industry Commission's report into public housing on 13 January 1994;
(b)recognises that the recommendations of the report will affect over one million low income households in Australia receiving housing assistance from the Commonwealth and State Governments;

(c)condemns the Minister for Housing, Local Government and Human Services (Mr Howe), the Minister for Social Security (Mr Baldwin) and the Assistant Treasurer (Mr Gear) who publicly acknowledge that the Federal Labor Government will not respond to the Industry Commission's recommendations until June 1994; and
(d)urges the Federal Labor Government to address the recommendations in the 1994 Federal Budget context.

SPEECH.PARA: This motion refers specifically to the Industry Commission's report on public housing, and I acknowledge Senator Margetts's general comments on the tabling of that document. My motion goes further. The second part `recognises that the recommendations of the report will affect over one million low income households in Australia'. The motion then condemns the Minister for Housing, Local Government and Human Services, Mr Brian Howe, the Minister for Social Security, Mr Baldwin, and the Assistant Treasurer, Mr Gear, for the action that they took in a joint press release at the time that this document was released. Their response was totally inadequate and certainly did not measure up to the fine principles, recommendations and findings of the report itself. In the fourth part of the motion I urge the federal Labor government to address the recommendations that have been made to it, rightly and properly, in the context of the 1994 federal budget.

PARA.TAB: The federal government to date has not given public housing the attention it deserves. I was appalled to read in the press release by the ministers for housing and social security and the Assistant Treasurer which accompanied the report that they publicly acknowledged that the federal Labor government would not respond to the Industry Commission's recommendations until June 1994. What a disgrace. Here is a statement that refers to a response that is going to come in June. I ask honourable senators to contemplate the reason for that. The budget this year is in May, so a month later the government will make a response.

It simply cannot be argued that the federal government needs more time to address the pressing problems of public housing in Australia. The Industry Commission report that was tabled in January follows on from an interim report that has been on the table since August last year. And now the government says mincingly, `Please give us a bit more time; let it flow to a month after the federal budget'. What a disgrace. This government has absolutely no ability to address the problems raised by the Industry Commission.

The areas that need to be addressed urgently by the government include: expenditure to promote and facilitate public housing; housing assistance to people in crisis; the supported accommodation assistance program and the crisis accommodation program; the funding to modify community housing to meet the special needs of people with disabilities; the housing problems facing Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people; the rent assistance measures for tenants in the private rental market so that, firstly, it declines as income increases and, secondly, is available to all low income tenants in the private rental market and, thirdly, is brought closer to rent rebates in the public housing sector.

The Australian people have a right to know what their elected government is going to provide in the form of housing assistance—and the government is going to totally walk away from this. We have total chaos and confusion. One only needs to look at the budget overview for the Department of Health, Housing, Local Government and Community Services that accompanied the 1993-94 federal budget. That overview properly recognises that in the area of housing the expenditure is in the order of $1.125 billion. That is over a billion dollars of expenditure.

A great proportion of that—probably about 90 per cent—is dedicated under the Commonwealth-state housing agreement which obviously needs radical review. That is addressed in one paragraph of that overview. On the following seven pages of the document we get all of the little petty cash items that the government wants to pick up and claim credit for. I stress, it is a review of the mortgage and rent assistance program. With export strategy, because the housing industry has been faltering in Australia, the government wants to expend some $0.8 million for us to be competitive internationally. It is an important construction initiative, but not one that I would have put down as the second most important priority.

Again, the government is going to provide the implementation of a housing choices strategy for older Australians—that is not addressing the fundamental problem. It is going to look at a national youth housing strategy for young people between the ages of 16 and 19 who, it claims, `obtain public housing at a rate disproportionately lower than any other age group', and where there is often a lack of consistency in the way they are treated by state housing authorities. The government wants to look at these 16- to 19-year-olds, not the fundamental issue of the family and how important it is. As I said, this confusion and chaos is constant.

The Industry Commission report, which is in two volumes, is an important document. It is concerned with accountability in the housing portfolio area. Concern is expressed—indeed, I would express concern—about the muscling in of the recommendations in this report between those that appeared first in the draft report last August and what has now appeared. There has been a shift in priorities. Very obviously ministers of the Crown, frightened that they will have to address some budget priorities and areas of accountability, have muscled in on the Industry Commission in the final report. These accountability recommendations have slipped seriously in the priority order. I wonder to what extent there has been subtle intervention by the ministers or departmental officers.
