I give notice that I will be pursuing that matter in the estimates.

The Auditor-General has also commented recently on this whole area of accountability. In Audit Report No. 1, 1993-94, volume 6, there are some important issues. They highlight the fact that after a decade of Labor, the administration and accountability of Commonwealth-state housing programs is still in question. The Industry Commission's suggestions on accountability come on top of this very damning Auditor-General's report. In his report, the Auditor-General found:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . there remains scope for further enhancement to the Agreement (CSHA) and the manner in which it is administered.

The Auditor-General's comments in the area of housing and planning drew attention to a range of issues and agreements between the Commonwealth and state governments that need addressing in the performance of Commonwealth-state housing agreements. We have had a decade of a federal Labor government. Thankfully, in the last couple of years we have seen the state Labor governments falling over, but very obviously leaving us with the particular problems that led the Auditor-General to raise the questions.

PARA.TAB: We now need to ask: where is housing in Australia after a decade of Labor? What rules, regulations and arrangements between Commonwealth and state ministers have been put in place? There is a paucity of results. Billions of dollars of Commonwealth money that has been injected into housing has not met the essential need. I was alarmed at the last round of Senate estimates when officers of the Department of Health, Housing, Local Government and Community Services came forward and admitted that they had not responded to the recommendations with any degree of urgency.

Let us look at the Industry Commission recommendations for the housing industry. As I said in my opening remarks, the recommendations will affect over one million low income households in Australia receiving housing assistance from the Commonwealth and state governments. There are genuine battling families living in cities, suburbs, towns, villages and communities throughout Australia. It is interesting to note that figure of one million low income earners and also to note the current unemployment figure in Australia of around one million. I wonder to what extent there is a comparability and compatibility between those two disaffected groups. Many of these families that I am referring to in the disaffected low income groups have a mother, a father, a brother, a sister or some other relative who is unemployed.

The Industry Commission's report is a critical indictment of existing housing arrangements and highlights the need for urgent action in some very specific areas. It is a shocking report card on Labor's housing record. The recession has adversely affected large sectors of the Australian community. What on earth has Labor been doing to correct this, seeing that it induced the recession?

Labor has deserted its own natural constituency in the area of underprivileged housing. The Industry Commission report acknowledges that many people have difficulty accessing appropriate and affordable housing, including people with disabilities, elderly people, young people, women and children escaping domestic violence and family breakdown, sole parents, Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people, and migrants. The fact that the Industry Commission reveals that many needy people have fallen outside the traditional safety nets and government spending priorities shows the compounding relationship between unemployment and housing needs and the fact that the Labor government has failed to meet those needs. We need to look carefully at the whole program objectives which link the relationship between the Commonwealth and state areas and how they link up with employment generation in regions of high unemployment.

It is interesting that the questions we asked at estimates recently showed us clearly that there were regions throughout Australia where the lack of housing and the high level of unemployment go hand in hand. A year after the program commenced the department was unable to adequately inform me of the number of houses built, the number of jobs created, where housing was located, and who in the Australian community benefited from the housing being built. There was $75 million brought forward from the Commonwealth-state housing agreement funds for this program in 1992-93, and although $52.6 million was spent in that year, another $22 million was carried over into 1993-94.

I can tell honourable senators what the Labor government has been doing in this area—it has been announcing review after review after review. I recently went through all of the budget papers and departmental documents in this area. It is fascinating. I have compiled a list of some three pages of reviews.

There is an Australian and urban task force review; a Local Government (Financial Assistance) Act review; support for local government developing regionally based strategies; long term unemployment reviews; local government approvals reviews; Green street program; indicative planning review; a review of residential regulations; a way of looking at ways of reducing the cost structure to the housing industry; a model code for residential development; the better cities program—we all know how that failed; the housing choices strategy; the urban-export strategy; the integrated local areas planning; the House of Representatives report on patterns of urban settlement; the taxation and financial policy impacts on urban settlement and urban transport; the mortgage and rent assistance program; the community housing program; the review of the crisis accommodation program; the government's response to the report we are talking about; research by the Australian Housing and Urban Research Institute; the National Advisory Committee on Housing and Urban Development; the national youth strategy; the youth social justice strategy; studies on domestic violence; the job placement and training program; JPET pilot projects; the national information program informing tenants and landlords in the private rental market of their rights and obligations; and the development of a written code and practice for real estate agents. That is where the government has seen its priorities in housing, yet nothing has flowed from any of that.

Ministers responding on behalf of the government did not address any of those particular issues. These urban review policies do absolutely nothing for the people living in high density public housing. They have been totally deserted. It was interesting to look at the recent result in the Werriwa by-election. During the campaign the Liberal candidate, Mr Charlie Lynn, was vehemently criticised by Labor Party politicians when he referred to Macquarie Fields housing commission area as a ghetto.

TALK.START.PARA: —Do you think it is?

—You need to carefully look at the result from the polling booth for that particular area in that by-election. The media reported that the people who lived in Macquarie Fields had waited for years for Labor to fix their housing needs and had returned a 16 per cent swing to the Liberal Party at that polling booth, which says a lot about references to a ghetto and Labor's urban housing policies.

PARA.TAB: Labor has no appropriate housing policies. Its policies of the past have not kept up with contemporary housing and demographic needs. All we get is another review from the champagne socialists who live in the better housing areas of the suburbs.

TALK.START.PARA: —Teak tables at the Lodge.

—As Senator Patterson rightly puts out, very expensive teak tables are put on the shopping list of the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet. The Industry Commission has acknowledged the failure of government to keep pace with the changing requirements of housing applicants. It is low income housing near employment and training opportunities that must be addressed. The Industry Commission acknowledged the need for greater efficiency from the public outlay of $2.5 billion in Commonwealth and state funds by re-jigging rental to reflect more accurately the income of tenants. The beneficiaries would be the genuinely needy tenants and the more than 200,000 would-be tenants on housing waiting lists around Australia—200,000 tenants who have not been accommodated by the government's policies.

PARA.TAB: Many people on low incomes who do not own their own homes and are unable to obtain public housing must either rent privately at high market rents or remain dependant on other family members. I had a constituency representation on that very issue today from my electorate in Darwin involving a tragic situation which brought home to me that particular problem.

People on low incomes who are not Department of Social Security clients may not be eligible for this important rent assistance. People with low incomes in many circumstances are spending in excess of 25 per cent of their income on private rental housing. Many people on low incomes are in a most unfortunate situation of living in continual financial crisis. That is having a catastrophic effect on Australian families.

The Commonwealth government decision to defer a response to this important report dealing with the directions for general housing assistance reform until June 1994—after the federal budget—just shows how much clout the current minister, Mr Howe, has in this area. He has admitted defeat before the ERC has even met. Obviously, Minister Howe is a man under siege. It is only a matter of time before Carmen Lawrence replaces him not only as Deputy Prime Minister, but also as the relevant housing minister in Australia.

I seriously doubt whether any of the recommendations of the Industry Commission's report on public housing will ever be implemented by a Labor government. It appears that they certainly will not be addressed with any degree of urgency in the 1994 budget. By the time the government responds to it—obviously some time later this year, after which we get into the subsequent 1995 budget round—this report will be closeted away, collecting dust on a bookshelf. The people we must be looking after are the people that I believe very rightly the Industry Commission has acknowledged as those in crisis. Dozens of excellent submissions were made, and dozens of recommendations and findings need to be addressed. All we get from this government is another series of reviews.

TALKER.NAME: Senator LEES
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats are always rather cautious not to be seen to be saying anything that might be construed as support for an Industry Commission report. However, in this particular case I believe that this report has been well done. It has not come out with the usual `privatise everything, and on anything that cannot be privatised limit government expenditure as much as possible'. The report is very thorough and well-considered, and I recommend it to anybody who is interested in public housing.

PARA.TAB: Senator Tambling's notice of motion refers to the effect of the IC report on over one million low income households in Australia. I certainly agree. Unfortunately, when we look at the Liberal Party's proposals, we wonder exactly where is its current policy. I remember that one of the planks in Fightback was to sell off large slabs, if not most, of the public housing stock. However, we have before us today a motion criticising the government's response to this Industry Commission report.

This report basically makes it clear that it is more cost-effective to provide low cost housing as well as housing assistance. Pleasingly for the Democrats, the idea of selling off stock has not been looked at as a serious or realistic option. The proposal for a voucher system for use in the private market also is not covered anywhere here as anything credible. I recommend that the Liberal Party looks very closely at many of these recommendations when formulating its policy.

This is a substantial report which has obviously taken quite a bit of time and shows a lot of effort and work. All honourable senators would be correct to complain if the government response to this very detailed and well thought out document had been rushed. This was put down only a month before Christmas. Looking at the time frame, it is unrealistic to expect a full and considered response to this report in such a short time.

Indeed, upon making the report public, the Minister for Housing, Local Government and Human Services, Mr Howe, said that he would begin immediate consultations with the states to develop a new administrative regime in response to the areas of concern outlined in the report. On checking what stage this consultation process was at, I find that the first of these meetings took place in Adelaide two days ago. I am advised that a series of meetings will take place this month and that the report is the key item on the agenda for the ministerial council meeting at the end of February.

Senator Tambling basically implied in his speech that it is somehow negligent of the minister not to respond before this year's budget. However, the existing Commonwealth-state housing agreement means that the housing funding is basically locked into this year's budget. I wonder whether Senator Tambling is suggesting that the Commonwealth should breach the agreement with the states to achieve whatever it is that we are looking for. Surely we should be looking ahead to getting a full and considered response in a new housing agreement which has to be drawn up in the subsequent year.

The areas of concern raised by the commission's report were: tenancy management; housing allocation; rent setting; asset management; and accountability of the states in their administration of Commonwealth moneys. All of these need detailed and thorough consideration. These are all issues for a new Commonwealth-state agreement. Surely it is better for the minister to develop a thorough, new package rather than make an ad hoc response and patch up or in some way alter the current agreement.

When we look at Senator Tambling's press material, there is an inherent confusion about housing policy. The need for public housing will not go away whatever we do with first home buyer schemes or access to superannuation for people who are looking to buy their first home. In the real world, people without superannuation still need homes, and the private rental market is closed to many Australians. The need to stimulate growth in the economy at large by encouraging home ownership is a separate issue from the need for public housing. Indeed, we could just as well argue that, by stimulating the public housing sector, we would also stimulate the economy.

It is far and away the preferred option for the Democrats to put a large amount of money into public housing and in that way provide jobs right across Australia. When we compare the forms of assistance the government could offer to help people meet the need for shelter, the provision of public housing, according to the Industry Commission, overall ranks the highest in terms of accessibility, affordability, appropriateness, security of tenure and equity. The Democrats have always believed that provision of public housing of an adequate standard is the way to go for those who are not able to provide shelter for themselves. Indeed, it is a responsibility of government to ensure that its citizens are adequately housed.

The report has commended the management of public housing in Australia in some respects and made recommendations for improvements in others. Nowhere in this report do I find wholesale condemnation of the government's policy direction. Yes, there are many problems, some of which Senator Tambling outlined, but this report does not condemn, as he did, the general policy direction. I would prefer the government to make refinements to its existing service delivery and accountability, as suggested by the report, in a considered way, rather than rush in. It is eminently sensible to put more money into public housing under the present structure than to pull that structure apart when we have a housing agreement already in place with the states.

Senator Tambling has overlooked another point in relation to this issue. It is the standard practice for there to be around about six months for a response to an Industry Commission report—certainly one of this size. The government's response will be accepted in roughly this time frame. The Democrats expect a considered and thorough response from government before the end of June. In the meantime, I commend the report to members of the opposition. I hope they will read it thoroughly and use it to correct their housing policy.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOLKUS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Multicultural Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I also wish to speak on Senator Tambling's motion. Picking up on the points made by Senator Lees, we have seen an enormous waste of time this afternoon. We expect that from the opposition, but this has to take the Logie—the big one. We are talking about a report that was tabled some three weeks ago. Senator Tambling is calling on immediate action to respond to that report. Fourteen days, 20 days or whatever is not a long time, particularly when we are talking about issues such as this. Senator Tambling could very easily have given a much more considered response. He could have spent more time considering it. Had he done that he would not have made those basic mistakes that Senator Lees talked about.

PARA.TAB: This is very much a fraudulent, knee-jerk response to this Industry Commission report—a report that does deserve much more consideration. This response is from an opposition which less than a year ago was going to the electorate with a policy on housing. It was a policy that, despite the crocodile tears here this evening, promised the Australian electorate a huge cutback in the area of public housing. The policy promised $450 million under the Fightback cutback proposal.

What sort of moral authority do members of the opposition think they have to cry crocodile tears within 12 months in such a snap response to a very detailed report? What we are seeing again, and what we have seen consistently since the last election, is an opposition which has not been prepared to do the hard work—before or since the election. The opposition consists of a bunch of amateurs. No matter how many of them are on the front bench, it will not raise the quality of the output. Within two weeks of the report coming down they are claiming instant responses and moral authority, when they wanted to cut away per capita housing through the Commonwealth-states agreement. What do they think a cut of $450 million would have done to the people of the Northern Territory or Werriwa, or to people on low incomes?

No-one expects consistency from Senator Tambling, nor from the rest of the opposition. We on this side of parliament do not mind that, because the more that happens, the more likely we are to keep winning elections. We thank the opposition for the last five elections. What really stinks of hypocrisy is that those opposite, time and time again—particularly in this place—are screaming, wailing and crowing about states' rights. When we look at and analyse this report, what we see as the most basic, fundamental structure that the Industry Commission tries to tackle and analyse is state-federal responsibilities; their clarity and transparency, and the need for more transparency.

What do those opposite want us to do? They want us to come up with a response instantaneously, without consultation with state authorities. We have responded. Those ministers cited by Senator Tambling in his motion did respond, but they have responded in a more concrete way. That is unlike the simplistic approach to life and politics taken by Senator Tambling—particularly his approach to policies.

The minister responsible for this area has already moved quickly to establish processes for consultation with the state ministers. Arrangements with the states are in place already. Particularly under Senator Tambling's creed of politics there cannot be a unilateral decision to dump the states without consultation. The minister has organised consultations with state ministers. Bilateral discussions between the Minister for Housing, Local Government and Human Services (Mr Howe) and his state counterparts will be held in mid-February. Housing ministers are to meet in late February to discuss the Industry Commission report.

There is a lot I could say but I will not, given the time of day and the need to proceed to other business, but Senator Tambling has moved his motion without moral authority. He is critical of the federal government's response and, more particularly, he is critical of our record.

There is one thing that the Industry Commission did do. This point was endorsed by Senator Lees but, unfortunately, in Senator Tambling's rush to read this report he must have missed the vital paragraph. I do not know why the opposition keeps some of those opposite on the front bench. In terms of talent they are not producing much.

The opposition talks about rent assistance. Once again we think back to 12 months ago, when it was the opposition leader—the departing leader, Dr Hewson—who talked of people renting houses as being second-class citizens. That was the policy the opposition went to the last elections with. The opposition today is crying about those who may have to rent houses.

The government has a record that, in bald terms, is reflected in the fact that we have increased total expenditure during our term of government from $500 million to over $1 billion in 1992-93. We have put in place agreements with the states to continue funding. It is a policy which, between March 1983 and September 1993, increased in real terms by 139 per cent assistance for eligible families with three or more children—from $10 a week to $42.60. We have committed funds, put in resources and worked with the states. We have had the reviews and we read the results. More importantly, we produce the funds to accommodate the need, unlike the policy of those opposite which, at the last election, was very clear: do away with federal government support for public housing.

The Industry Commission's report, to the extent that it endorses anything, endorses the need for a mix of housing; a mix in terms of publicly owned housing and rental assistance. What the opposition's policy was then, and I do not know what it is now—we would all be surprised to hear what it is now—was to wipe the slate of one particular and important part of housing assistance; that is, public housing finance—$450 million less. That is the type of policy the opposition put up at the last election.

We have to go by that because there has not been a change, despite the endeavours of the opposition leader in this place to develop a policy think tank. There has not been a substantial addressing of these issues. The opposition criticises us for not giving sufficient import to these issues. It is not just the arrangements with the states that are important; but the fundamental issues that the commission raises, such as the transparency of funding arrangements and the greater clarity, objectives and responsibilities of both Commonwealth and state governments.

TALK.START.PARA: —What did the Auditor-General say about you?

—The Auditor-General is not the electorate. What the electorate said about us last year was quite different from what it said about the opposition. The opposition has candidates running around this country. I was in Werriwa just a week before the election. I did not see a ghetto; I saw a lot of concerned people. The end result in Werriwa was one of the lowest swings away from a government. Everyone in the electorate knows that last year was not a good year for us in terms of some of the issues we had to confront, but it was not a good year for Dr Hewson either. That is the bottom line for all members of the opposition sitting on the front bench, because Dr Hewson's time is limited and the time of those sitting on the front bench is limited. It is limited because the opposition cannot grasp the issues.

PARA.TAB: The Industry Commission made assessments and put up proposals to look at the clear and full cost benefits of various tenures, the best levels and mix of assistance measures, and so on. What is important is that we have processes in place that have been agreed to with the states. These are the sorts of processes and issues that the opposition is not addressing.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Patterson Sen K.C.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support Senator Tambling's motion relating to the Industry Commission's recently released report into public housing. I welcome the opportunity to do so for a number of reasons but most particularly because I found the response of the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs, Senator Bolkus, to Senator Tambling's speech just stunning.

PARA.TAB: Minister Bolkus had the hide to call the coalition hypocrites! I cannot believe that he had gall to do that, given that the government told pensioners that they would be taken out of the tax system by 1995, then five days after the election, the former Treasurer, Mr Dawkins, said that that was some sort of a typo and that it was not right. The government had the temerity to tell people that there would be no increase in taxes, and then only yesterday we saw an increase in the tax on leaded and unleaded petrol. That was after the government had gone round the traps telling everyone that the coalition was going to do terrible things. After telling us that there would be no increases in taxes, the government increased the wholesale sales tax. For the minister to stand on that side of the chamber and call us hypocrites is simply astounding, but then nothing about the Labor government should astound us.

As shadow minister for senior citizens and aged care and shadow minister assisting the Leader of the Opposition on women's affairs, I am concerned by the fact that the government has not seen fit to respond to this important report in the 1994-95 budget election. It seems that whenever there is an issue that comes up or report that is tabled we are to be told that it will not be dealt with in the new budget because it is being brought down earlier. That should have been taken into account when the cabinet decided to have an early budget.

A draft report was tabled in August of 1993. Yet Senator Lees—a member of the fifth faction of the Labor Party, the Australian Democrats—says, `Look, it is very difficult for the government to take the report into account in this budget because it has only just been brought down'. In fact, the government cannot respond because it already has agreements in place with the states. As early as August, the government was in receipt of a draft report that was very much along the lines of the final report. So Senator Lees' argument holds little if any water.

The sort of tardiness that the government is demonstrating in its response to this report—it knew what was going to happen because it already had the draft report—is not confined to this matter. The coalition is appalled by the apparent lack of political will demonstrated by some of the Labor ministers in responding to the shameful human rights abuses so lucidly highlighted in Commissioner Burdekin's recent report into mental illness. But we have heard nothing from Mr Howe. The silence is deafening.

There has been no response to what is happening to women postnatally; no response to what is happening to young people with schizophrenia; no response to what is happening to people with Alzheimer's disease; no response to what is happening to people with dementia; and no response to what is happening to the number of people who are homeless as a result of the policy of de-institutionalisation of former Labor governments. We have heard nothing from Mr Howe on that report—not a thing. It is increasingly apparent that Labor's so-called commitment to social justice is predicated on ensuring its own electoral successes rather than improving the lot of Australia's one million-plus low income households.

Issues relating to housing that affect older Australians are somewhat different from those that affect younger Australians. The majority of older people own their own homes. Often they own them outright—free of debt. For many retired people their home is a source of significant emotional attachment and, given this government's policies, reliability. It is one asset that does not seem to change. Their shares are now being assessed as capital gains for income assessment purposes so the family home is regarded as an asset that is at least secure. For many of these retired people the family home is their first and only home. It is where they have raised their families; it is the source of many happy memories. But at the same time, a family home can become a burden in retirement. It may be too big and too costly to maintain, or inappropriately designed or located for individual health and personal care needs. As a person or a couple gets older this burden inevitably increases.

At a time when our population is ageing—a fact highlighted in the EPAC report released earlier this week—our challenge is to adopt policies that facilitate the development of sufficient appropriate housing choices for older Australians. While that is a responsibility of both state and federal governments, state governments in particular should be encouraging flexibility in housing regulations so that older people have some flexibility in the way their house is used, especially over a limited period so that they could have people living with them or assisting them. But that is a matter of concern for the states.

The Deputy Prime Minister has frequently highlighted the deleterious effects of urban sprawl. In fact, from shadowing his portfolio, I think housing is his only interest. To ask him about other issues, such as aged care and disability services, one would think that he hardly knew about them. He has talked about the urban sprawl—not for one moment do I suggest that the problems that he highlights are not real—but two points need to be made.

First, this government has a lot to answer for because of the recession that we had to have and the high interest rates that followed. The high interest rate policy of the then Treasurer and the now, unfortunately, Prime Minister Keating—I am sure that there are one or two people on the other side who lost out in the recent reshuffle who think it is unfortunate that Keating—
The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Calvert)—I think you have to address the Prime Minister by his correct title.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will refer to him as Prime Minister Keating because, unfortunately, the rules of this chamber require me to do so but I would prefer not to. Thank you, Mr Acting Deputy President, for pointing that out to me because I had made a slip. The high interest rate policies that resulted in record high mortgage rates forced young families to move out into satellite suburbs—miles from the metropolitan areas, long miles away from their families, support systems and extended families, and miles away from their work places, which involved long distances to travel—to find a house that they could afford.

PARA.TAB: Secondly, it has always been my philosophy that it should be the people themselves and not the government who decide where and in what sort of accommodation they live. For many older Australians their housing choice must by necessity be far more than mere bricks and mortar. In times gone by some aged care planners referred to a continuum whereby older people moved from a home to a retirement village, supported accommodation unit or hostel and then to a nursing home and possibly finally to an acute hospital bed.

It is doubtful whether that continuum ever existed. It is certainly true that it does not exist today and it is less likely to exist in the future. As the needs of older people increase, they may opt for an accommodation choice more appropriate to their needs. They do not necessarily move along the continuum that I described. Most often they move only once or possibly twice.

Mr Noel Howard from the highly successful Illawarra Retirement Trust refers to `taking care to people' rather than `taking people to care'. This is the way of the future in terms of ensuring appropriate housing choices for older people. Not only does it maximise older people's independence and reduce the number of upheavals that they must endure, but it is also financially far more efficient for government.

Unfortunately, if there is one part of the aged care program that is badly in need of reform, it is the home and community care program. While there has been a major increase in funding for HACC since its inception in 1985, less than half of the target population benefits from that program. In spite of this massive unmet demand, Labor has seen fit to reduce the real rate of increase in HACC funding in each of its last two budgets. We have an EPAC report that shows us that the number of older people in Australia is increasing, and yet in the last two years Labor has seen fit to decrease the real rate of HACC funding. The inevitable result of that lack of HACC funding is early admission to residential care, with an accompanying loss of independence for older people and significantly higher costs for government.

Many of the problems with HACC stem from the fact that it traverses all three tiers of government, resulting in duplication, unnecessary administrative overheads and major differences in service provision both between and within states and regions. The key to reforming HACC lies in putting Commonwealth-state relations back on the political agenda. They were taken off the agenda by Mr Keating when he was elected by his party because he believed the initiative belonged to Mr Hawke. Unfortunately, as the Queensland Premier has pointed out, the likelihood of it coming back onto the agenda is remote under the current Prime Minister.

While most older people own their own homes, ensuring some degree of financial security in their retirement, I cannot let this opportunity pass without referring to a group that is often forgotten by government and society. I refer to older people who are either totally homeless or who live permanently in boarding houses—in particular those who live in boarding houses around the edges of some of our inner city areas. Those people are being affected by the regentrification of those areas.

In his mental illness report, Burdekin points out that large numbers of Australians affected by mental illness live in boarding houses and that living conditions in many of these establishments are nothing short of disgraceful. Older people make up a large proportion of these residents. These older people often have no family—if they do have family, they have separated themselves from that family or have been separated many times because of their mental illness—friends or support base. If they were not in a boarding house, they would be on the street or on the park bench.

While considerable effort and money have rightly been put into solving the problems of youth homelessness, society has largely forgotten our older homeless. We must ask why. It is only the tremendous work of voluntary agencies that allows these most disadvantaged members of our society to maintain at least some basic level of dignity.

A thought just crossed my mind while I was thinking about that. It sticks in my throat that Senator Bolkus said that we were hypocritical. Talk about hypocrisy! On 11 December 1992 Mr Keating announced on the Sunday program that he was going to match dollar for dollar moneys raised by the charities over the Christmas appeal. When the representatives of the charities went to sign the fine print, they found that it was dollar for dollar raised and spent during the Christmas period. One charity that would have got $8 million on the first understanding got $5 million when it came to look at the fine print.

What did charities get last Christmas? A big fat zilch—nothing. Why? There were the same number of people unemployed and the same number of people in difficult straits. There was an increase in long-term unemployed and a development in what people keep talking about as the underclass. Agencies were telling us that more and more people were coming to them for help. What had changed? The answer is that there was not an election coming up early in 1994. That is what had changed. It is hypocritical. Senator Bolkus has the hide to stand on that side of the chamber and call us hypocritical. He should look at his own policies and his own party's behaviour before he criticises ours.

As I was saying, those voluntary organisations go on regardless of the hypocrisy of the current government. I wonder what they think about the next Industry Commission report that is being commissioned to investigate voluntary organisations. I am interested to know how they feel about having to participate in that. I am sure that will be an interesting exercise.

Those voluntary agencies do an enormous amount of work, but is it good enough that the government leaves it just to them? If this government is really serious about social justice, it should remember that it has a responsibility not only to respond to the valid concerns of lobby groups but also to go in to bat for those who have no advocates and no political voice. They do not have people who come to Canberra and lobby for them. This hypocritical government is not concerned about them. Minister Howe does not look as though he is going to give a reply to Mr Burdekin, who pointed out that this is an area where urgent action is required, especially for older homeless people who have a psychiatric disturbance.

One important feature of the report is the highlighting of the difficulty that many women and children have in gaining access to appropriate and affordable accommodation when escaping domestic violence. The report states:

SPEECH.PARA: Women escaping domestic violence can have difficulty finding refuges and shelters that accommodate children, in particular teenage boys.

The commission acknowledges with some concern that the demand for emergency accommodation has currently outstripped the capacity of current programs to provide it. The report states that because there is a lack of medium to long-term public housing many women are staying in supported accommodation assistance program facilities and crisis accommodation program facilities indefinitely. This is eroding the benefits initially achieved by the government's emergency accommodation programs in providing people who are homeless or in crisis with immediate housing assistance. Those facilities are being used by people on a longer term basis and they are not there for those people with immediate housing problems.

PARA.TAB: In a lot of ways it is ironic that this report deals with issues such as crisis accommodation for women. I do not know whether Mrs Kelly, the new minister for women's affairs, would be particularly aware of this. She is too busy covering her back, her front, her sides and every other flank to try to cover up what she was doing dishing out $30 million without any records or any information based on oral discussions with her staff. Somehow she and her staff have lost their memories about what they have done with a couple of thousand applications. She is busy doing that while women, l suppose, will languish.

Fifty per cent of the supported accommodation assistance program clients are women and over a third are children accompanying a parent. Many women and children are suffering as a result of the current demands being placed on the supported accommodation assistance program and crisis accommodation program facilities because of the lack of affordable medium- to long-term accommodation.

In the report some attention is given to the need to streamline the assessment procedures relating to the supported accommodation assistance program and the crisis accommodation program funding. Honourable senators will recall that the SAP program principally funds charitable organisations and community groups to provide supported accommodation for people who are homeless or in crisis. The crisis accommodation program, CAP, provides capital funding for crisis and supported accommodation housing. While both SAP and CAP are joint Commonwealth-state programs administered by state governments, the requirement for both levels of government to be involved in assessing and approving applications for funding is causing delays and is unnecessarily adding to the cost of assistance.

Another example is that on the one hand we have HACC and on the other hand we have the SAP and the CAP programs, both of which are suffering because of problems with state-federal relations. Again this is an issue that Mr Keating dropped because it was Mr Hawke's baby. Mr Keating could not be associated with that in any way because it might have reflected on Mr Hawke's achievements, so he dropped it. Yet another problem goes unresolved because of Mr Keating's ego and his inability to deal with the fact that his predecessor might have been on the right track.

It has also been noted that the involvement of various government departments and community groups in the provision of support and accommodation means that there has been little pressure on the public housing authorities to house people with special needs. One of the report's recommendations is that the supported accommodation assistance program and the crisis accommodation program should be combined and come under the control of the supported assistance accommodation program manager, with a discretion to allocate funds for capital or recurrent purposes. This recommendation is worthy of consideration. I wondered whether Senator Lees actually read the report because she concentrated just on the housing issue in that very specific and narrow sense. When we go through the report, we find that it really deals with a very broad range of issues relating to housing.

On page 129, the report outlines concerns that were expressed by homeless women interviewed by the commission. They expressed concern not only about access to refuges and shelters, but also about their ability to pay the rents demanded in private rentals for appropriate accommodation and the difficulties in accessing public housing. The report states:

SPEECH.PARA: Other issues of concern included discrimination, the lack of information on housing for people in crisis, and the stigma attached to being a homeless woman with children.
The report also states:
Homelessness amongst young people is exacerbated where young people, particularly young girls, are afraid to seek assistance at mixed refuges and shelters because their safety may be in jeopardy.

Some attention is also given in the report for the need to address the disparity between the amount of rent assistance received by private renters and that of public renters on similar incomes. While rent assistance is largely determined by the level of rent paid by the household, public housing rebates are calculated on the level of income the household receives. This means that the levels of assistance paid to private renters is much less than the rental rebate to public renters on similar incomes. This is another issue that could have been addressed in this budget; it is not an issue that has to be addressed between state and federal relationships. It was a very myopic approach taken by Senator Lees and Senator Bolkus. These are issues that the government can address in this budget. If the government had the will, it could address these issues. But it is obvious that the government does not have the will. It is not responding to this issue, and Mr Howe is not responding to Burdekin.

PARA.TAB: The commission has recommended that the Commonwealth government should change rent assistance to tenants in the private rental market so that it is brought closer to rent rebates in the public housing sector. If this recommendation were to be taken up it would greatly benefit low income women, particularly those women who are sole parents. Not only would it be more equitable but it would enable many women to have greater flexibility and mobility to find employment. It would not only enable them to be located close to employment, but also enable them to be relocated close to their extended families from whom they could receive assistance. Such a measure would give low income women more control over their lives. But, as I said, I do not think this will be a primary concern of Mrs Kelly at the moment.

I would love to have Mrs Kelly in this chamber and to ask her a few questions about this industry report. I think she would find it as difficult to answer these questions as she finds answering the questions on the sports rorts. My greatest sadness is that she now has the women's portfolio. While she continues to stonewall on the sports rorts affair, women's affairs will not be attended to appropriately. That area will be neglected because she will be too busy worrying about the sports rorts and saving her own skin.

In conclusion, I urge the government to consider this important report in its current budget deliberations. There may be state-federal issues—there should not be because the government had a draft report—that have to be addressed. But there are issues that do not have state-federal problems associated with them that can be addressed. The fact that this year's budget will be brought down earlier than in previous years is of no relevance to Australia's thousands of homeless people. They simply want a roof over their heads. If no action is taken in this year's budget, then it will be late 1995 before they, and the tens of thousands of other Australians who find themselves in inappropriate or unaffordable accommodation, receive any relief. I suppose it will be just in time for the next election.

I also urge the Labor government not to continue along its apparent current path of winding back the much needed reforms to Commonwealth-state financial relations as they apply to public housing and home and community care. The irony is that we heard recently of how Mr Keating wields his power to accelerate the placing of prints in the cabinet room, yet he does not have the same will to use his power to accelerate putting people in housing.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply—This has been an interesting debate. I think it highlights the points that both Senator Patterson and I have made that complement and bring out those issues that the Industry Commission properly addressed. I was interested to note the comments of Senator Margetts on the report prior to this debate. They were of a similar nature. Whilst Senator Margetts has not participated in this debate, I note that she supported the thrust of our motion, particularly that the government should address the fundamental recommendations of the report in this year's budget. I trust, therefore, that the Green senators will be consistent and will support this motion when it comes to a vote in this chamber. It will be a test for the Greens to be consistent with the comments that they made.

PARA.TAB: Senator Lees contributed on behalf of the Australian Democrats and has indicated that the Democrats will not be supporting the motion. I am disappointed; in fact, I am disgusted at that stance by the Australian Democrats. It just highlights a number of the issues, as Senator Patterson has pointed out, where the Democrats have missed the main game. Senator Lees threw a couple of questions that I will address. She asked whether we want to break the existing Commonwealth-state housing agreement which is already in place. Frankly, I am appalled that the Australian Democrats feel that taxpayers' money, all $1 billion per year, should not be properly accounted for in the Commonwealth-state housing agreement. This is particularly so in light of the fact that if the Democrats had been doing their homework and studying what was going on, if they had addressed what the Auditor-General had previously reported to this chamber and if they had addressed the issues of last August, when this issue was before the chamber in the draft report they would well have been aware that all state ministers have been taking a close interest in this issue. The consequences that flow from the questions that were asked in the 1993 estimates should also have been before the attention of the Australian Democrats. Senator Lees acknowledged that the ministerial council was meeting later this month on this matter. I would have thought that the accountability mechanisms would have been discussed and put in place prior to the budget.

That leads me to the conclusion that the Australian Democrats and the Labor Party have already reached a compromised accord on the 1994 budget. Senator Lees and the Democrats are therefore already intimidated by the commitment that they have given the government for the May budget. Senator Lees is not prepared to come in here and argue the issues that affect young Australians, elderly Australians, disabled Australians or Aboriginal Australians in the area of housing need and housing priority; she is prepared to walk away from that because a cushy deal has already been done—it has been cooked up in the corner—between the Australian Democrats and the government on this budget. The government has changed the parameters of that Commonwealth-state housing agreement, including the funding arrangements. I fail to see why the Industry Commission recommendations cannot be addressed in the time frame that is before this chamber.

Senator Lees also asked a question relating to the coalition's policies at the last election on the possible sale of public housing. I ask the Australian Democrats to consider very carefully what would be the consequences of selling some old public housing stock in which inappropriate people are currently enjoying the tenancies. This would release considerable capital that could be reinjected into the community for low income, needy tenants—for the 200,000 I mentioned who are sitting around on waiting lists. The government and the Democrats are just afraid that all of this will be too much like hard work before the May 1994 budget.

Senator Lees has implied that she supports the thrust of the Industry Commission's report. However, with over 200,000 people on waiting lists in this country not able to access public housing or rent assistance, I would have thought that these low income Australians in need of housing would have been the very people the Australian Democrats wanted to assist immediately. Under the government and Democrat plan, these people will have to wait until May 1995 or perhaps later—some 15 months away—for housing rental assistance as proposed by the Industry Commission report. How does Senator Lees explain that to the struggling families living throughout Australia in our cities, towns and villages?

Senator Bolkus made a six-minute response on behalf of the government, basically attacking Liberal and National party policies and claiming they were hypocritical. He had an absolute paucity of argument. He had no informed response to the Industry Commission report that was before us. Whilst he raised the issues of the transparency and the accountability mechanisms that need to be addressed, he did not come up with any solutions. Is that not admirable? The Labor government hands over $1 billion of taxpayers' money to the states with insufficient accountability mechanisms in place and really does not care at all whether the money is spent on housing for Australians who need housing. How ridiculous!

We need to look very carefully, in light of what has been put forward, at the issues that later this month are to be presented by this government to the state housing ministers. These issues were raised by the Auditor-General last year. I note that it now looks as though two financial years will pass before the accountability in the housing program will be addressed—and this by a federal Labor government!

The minister had the absolute gall to speak about Labor's grant in the public housing area. He gloated over the fact that over 10 years of Labor government public housing expenditure had doubled from $500 million to $1 billion per annum. What he neglected to tell the Senate was that in 10 years of Labor government the housing waiting list doubled. That is right—it doubled. Let me give honourable senators the figures. In 1983 when the Labor government came to office there were 125,570 people on that waiting list. In 1992 the figure was 216,339—and the Labor Party and Senator Bolkus call that social justice.

Senator Bolkus had the hypocrisy to say that the Liberal and National parties failed young people. I would ask him to consider that young people today are the first home buyers of tomorrow. I proudly stand here and say that I want as many people as possible to take up their first home buying options, whether through the right to use superannuation funds or whether through the right to use other financial issues that we put forward. I want disabled people and Aboriginal people to have the right to decent housing.

I note that in the response to this Industry Commission report, the only issue that the Labor government has addressed is the Industry Commission's recommendations with regard to funding of Aboriginal housing, which it has knocked back. It put them to one side. It said, `This is the issue that we will make a decision on. We are not going to do anything; we are going to leave the present system in place'. Yet, it has told everyone else in the community, `You must wait until 1995'. I urge the Senate to support the motion.
Question put:
That the motion (Senator Tambling's) be agreed to:
Question so resolved in the negative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate—

TAB.TAB: (a)condemns the Government for its divisive approach to Australia's national symbols and, in particular, its abolition of the oath and affirmation of allegiance required of new citizens;

(b)whilst recognising that the new so-called pledge of commitment is now law, despite strong Coalition opposition to the change, sympathises with those local government councils which have expressed anger at being required to use the pledge in citizenship ceremonies;

(c)criticises the Government for its failure to include the pledge and preamble in the current review of the Australian Citizenship Act 1948 by the Joint Standing Committee on Migration, even though these are crucial and important symbolic parts of the Act; and
(d)urges the Government, it if wishes the review of the Act to be taken seriously, as the occasion demands, to include consideration of the pledge and the preamble.

SPEECH.PARA: This motion condemns the Keating government for its divisive approach to Australia's national symbols, including in particular its abolition of the oath and affirmation of allegiance required of new citizens. The motion also criticises the government for excluding consideration of the new preamble and pledge of commitment contained in the Australian Citizenship Act from the forthcoming review of that act by the Joint Standing Committee on Migration. It urges the government to change its mind on this point.

PARA.TAB: A nation's symbols and institutions are of fundamental importance to its stability, good governance and sovereign independence and to the wellbeing of its people. As the great 19th century British statesman Benjamin Disraeli said more than a century ago:

SPEECH.PARA: Individualities may form communities, but it is institutions alone that can create a nation.
I am sure that Disraeli also included a nation's symbols, in particular its flag, in this profound sentiment. As that great US President Woodrow Wilson said many years ago:

The things that the flag stands for were created by the experiences of a great people. Everything that it stands for has been written by our lives. The flag is the embodiment, not of sentiment, but of history.

TALK.START.PARA: —He was talking about a truly independent America.

—The 13 stripes on the flag, the Stars and Stripes, as Senator Schacht may be aware, stand for the 13 original British colonies that became the 13 original states of the United States. Such insights as that from great leaders around the world, however, are of course beyond the vision of Prime Minister Keating.

PARA.TAB: On the contrary, Prime Minister Keating and his Labor government, like no other government in Australia's history, have sought deliberately to denigrate and pull down Australia's national symbols. In doing so, he has fuelled divisions within our nation which runs the risk of very serious long-term damage. Of Mr Keating one can say no more than that he is a highly divisive leader who has been prepared to ditch Australian traditions and institutions to suit his own political ends. He is a wrecker of Australia's institutions and symbols. He is prepared to pull them down without—

TALK.START.PARA: —Did you go to the Australia Day ceremony on the 26th? Were you there?
—What are you going on about?

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Calvert)—Order! Senator Schacht, if you want to speak on this matter you will have plenty of opportunity.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, he can speak later on. Every Australian knows—perhaps every Australian except Senator Schacht—that this Prime Minister is prepared to tear down fundamental institutions and symbols like the Australian flag just to justify and satisfy his own short-term political ends. He wants to impose a Labor party legacy on our institutions and our symbols. They ought to be beyond petty party politics. They ought to be of a nature which is supported by the whole of this nation because national symbols are part of a nation's character, heritage and pride.

PARA.TAB: I was reminded of the importance of those basic symbols of ours when I visited the provisional Parliament House with my colleague Senator Rod Kemp. I found two very stark and contrasting examples in the exhibitions currently being held there. The first of those exhibitions was of the flags of Australia. It was an excellent exhibition because it presented fully the history of the flag. It presented the options, the alternatives, for looking at the future of that great and fundamental symbol.

The second exhibition was called Landmark. That exhibition was supposed to reflect the relations between the land, its people and politics. It concentrated on three elements. It concentrated on Mabo, it concentrated on the Franklin Dam debate of a decade ago, and it also dealt with Australia's immigration. I was really very saddened to see the very biased approach to all of those issues that that exhibition took. In my own area of immigration, it had Al Grassby as the pinnacle of Australian immigration policy-making. The exhibition made no reference at all to the fact that it was the Liberal governments under Menzies that, progressively through the 1950s and 1960s, produced an enlightened immigration policy which led to the abolition of the white Australia policy.

It was the Menzies Liberal-National governments of those periods that provided an immigration program which formed the great basis for much of the development of our nation. None of that was included in that exhibition. I must say I found that not only surprising but a matter of great concern, and it ought to be of great concern to all of us.

One should reasonably expect that a person of no less eminence and stature in this country than the Australian Prime Minister, the highest elected official in the country, should uphold and promote our national symbols with honour, pride, commitment and resolution. On the contrary, Mr Keating has had a go at just about every national symbol. He has undertaken a persistent, venomous and divisive attack, supported and encouraged by his left wing colleagues, various un-Australian vested interests and apologists, including, in particular, Senator Schacht and Senator Faulkner, who has temporarily joined our side, and supported by a group of downright un-Australian activists and interest groups. If one is going to play with the nation's symbols and institutions, one is playing with the very core and basis of what this nation has been built on.

Not only is this approach a monstrous attempt to rewrite our history, but it also sucks the confidence and vitality of our people. One of the most shameful of these assaults has been the Prime Minister's denigration of our number one national symbol, the Australian flag. He has denigrated it not just in Australia but around the world. He ignores public opinion which overwhelmingly takes pride and honour in our flag, a flag under which Australians have fought and died in order to defend that which it represents—that is, a free, federated nation under the Southern Cross, built on our rich heritage from our founding fathers from Great Britain.

Mr Keating has taken that denigration around the world. He did it in Indonesia, in one of his first fleeting visits when he tried to discover Asia in his early days as Prime Minister. With regard to Mr Keating taking Australia into Asia, he is an absolute novice; he is a Johnny-come-lately. He said in Jakarta in 1992—several months after he became Prime Minister:

SPEECH.PARA: I'm sure that in this part of the world, people do wonder about Australians representing themselves with a British flag in the corner of our flag. That must change and it should change because Australia should respect itself as a country of independent minds and spirits.

At about the same time—indeed, on the same tour—he said to a group of school children in Papua New Guinea who were waving the Australian flag on the occasion of the 50th anniversary of the Kokoda Trail, `I see you've got an Australian flag, have you? Well, I'll get you a new one soon'. I have yet to hear of any other national leader in any other country of the world who grovelled and denigrated his nation's prime national symbol in overseas visits in the way that Prime Minister Keating did on that occasion. Not only did he do that, but at an Anzac Day ceremony just two years ago, when the national president of the Australian RSL, Alf Garland, wanted to present him with a small Australian flag, he gave it back to him and said, `No good giving it to me, give it back to one of your Pommy mates'.

PARA.TAB: That is a quote which has never been denied by this Prime Minister. It shows that the Prime Minister's motivation in terms of his attack on our institutions and our symbols is not done on the basis of wanting to assert Australia's independence. Everyone in the world, including everyone in Asia, knows that we are a totally independent nation and we have been for many decades. What it concerns is a deep-felt hatred of anything English. That is what motivates this Prime Minister in terms of our institutions, in particular the flag and in particular the republican debate. He seems to imply there is a subservience somehow or other by Australia to Britain because of those institutions and symbols.

I well recall, and I am sure my colleagues well recall, it was in the 1950s and 1960s that Mr Keating and his party were waxing long and loud on our so-called subservience to America. It had nothing to do with Britain; at that stage it was America. When he has a problem he picks a diversion and does it in a way that is deeply offensive to most Australians and, most importantly, in the longer term, is deeply damaging to the whole fabric and fibre of our society. It is a tragedy that this Prime Minister does not realise that.

With regard to this area of denigration of basic institutions and symbols in Australia, of recent interest directly to my portfolio of immigration and citizenship has been the unwarranted, party-politically motivated abolition of the Australian oath of allegiance for citizenship ceremonies. That move did not have widespread community support. There was no extensive community consultation on it. It was simply part of the Labor Party's divisive republican agenda.

TALK.START.PARA: —Did you go to the Australia Day ceremony on 26 January?
—Senator Schacht waxes very loud on this because he has been one of the prime-movers in this most base, divisive movement in Australia.
—I am proud to be involved as a leader of it.

—Yes, you are certainly a leader of it, and history will hold you responsible. What we have now is an oath under the constitution for members of parliament, but a very limp, characterless, uninspiring so-called pledge for new citizens which excludes all reference to our nation's head of state, which is the underpinning core of the whole of our constitution. Yet, this government has deliberately and wantonly thrown all of that reference out.

PARA.TAB: Even more disturbing is the fact that the government has referred to the Joint Standing Committee on Migration the review of the Australian Citizenship Act, but in the letter of referral to the migration committee it has excluded any reference to the review of either the pledge or the preamble. The motion which we are debating urges very strongly that the government changes its mind on that aspect. If it does not, I hope that the committee in its deliberations would ignore that edict of the government and do what is absolutely essential to have a proper review of that act.

The Prime Minister has also lambasted our nation's successful and longstanding constitutional arrangements. The integral role of the apolitical head of state has been personally, philosophically and party politically abused. That debate has been damaging to our national unity and character. It has been divisive and completely unnecessary.

I would challenge the Labor Party to introduce in this session its constitutional referendum bill to remove our Australian head of state. Let us take the issue to the people before it further divides Australia, and let us show this so-called government on the other side of the chamber just what Australians think about that.

I cannot in the short time available traverse all the other areas where this Prime Minister and this government have denigrated our symbols and institutions and divided our nation. One has only to think of the arrogance with which the government and the Prime Minister treat the Senate. It is not long ago that the Prime Minister said that the Senate is out of control and that it had to be told that government is made in the House of Representatives. What nonsense and what blatant arrogance. We have seen the denigration of our federal system and the great growth towards centralism. We have seen the denigration of Anzac Day and the downplaying of such things. All these issues are very important and they should be far above party politics. I urge the government to get itself off this very divisive route.
The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Calvert)—Order! The honourable senator's time has expired, and so has the time for the consideration of general business.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President, I raise a point of order. I would like to seek leave of the Senate to make some remarks relating to the independence of this nation, and particularly to this government's involving UN committees in the Australian legal system, something of which Senator Schacht is a very keen supporter.
—No.
—Order! Senator Kemp, leave is not granted. For your information, general business at this time next week may continue with this motion. I am not sure of that but there is a chance that it may.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Joint Select Committee on Certain Family Law Issues

PARA.TAB: Debate resumed from 1 February 1994, on motion by Senator McKiernan:
That the Senate take note of the document.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have pleasure in addressing the government's response to the report of the Joint Select Committee on Certain Family Law Issues. This particular inquiry was one of the most challenging, intense and, in a sense, harrowing inquiries that I have participated in. The inquiry received 1,031 submissions, then something of a record. However, this has now been surpassed by more than 6,000 submissions received for the inquiry which follows the family law inquiry; that is, the one that concentrates on child support and also deals with the resources available to the Family Court. The latter is an extremely important issue and I look forward to the committee tackling it at a very early opportunity.

PARA.TAB: Mr Acting Deputy President, I said `harrowing' because, as we went through the process under your expert and tolerant guidance as the chairman of the committee, I—and, I believe, other members of the committee—realised the limits of legal action which can be taken in such an intensely personal and traumatic area, where people have been hurt and where, in their pain and frustration, they want to hurt their former partner. I say `harrowing' also because the children were likely to be the innocent victims. Everyone would support the Family Law Act, and indeed the Family Court, when the statement is made that the welfare of the child must be paramount. I believe that in all the dealings of the committee—and, I am glad to say, also in the responses from the government—this guideline has been observed.

It is clear that we have a responsibility to construct a legislative framework that is as good as can be achieved to deal with this highly traumatic area of personal concern. In doing so, we need to realise that prevention, education and alternative dispute resolution—alternative to the courts that is—are the areas which we must emphasise to spare the former partners and their children some of the trauma.

Accordingly, I welcome the positive response by the government in a number of areas. In particular, I welcome its acceptance in principle of the committee's view that alternative dispute resolution and mediation processes, as well as counselling and education, should be advanced at a much greater rate. I welcome also the strong commitment to improved enforcement of Family Court decisions.

The government has also adopted one of the committee's recommendations in a somewhat stronger way than I believe the committee expressed it, and that is in the area of pre-nuptial agreements; it has specified a number of welcome guidelines for the way in which this matter should be dealt with.

The government has picked up another area in a stronger way than the committee considered it, and in a very welcome way. I refer to the joint parenting concept, which should, as time goes on, supplant the concept of custody which to some extent carries the implication that the other partner is excluded.

I regret that the government has not responded to some of the additional recommendations that I have put forward relating to facilitating self-representation, the separate legal representation of children, and the treatment of gay and lesbian partnerships in the same way as heterosexual de facto relationships are treated by the court. If this committee system is to provide the benefit to the Senate as a whole that we expect from it, I believe the time must come when the government is asked to respond to dissenting opinions when specific recommendations are made as well as to the majority recommendations.

I return to the government response. I welcome the fact that, where the committee has recommended legal procedures and measures and the government has accepted them, the government has done so with a degree of alacrity and has in fact stated that those things will be implemented and dealt with fairly quickly. However, on the areas that I mentioned before, which in some way are central to the recommendations that the committee made—that is, mediation, counselling, education and training of counsellors to achieve the deployment of people with better qualifications—we find that the government accepts the recommendations in principle but, on no fewer than 15 occasions, then says that the matter must be considered in the light of competing budget priorities. That surely must be disappointing.

The committee has placed on record in a very painstaking way the opinions and the evidence provided by more than a thousand submissions and by several hundred people who appeared before it. I believe it would have been appropriate for the government not only to accept in principle the committee's recommendations for changes and improvements, but also to give the committee the response that it would do its best to find the funds for those recommendations. But in only one case does it say that it will seek to provide additional funds; in all other cases the comment is extremely non-committal. This means that the coming budget consultation process will be central to these considerations. I assure the government that the Australian Democrats will very carefully watch what it does in relation to providing funds for improvements that it has acknowledged in principle to be worth while.

I would add the point that in some areas—domestic violence is one of them—many of the responses that the government has made seem to indicate that it believes enough is being done already. If that is the case now, then the improvement has happened very speedily. If has not happened then the government should accept that the committee would not have reached the conclusions it has on substantial evidence. It is somewhat off-handed for the government to say it believes that this matter is already being attended to by the Family Court or by other agencies. I am somewhat disappointed by the cavalier attitude that the government takes to a number of issues and, in particular, to the issue of domestic violence.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BROWNHILL
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President, may I mention the part that you played in getting a government response now to this very important, very emotional and very traumatic act—the Family Law Act. The people it deals with all the time are those who have concerns and problems, and who obviously have not been getting on. The situation is always full of emotion. As chairman of the committee which investigated the Family Law Act, Mr Acting Deputy President, I believe the part that you played has to receive some commendation, as does the part that Senator Spindler played in supporting my initial moves for an inquiry into this act.

PARA.TAB: It has been a long road. It took quite some time to get the inquiry started and then to get the Attorney-General to enact many of the changes that the committee recommended. No amount of legislative change will remove all of the bitterness and pain of family separation. In trying to get this inquiry going in the first instance, I sought to make the system more equitable, affordable and accessible to all. I believe the committee was able to go some way towards doing that. I thank all my colleagues who supported this inquiry. I thank you, Mr Acting Deputy President, for the part you played as chairman of that committee.

I welcome the government response. The present Attorney-General, Michael Lavarch, was on that committee under your chairmanship, Mr Acting Deputy President. Although we have the government's response, I regret that it has taken a year. Maybe that has a little bit to do with elections and changes of Attorney-General. But change in the legislative process is always slow, and changes to family law appear to be particularly so, as we have seen. I am pleased that the government has picked up many of the committee's recommendations. Senator Spindler has alluded to quite a few of them and I will not repeat them.

The Attorney-General has called this the most far-reaching reform process in family law since the act was first introduced. When the Murphy act was first introduced it was quite dramatic and innovative, and included the change from fault to no-fault. I will not go back to that debate because it has long passed. The act has been going for quite some time and the review has brought out a few things. Mr Lavarch has said that the original concept of simplicity and affordability was never fully realised, and those of us who were on the committee would understand exactly what he means by that. He was on our committee and would well know the number of complaints we had about the cost and complexity in the whole process of the Family Law Act.

The government's response says that it is committed to attacking excessive costs in family law as part of a concerted effort to overcome the wider problem of the financial barriers that ordinary citizens have. That is what this report is about. There are 40,000-odd divorces every year. Even though there may be only 5 per cent of that number who go to the adversarial or legal side of the act, it still applies to everyone. I am particularly pleased that there will be an effort to increase mediation and to reduce the adversarial nature of divorce. Senator Spindler has already alluded to that. Hopefully, in years to come children will not be used as pawns in bitter custody battles. Fairer access and custody procedures might well be the result of the work of this committee.

Children are involved in 59 per cent of marriage break-ups. Each year in Australia the numbers are increasing as divorce rates continue to climb. For their sake it is imperative to get in place legislation that protects them and ensures their very best future. That is what the change in the act was meant to do in the first instance: children were meant to be paramount. I wonder sometimes whether in the last years they have been used only as pawns in the game. I accept the government's refusal to remove the terms custody, access and other emotional terms, but, if we alter the process by which custody and access are achieved, we will at least be removing some of the acrimony. It is impossible to remove it all. No matter how much we change the legislation there will be some who complain that we have not done enough. I believe that the act should be looked at again in a few years time. If there are many complaints and problems with it, it should be amended to make it better. That is what we are meant to do in this place. We look at bills that are put up by the government of the day—and occasionally by a private member—and they become acts after passing through this parliament. We should be making the Family Law Act good, easy to understand and financially accessible to people who divorce once they have decided they cannot live together.

I welcome the assumption of equality as a starting point for property settlements. However, one of the many reasons why the inquiry commenced was to prevent the complete disintegration of the family farm in property settlements due to the adversarial nature of the act. The present system of property settlement is too discretionary and leads to too many inconsistencies and inequities.

The committee heard countless examples of seemingly bizarre property settlements. While not many involved farms, there were enough to make one realise that the present law is unjust. Regretfully, the government wishes to continue this injustice.
