However, the response states that there does not appear to be any basis for differentiating between farming properties and other businesses, and that the Family Court should consider the desirability of preserving that business as an income producing unit. If the Family Court ensures that, in the long run, the children will benefit from the money invested, it will go a long way towards overcoming some of the difficulties that have been created by previous Family Court judges.

For far too long superannuation has been a sticking point that has not been treated with any consistency or equity. I certainly agree with the government response that a new approach is needed. The government says that in the future superannuation will be treated as a discrete asset to which both parties have contributed, directly or indirectly, and from which both parties will be equitably entitled to benefit. I welcome the initiative of the government to convene a working party involving superannuation industry experts to develop a proposal.

Mr Lavarch, as the Attorney-General, sat on the committee, so this matter is now in his court. If he can do something to alleviate all the problems raised in evidence before that inquiry, he will go a long way towards making his mark as being an Attorney-General with the interests of children at heart. This report is all about ensuring that, even though divorce is adversarial in nature, the interests of the children are looked after.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased to have the opportunity to speak on the government's response to the report of the Joint Select Committee on Certain Aspects of the Operation and Interpretation of the Family Law Act while you, Mr Acting Deputy President, as a former chairman of the committee, are in the chair. This evening, you may have to listen to me in utter silence, while as chairman you were able to intervene whenever you felt it appropriate to do so.

PARA.TAB: I was pleased to be a member of the joint select committee, an inquiry which took a reasonable length of time—it could not have been done in less time. The committee had what it then thought to be a fairly large number of submissions—over 1000. That number pales into insignificance when compared to the number of submissions that we have received on the inquiry that we are now undertaking on the operation and impact of the Child Support Agency. Those involved will remember that we recommended to the government that the committee continue its work in this area because of the number of people before the committee who raised access and child maintenance as significant issues. All committee members felt that it was important to present the report dealing with the other aspects of the operation of the Family Law Act and then invite the government to ask us to deal with that which had been left out of the original terms of reference, namely, the Child Support Agency. It will be some little time yet before the committee is in position to report on the agency.

Just about every case that comes before the committee involves the vexed question of child access, as it did so frequently in the previous inquiry. Indeed, the committee made some recommendations on access and about enforcing access and was very aware of the difficulties in this area. Ultimately, a court order can be enforced by putting in gaol any person who does not comply with it. That concept, in relation to child access, is very difficult to come to terms with.

Although the committee has not found all the answers to child access, I am satisfied that the judges of the Family Court of Australia are equally aware of the problems of making access work for all the parties involved, particularly the children. However, there is still work to be done to resolve the issues. Fundamentally, the resolution of access problems in most instances comes down to working out a better relationship between the parents living apart than they obviously had while living together, and in part dealing with the grieving process which is a consequence of the marriage failure, and the hurt that goes with it. Mostly, it is the hurt that still exists on one side or the other, or with both parties, that causes access to continue as a problem.

The inquiry was established in about March 1991 and the committee handed down its report of 120 recommendations in November 1992. We all would have liked to have seen the government's response to that report much earlier than we did. But I, at least, recognised the difficulty of dealing with such an extensive report when an election intervenes and a new Attorney-General is appointed and has to, in a sense, start at the beginning. The report was listed for tabling on the last sitting day last year, but it was not reached as an item of business, so we now have it before us this year.

One can feel pleased that the government has accepted the bulk of the recommendations, although they still have to be put into effect. While less significant in many ways, one of the most important recommendations is that before too long the Family Law Act should be reprinted and consolidated so that it is easier to use. Another issue that we could talk about for some time is the complexity of the act. In its present form it has to be more costly to deal with than if it were reprinted, consolidated and made easier to read.

The original act set out to simplify dissolution of marriage by making it more friendly and so on—we would all recall the rhetoric of 1975. Ten or 12 years ago, the act was about a centimetre thick, but now one almost needs both hands to deal with it. It is a great pity indeed that, like the Taxation Act, this sort of legislation is blossoming.

During the inquiry there was an enormous amount of criticism of the cost of lawyers—much of it, I thought, totally unjust and unwarranted. That is not to say that there are no specific instances where costs have been grossly excessive. But it would be naive in the extreme to suggest that lawyers need not be involved in this area. With counselling and mediation, both parties should be well informed about their rights and what they are embarking upon, otherwise great injustice could follow.

Tonight, I cannot refer to all the issues in the report. However, I support the concept of moving towards mediation where that is likely to be effective. Another recommendation is that the concept of guardianship be retained in the act. I would have liked the committee to suggest that the word `custody' be removed from the whole area. I am pleased to see in its response that the government has formed a preliminary view that there should be a move away from, amongst other terminology, the use of the words `guardianship', `access' and `custody'. I would urge the Attorney-General to follow up that.

The word `custody' is an extremely negative word in this country and in our vocabulary. The word `custody' has within it the concept of being in custody. We may say that it is a superficial reaction to the problem of dealing with children, but people feel they must have custody of a child to assert their ownership of it. The same result can be achieved, but in a way that is less confrontationist.

I would say that custody of children is that which follows from the birth of a child. Those two people who were the parents should have custody—if that word is used at all—for all time. The court should make orders relating to where a child will live and how it may move between its parents, and hopefully its grandparents. I recognise that there would have to be consequential legislation dealing with things like passports, but they are mere bureaucratic details.

Many of our recommendations involved more money, more counselling, more access to interpreters et cetera. The committee has now embarked on an inquiry as to the funding of the Family Court; whether it is adequate for the things that the parliament has asked it to do, and whether it is dealing wisely with the money it has. So anybody reading the report may feel it does not have depth and detail in that respect, but at least we are looking at it.

The big area which still is to be solved in our society is superannuation. I am not entirely happy with the government's response, but I think it flows from the fact that the government has not yet come to terms with retirement income policy in our society. Current superannuation legislation still leaves women the poorer in old age for the want of proper superannuation or a proper retirement income policy.

I look forward to the debate when the government brings forward the legislation relating to the changes in the Family Law Act. It goes wider than just dealing with superannuation as a matter of a property settlement. But I do think the government has not quite grasped the nettle yet in relation to what it intends to do. We have dealt with so many issues, and there are more here. I hope people interested in the area will look at the report and the government's response. I hope they will maintain their interest in the topic. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Environment, Recreation and the Arts Committee

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bell Sen R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the report.

This report is a result of a reference of the Senate on 7 May 1992. That does seem a long time ago, but between the first reference by the Senate and the presentation of this report we did experience an election. Consequent upon the election, we also experienced a change in the chair of the Standing Committee on the Environment, Recreation and the Arts.

The committee found what common sense would expect to reveal on this matter: that there is a long history of the incidence of toxic algal blooms in Australian waterways. In fact, there is evidence to suggest that incidences of those blooms occurred before there was habitation of the Australian continent, either by Aboriginals or by any subsequent occupation. This suggests that such blooms are a natural occurrence. While that may be so, the committee learned that the occupation and exploitation of the land resource of Australia has resulted in an increased incidence of these blooms.

The committee also found that there is an abundance of knowledge in fact and opinions derived from all sorts of sources as to what is the cause of these blooms. The committee found there was plenty of information but not a lot of collation or confirmation.

The information tends to follow the same source; that the blooms were caused either by an abundance of nutrients or reduced turbidity or flow, or an increase in the conditions which are conducive to the growth of the toxic algae. The growth may occur because the algae is not being grazed upon, or because the conditions are so overwhelmingly suitable for that particular part of the ecology that it overwhelms all others.

The blooms, by their very nature, tend to exhaust their nutrients and dissipate of their own accord; or they can be reduced and modified in a number of ways. The most severe way, which is being undertaken by authorities in the United States—I would say fairly typically—is the application of a few explosives, and the bloom was suitably dispersed. In other cases there is an increase in the flow in the water body; and again the bloom can be dispersed.

The fluxion of time allows the bloom to exhaust its nutrients and disappear of its own accord. But nutrients can also be removed either in an immediate sense by mechanical or even chemical means; or they can be removed in the long term by a change in the source of those nutrients. It is that area, the change in the source of the nutrients, which holds the greatest promise for intervention by either government bodies or private individuals.

This knowledge is well held in the community. It is a question of coordination and, I would suggest, the will actually to conduct this removal of the source of nutrients.The committee fairly early in the proceedings found that phosphorus in its various forms was a major contributor to the nutrients. I am a little disappointed that we were unable to find a strong enough recommendation virtually to direct that the sooner we remove the sources of phosphorus from our waterways the sooner we will have a long lasting reduction in the incidence of toxic blue green algal blooms.

Although I did not consider it necessary to use my initiative to create a minority report that came out with some stronger recommendations, I find some dissatisfaction in that we could not get to the stage where we recommended that action be more immediate or effective. I cannot really see any reason why we should extend. For example, recommendation 9 states:

SPEECH.PARA: The Committee recommends that if a significant reduction in levels of phosphorus in detergents has not been achieved within two years then legislation be enacted to reduce levels or to ban phosphates in detergents.

Although that does address the concern about phosphates in detergent, the committee was given evidence about examples in Canada where phosphate levels of detergents were reduced without affecting their effectiveness and where there was a considerable effect upon the incidence of toxic blue green algal blooms.

PARA.TAB: The recommendation, although it does address this problem, is, I would suggest, a bit limp and not quite direct enough. Even though I was a member of the committee, I do not feel at all guilty about suggesting that we could have had stronger recommendations. The evidence is there and those who read the report will probably be able to come to the conclusions themselves—the urgency and the economic advantages which would accrue to Australia in reducing the incidence of those blooms; and the economic disadvantages—the huge amount of money that is wasted in Australia—and the huge amount of social pressure that should be brought to bear upon any authority which has any sort of control at all over our waterways. That, of course, is the other problem—the problem of who does control our waterways, be they internal waterways or be they the coastal waters of Australia. It is a sad indictment of the map drawing skills of our colonial forebears who tended to ignore the biological and the natural geographic boundaries.

While this committee was investigating this matter, it found that the bio-regional concept of the management of our resources transcended the artificial cartographic skills of our former boundary makers. For example, water catchment areas were seen as the most suitable way to determine the boundaries of a group of people who were trying to do something about managing their resources properly. This often involved two, three or even more municipal boundaries, parts of municipal areas and parts of cities. In some cases such bio-regional groups even transcended state boundaries.

The Murray-Darling Basin covers several state boundaries. Any action that is undertaken in that Murray-Darling Basin to try to govern that water resource requires the cooperation of several state governments, the local governments and many other quangos and semi-government authorities. So it is difficult but not impossible, I would suggest. I would recommend that people take very careful note of this report, read it carefully, see the wealth of knowledge it contains and perhaps even see the need to be a little bit more forthright than the recommendations would have us follow. We do need to act urgently on this matter, and I commend the report to the Senate.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: —When the Chemical Weapons (Prohibition) Bill 1993 was before us yesterday I was discussing and putting into context arms control measures in the bill and I was talking about nuclear weapons and the nuclear non-proliferation treaty. I gave only a brief review and, before I leave the subject, I want to make the point that the world has entered into a new age with respect to nuclear weapons. We will see in the decade ahead a huge reduction of the nuclear arsenals and the number of nuclear weapons in the world because of the end of the Cold War. We will not see their total elimination; nevertheless, the reduction will be quite dramatic and the world will be a better and a more secure place as a consequence.

PARA.TAB: While primarily due to the ending of the Cold War, reduction will also be due to the possibility that new weapons systems will provide some alternative to nuclear weapons in a military sense. I do not want to expand on that at this time, but the emergence of precision guided munitions launched primarily from aircraft and secondarily from missiles allows for greater precision in attacking military targets and greater safety because, unlike nuclear devices, they cause no damage to surrounding civilian infrastructure.

The international convention on chemical weapons reflects great credit on the years of work that this government has put into bringing this about and it has, as I said earlier, the full support of all on this side of the Senate. Chemical weapons in the broad sense are poisonous gases, solids or liquids which can be delivered in a variety of ways against human beings. They share some of the characteristics of nuclear weapons that we were talking about before, but they differ markedly in several characteristics: they are usually low cost and readily available, or their precursors are readily available, and are very easy to conceal and transport. Most of the chemical precursors used, as I said a moment ago, are very cheap. They are readily available in the normal industrial or commercial world and their presence is easily explained as having a legitimate commercial purpose. The processing factories wherein the chemical weapons are made are also relatively cheap to establish. In fact, they are very cheap when we compare their cost to the huge cost of enriching nuclear fuel to weapons grade levels, of ultracentrifuges and of the gaseous diffusion process where there is a huge capital outlay.

The cost of a factory to produce chemical weapons is infinitely less and, therefore, much more attainable for nations around the world. It is very easy to conceal and deceive because, quite plausibly in many cases, one could argue that it was a normal chemical factory producing a range of chemicals. Because of all these factors they are very tempting to the less technologically developed and poorer countries of the world.

From a practical point of view, chemical weapons have certain inherent limitations. For example, against dispersed troops in a high wind, there is obviously some limitation to the use of gas. But the other side of the coin is that agents such as nerve gases are really quite devastating in their lethality. Nerve gases are a magnitude beyond the gases that were used in the First World War, to which I referred yesterday when I was talking about lethality.

The two important areas of international arms controls that now need to be addressed by international arms control measures are biological weapons and missiles. The need for control of biological weapons is self-evident, and I do not need to talk about that. But there has been little or no attention paid internationally to the ready availability and the increasingly easy way one can obtain surface-to-surface missiles. I am not necessarily talking about those at the top end of the range—the intercontinental ballistic missiles, which are extremely expensive, very difficult to transport, very difficult to conceal and the presence of which is readily detected by technical inspection means. I am talking about those missiles with a range of between 1,000 kilometres and 5,000 kilometres. They are the problem.

Again, as weapons systems go they are relatively cheap and affordable and they are becoming increasingly easier to obtain internationally. They provide excellent platforms, not only for the delivery of high explosives but also for chemical and biological weapons. One has only to reflect on the effect of these sorts of intermediate range ballistic missiles with biological or chemical warheads, to realise that they are a terror weapon par excellence when they are used against undefended civilian communities. As such, the possession of the missiles is a necessary target for future arms control measures.

The element in the bill which limits its effectiveness is the old enemy of all arms control measures—verification. That problem is common to all the arms control measures that have been put in place. How are we going to inspect and detect the presence of these weapons in another country? The bill provides comprehensive measures but, at the end of the day, governments are like individuals—they can choose to break the law or to be dishonest. When a government chooses to break the law, it has much greater powers of deception and concealment than any individual.

Supporting the verification process in this bill is a procedure called the challenge inspections, whereby one country can request an actual on-site inspection of a facility in another country if there are reasonable grounds to suspect there has been non-compliance with the treaty. In practice, this verification process may prove to have some limitations, but the intention behind it is laudable and, at the present time, the legislative procedures are about as far as they can go. Clearly, in the years ahead, the bill and the treaty itself will have to be upgraded to improve its application and effectiveness. That will come about through improvements in technology whereby verification can be strengthened and through improvements, hopefully, in international goodwill and cooperation.

My criticisms of the verification process are not in any sense an attack on the bill. I do not wish to be seen to be reflecting adversely on the importance of the bill—I believe it is a very important bill—but the criticisms are merely a sanguine recognition of the difficulties inherent in any international arms control legislation. I have not dealt with the details of the bill because, frankly, there is no point in rehashing the minister's second reading speech, which covers the details of the bill in an exemplary way. This bill represents an important and a further step down the path of international arms control. In this particular case, it goes further because it provides for the elimination of one of the weapons of mass destruction. As such, it has our support on this side of the chamber.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chamarette Sen C.M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was extremely fortunate and very proud to be part of the Australian delegation at the signing of the Chemical Weapons Convention in January 1993. Along with former Senator Giles, I attended a conference of the Parliamentarians for Global Action. Both Senator Giles and I were invited by Senator Gareth Evans, in his role as foreign minister, to attend the official opening ceremony at the UNESCO building in Paris. It was an inspiring occasion to hear many of the world leaders espousing the cause of peace. There was a sense of realising the enormous potential in people and nations when they set themselves to work for the positive goals of disarmament and peace.

PARA.TAB: The Parliamentarians for Global Action met for a symposium on the role of parliamentarians in the implementation of the chemical weapons convention concurrently with the signing ceremony. Members of parliaments from 20 nations discussed the responsibilities of parliaments generally to, firstly, introduce and enact legislation to facilitate on-site inspections, to prohibit violations of the convention, and to introduce appropriate sanctions; secondly, to establish a national authority to fulfil the requirements for reporting and provision of international information; thirdly, to review the trade regulations for any inconsistencies with the convention; and, finally, to appropriate funds for the new international authority.

Part of the role of members of the PGA, Parliamentarians for Global Action, was to distribute amongst members model draft legislation, such as the one that had already been prepared by Australia for general guidance. As we travelled to this conference, I was proud to be taking petitions, which had been signed by almost all of the members of our Senate, which later became the model for parliamentarians throughout the world. The petitions served as a model for declarations that parliamentarians could make to assist the progress of the convention within their parliaments.

After having that wonderful opportunity, I saw how this particular convention had broken the ground in several different ways. It was described by the Secretary-General of the United Nations as `a decisive breakthrough in the history of disarmament'. When the convention opened in Paris for signatures, it was the first genuine universal disarmament treaty. It was non-discriminatory in the sense that every nation could declare itself allied with the spirit of this convention, regardless of whether it had already made or was stockpiling chemical weapons. It was thus a very wonderful time to watch representatives of nations coming up and saying, `We have never been associated with the production of chemical weapons; neither do we ever intend to be'. The overwhelming majority of nations clearly appreciated that everyone will benefit from the treaty. At the United Nations General Assembly a year earlier in 1992, a resolution had been co-sponsored by 144 nations and passed by consensus. This eventually lead to the convention being signed from 13 to 15 January 1993.

There are three great advantages to signatory nations. Firstly, the initial multilateral disarmament convention provides for a complete verifiable ban on a whole class of weapons of mass destruction. Secondly, it provides a model of verification which can strengthen other arms control regimes, such as the nuclear non-proliferation treaty. Thirdly, the convention will enhance trade in chemicals under a predictable, internationally agreed regime.
I quote a statement put out by Parliamentarians for Global Action in which Australia received praise for its involvement. It states:

SPEECH.PARA: After more than two decades of discussion at the UN, the pace of negotiation was greatly increased as a result of initiatives taken recently by Australia and like-minded countries. In particular, in 1989 Australia mounted the highly successful Government-Industry Conference Against Chemical Weapons in Canberra in the course of which the International Chemical Industry for the first time affirmed its opposition to chemical weapons and its support for the Convention.

Australia was seen to take the lead, through the so-called Australia Group of countries in our region, in coordinating action taken by countries to control the export of chemicals and equipment which could be used in the manufacture of chemical weapons. Australia also worked effectively to develop a regional consensus against chemical weapons in the South Pacific and South-East Asian region. It is gratifying to note that among the 154 signatories to the convention, all of the nations in these regions were represented.

PARA.TAB: The chemical industries involvement has been crucial to the successful completion of the convention. The task now is for the chemical industry to collaborate fully with governments and other industries to ensure effective implementation of the chemical convention requirements. The need is set for the focus, by participating nations, on the urgent legislative and institution building tasks which we will need in, at least, the initial years.

As Senator Evans mentioned in his second reading speech, only four of the 154 signatories have yet ratified the convention, though many others are preparing for ratification and implementation. It is fitting, therefore, that Australia is the fifth to ratify. Australia is certainly offering assistance, a lead to other nations and encouragement towards the day when the convention will come into effect. This occurs either after 65 countries have ratified it or 13 January 1995.

My colleague Senator Margetts raised some concerns. Having expressed my support of the convention, I too would like to raise, not by casting any aspersions on the convention at all, some features that we need to look at and consider as we go on to participate in this very positive venture. The convention specifically outlines procedures for the prohibition and destruction of chemical weapons. No signatory is to use or to be prepared to use them and undertakes to destroy any existing stocks. It is an impressive achievement, going much further than the current status quo on nuclear weapons under the non-proliferation treaty, as was raised by my colleague earlier in this debate.

I want to focus on the issues associated with the demilitarisation of chemical weapons. The effectiveness and safety of the destruction of the chemical agents and of the costs associated with their destruction pose serious consequences for the environment. The schedule of the Chemical Weapons Convention outlines that:

SPEECH.PARA: Each state shall determine how it shall destroy chemical weapons, except that the following processes may not be used: dumping in any body of water, land burial or open-pit burning. It shall destroy . . . only at . . . appropriate facilities.

The favoured method, unfortunately, is incineration. With tens of thousands of tonnes of chemical agents to be destroyed, we are looking at a huge environmental problem, simply because the incineration process is not a closed system. Emissions escape the combustion train. Also, there are the products of incomplete combustion that disperse into the atmosphere along with the left-over contaminated ash. Worse than this, some nations do not have the funds or the facilities to appropriately deal with the harmful agents. Russia has been a case point of concern ever since the bilateral treaty on the destruction of chemical weapons with the United States.

PARA.TAB: The destruction of chemical weapons can be as bad as using the weapon itself. This was pointed out in a very personal and concerned way by one of the parliamentarian delegates from Russia who said that the concern of people in the local community about the stockpiles was so enormous that they may not be willing to have the destruction occur. The lack of proper environmental protection laws in many countries throughout the world will mirror the problems that have been mentioned in relation to Russia. It could lead to great difficulties and quite damaging consequences, not simply for the environment but for all the people living in those areas and, potentially, for the global situation.

The United States' efforts in keeping its side of the agreement has also resulted in environmentally and politically unsound practices. The US has been stockpiling chemical weapons on Johnston Atoll in the Central Pacific for some years and incinerating them, despite the protests of Greenpeace and neighbouring nations—Kiribati, the Marshall Islands and Micronesia. High temperature incineration of such a huge stockpile of highly toxic weapons ignores the dangers to human populations and wildlife.

There are ways to avoid significant environmental consequences. It is important to distinguish between the demilitarisation of chemical weapons and the detoxification of chemical agents. This would be done by having separate timetables and procedures for them. Demilitarisation is the immediate priority, disassembling them so that they cannot be used as weapons. Detoxification, or disposal, can then take place under stringent controls monitored by the procedures either already in place or to be made available through the sharing of information amongst the member nations of the United Nations.

Once a distinction is made in practice the pressure may be to burn off the agents as quickly as possible. Again I must stress that we need to be aware of the different practices in different countries. There has been a tremendous growth in research and development in technologies for the disposal of chemical agents, especially since the development of the United States and Soviet bilateral agreement and the United States Army decision 12 years ago to prefer incineration. These technologies provide many alternatives relying on incineration, including neutralisation, electro-chemical processes and chemical reprocessing.

It is an imperative for the international community to remove those weapons which can cause so much damage to world peace, and it is commendable to have the convention pursued with vigour and commitment by the Australian government. But while it was exciting to see so many nations sign the convention so that the world might rid itself of chemical weapons and their destabilising influence on fragile military balances, it must be noted that therein lies the only focus of the convention. As so well put in the international citizen's accord on chemical weapons disposal:

SPEECH.PARA: Chemical weapons disarmament requires a comprehensive approach which fulfils international human rights and ecological needs.

There was discussion at the Parliamentarians for Global Action conference regarding the need to also share the financial resources of the wealthier countries to assist those who would be in a very difficult position indeed to find not only the technologies but also the resources with which to put those technologies into place. The international pressure needs to come from nations like Australia which played such an important role in setting it up to ensure the consequences of chemical disposal do not have significant impacts on people and the natural environment.

PARA.TAB: In closing, I would like to acknowledge the role taken by Senator Gareth Evans and his staff in furthering the progress of the Chemical Weapons Convention in the international arena and in this parliament. Their efforts have brought great credit to Australia.

I seek leave to table a document which emanated from the conference I mentioned, Parliamentarians for Global Action. The document is called the Paris statement, and it speaks of the role of parliamentarians in the implementation of the Chemical Weapons Convention. It describes some of the recommendations of the convention. Prior to tabling this, I would like to quote one section for the benefit of colleagues in the chamber as I believe it reinforces the useful action that has been taken by Australia in the whole process. We have now reached a stage where we are actually presenting legislation to this parliament—and I believe this is of great significance—with cross party support.
Part of the commendation that Australia received at the Parliamentarians for Global Action conference in recognition of its efforts read:

SPEECH.PARA: After twenty-four years of discussions and negotiations, the Chemical Weapons Convention has been opened for signature.
With this in mind, we would like to thank all those who helped in developing this treaty and, in particular, Australia, which played a key role.
I conclude by seeking leave to table that document.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President, it will come as no surprise to the Senate that the Australian Democrats strongly support the Chemical Weapons (Prohibition) Bill. The Chemical Weapons Convention which the bill gives effect to is a milestone in international affairs. It abolishes an entire class of weapons—weapons which are among the most inhumane yet invented. It establishes an international verification system which, at least on paper, sets new standards of intrusiveness and effectiveness—a fact that we applaud.

PARA.TAB: The fact that we are debating this bill is due in no small part to Australian efforts and, in particular, to those of the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Senator Gareth Evans), his staff and his department. I do not want to leave anybody out, but the four people I would particularly like to mention here are John Dauth, Richard Starr, Paul O'Sullivan and Martine Letts who did a great deal of the work. I know a lot of others did a great deal of work, but I mention those four in particular.

It is widely acknowledged that Australia played a major role in focussing the international community on the task of bringing the ridiculously protracted talks to a fruitful conclusion. This legislation gives great satisfaction to the Australian Democrats. Throughout the 1980s we consistently argued for major disarmament measures such as this. We were accused of being naive and idealistic; we were told the world was full of despots who could not be trusted to keep their word; that disarmament would simply play into their hands. We were told that of course no country would voluntarily compromise its sovereignty to allow the kinds of intrusive verification measures which are needed.This bill strongly suggests that the cynics were wrong and the idealists—many of them, thank goodness, Australians, I am proud to say—were in fact realists with a bit of vision.

It is a little early to declare absolute victory, though. Few countries have yet ratified the convention and the verification machinery has not been proven in practice. Nevertheless, Australia has nothing to lose by being amongst the first countries to pass the ratifying legislation. We have no chemical weapons—unless there is something the minister has not told us—and can only benefit from the impetus our ratification gives to the spread of the convention. There may be an extra burden on the Australian chemical industry, but it has played a constructive role which recognises the benefits that will ultimately flow to it. The industry deserves to be commended for this very enlightened approach.

Iraq should also be given a perverse sort of credit for its unwitting contribution to the convention. It was the brutal 1988 gassing of Kurds by the Iraqi air force, and the subsequent threatened use of chemical weapons against coalition forces during the Gulf War, which generated the wave of public and political opinion in favour of a global ban. Without detracting from the achievement that this bill represents, it has to be recognised that the really hard disarmament tasks are much further from completion, and some of them have not been started.

I remind the Senate that the Gulf War also highlighted the dangers posed by the trade in conventional arms and nuclear technology. Very little has been done, though, to curb the growth in conventional armed forces and no moves have been made towards a global nuclear weapons ban. We do not even have a comprehensive nuclear test ban treaty yet, although steps have been made in the right direction.

The reality of international politics is that a ban on chemical weapons was more attractive and achievable than these other measures. But when one looks at the tragedies of Cambodia and Afghanistan, it is arguable that, for example, a global crackdown on the production and use of landmines will do a great deal more to prevent human suffering and promote economic development. The Chemical Weapons Convention, as important as it is, can be seen as only one step on a long road. The world cannot afford to rest on its laurels.

The 1990s have so far been a period of unprecedented international cooperation on security matters, of which the Chemical Weapons Convention is a prime example. However, much remains to be done before we can bask in the satisfaction that the world has been made a safer and more peaceful place. The Democrats support this bill, and we look forward to many more in the same vein.

TALKER.NAME: Senator GARETH EVANS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Foreign Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to thank very warmly the Senate and those honourable senators who have spoken—Senator Hill, Senator MacGibbon, Senator Margetts, Senator Chamarette and Senator Bourne—for their support for this legislation and also, of course, for the Chemical Weapons Convention on which it has been based. I want to thank them particularly in each case for the warm words that they have expressed about the role of Australia, the Australian government, Australian officials and, in some cases, me in bringing that convention to fruition.

PARA.TAB: The significance of the Chemical Weapons Convention speaks for itself. Certainly, it has been very well explained by Senator Chamarette this evening, a little more quickly by Senator Bourne and others. There is no need for me to repeat its phenomenally important multilateral disarmament achievement—the first achievement after many years of the conference on disarmament in Geneva, and what we all hope will be a herald of further things to come that are possible in the post-Cold War era.

The successful conclusion of the convention negotiations was a major achievement for Australian diplomacy and one of which I am very proud. It was a demonstration of the kind of effort a country of our size and comparatively limited clout can have if we put to work those resources of energy, stamina and creativity that are abundant among our own officials. I would like to add just a little to what Senator Bourne said about particular individuals within the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade and elsewhere who made such an important contribution to this process.

Within the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade, some were particularly important during the latter stages of the negotiations—the so-called acceleration phase when we initiated the government-industry conference against chemical weapons and, more particularly, the last stages of the treaty negotiation with a draft of our own. The people who mattered most among the chiefs were Mike Costello, the secretary to the department; John Dauth, then the divisional head; Richard Starr, the branch head in the arms control branch; and Paul O'Sullivan, the Australian Ambassador for Disarmament to Geneva.

Among the indians were Martine Letts—who is now on my own staff but was then a key figure in the department—Dr John Gee, Peter Furlonger, Chris Moraitis, Patrick Cole, Ron Morris and Miriam Baxter. Robert Mathews, who received a Medal of the Order of Australia in the general division for service to the control of chemical weapons in the recent Australia Day honours list, was one of those outside the department who was a crucial contributor in that phase, as was Shirley Freeman from the Materials Research Laboratories. Before that, Dr Tim McCormack from Melbourne University was also a major contributor.

At the earlier stage of the negotiations—and after all, this was an exercise, as Senator Bourne said, that went for some 20 years—the key individuals who moved it along in the latter stages of that were Kim Jones, the former divisional head and, amongst the other officers, Jim Silva, Tony Taubman, Bronte Moules, Richard Butler and Richard Rowe. The last two people I mentioned are now at the Australian Permanent Mission in New York. Outside all of those frameworks, I particularly add a reference to Mr Tom Reynolds, the former President of the then Chemical Confederation of Australia who acted as chairman of the industry forum in our 1989 government-industry conference.

Many other departmental officers contributed in various ways to this exercise. It was a massive team effort. The scale and the intensity of it are very difficult to explain to outsiders, but this is probably the most complex piece of international disarmament treaty law that has ever been negotiated—not probably; in fact, it is. All our people, those that I have mentioned—I hope I have not left any of them out—played a very significant role indeed.

I am not denying, as a number of speakers have drawn attention to, that there are still some tasks ahead so far as the convention is concerned, including in particular its ratification and entry into force. One hundred and fifty-four countries—a huge proportion of the UN membership—have already signed the convention. There is only a small number of actual ratifications to date. That does not reflect a lack of interest or, worse, opposition to the convention but rather the reality that it does take time to prepare for national implementation and ratification. We are only now, with the passage of this legislation, in a position ourselves to proceed to ratification, and that is a similar recurring phenomenon elsewhere.

We are still very hopeful that 65 ratifications will be received by mid-July this year to allow entry into force at the earliest possible time, which is January 1995. We have a particular problem in the Middle East, not because of a lack of commitment by many countries there to this convention but, rather, because of the problem of linkage politically we are experiencing between that convention and the Nuclear Non-Proliferation Treaty. A diplomatic task for us in the period ahead is to try to break through that impasse.

There is also the problem of ensuring effective operational implementation of the treaty. We will be spending a quarter of a million dollars to establish our own CWC office. That experience has to be repeated in many other countries. Senator Hill raised some questions about the legitimacy of that order of magnitude of expenditure. I simply say to him that it is based on transferring the Australian Safeguards Office to our own department, but adding to it a layer of specialist expertise which will be necessary in order to be able to perform the really quite complex technical tasks that are involved in the verification process.

Some questions have been asked about the likely efficacy of the verification process in the bill. I simply want to say that that was obviously the crucial and difficult issue that made the negotiations so long and difficult. I genuinely believe that we now have in the convention a workable regime—not only the best that could be negotiated, but a genuinely good regime that will be workable in practice and one which will ensure that we succeed in our objective ultimately of removing altogether from this planet the possession as well as the use of this particularly horrific brand of weapon of mass destruction. It had to be a good regime because no-one has been in any doubt about the peculiarly horrifying character of this weapon and, particularly in the light of the awful experience in the Iran-Iraq war in recent times, building on our earlier historical experience, the awful evidence of just how terrible a weapon it is.

I say finally that I personally perhaps got emotionally as well as intellectually, politically and diplomatically involved in this whole thing as a result of my own experiences in early childhood. I am drawing in this respect on something that Senator MacGibbon said and Senator Collins said by way of interjection during this debate. I remember vividly an uncle of mine who, in my early childhood in the late 1940s, 30 years after his gassing on the Western Front, was still coughing his lungs out in the most heart-rending fashion as a result of that awful experience to which he had been exposed. He eventually died from it shortly thereafter. That is a searing experience for any kid to have. It brought home to me the awful nature of these particular weapons. I guess it is one of the factors that make me very proud indeed that we are now, with the support unanimously of this Senate, able to pass this legislation, implementing in Australia and making possible our ratification of the Chemical Weapons Convention. I thank the Senate and commend the bill to the house.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time, and passed through its remaining stages without amendment or debate.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 10.30 p.m., I put the question:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate do now adjourn.

TALK.START.PARA: —In a mere 200 years of white settlement we have seen the removal of 90 per cent of the natural forests of this once green continent. On the one hand, we now claim to realise the terrifying significance of this ecological tragedy, yet on the other hand we are witnessing not an end to it, but its resurgence on an even more devastating scale.

PARA.TAB: Tonight I advise the Senate of new battle lines being drawn to save one of our most priceless assets, the `great Australian bush'. The ravaging of this, our heritage, is reaching new levels of absurdity in my home state of Tasmania where the Tasmanian Forestry Commission is not only permitting, but actively fostering greed-driven exploitation of our most vulnerable forests, the conditional dry sclerophyll forests. Most of us know these simply as the bush. We take them for granted, as we do our very life's breath. Virtually every Australian has at some time walked, picnicked, played or perhaps even been privileged to live in the bush. We may not all feel directly comfortable in it, but we cannot imagine a land without it. Yet it is there that we are witnessing commercial forestry at its worst, at its most devastating. What we are seeing is ecological madness, and the Tasmanian government through its Forestry Commission proposes to elevate it to a scale which is without precedent in this country.

I and countless thousands of my fellow Tasmanians will not tolerate this, and I give warning tonight that we are about to witness the greatest ecological battle that we have yet to see in Australia. Among the first people to react to the new wave of forest slaughter have been those in and around the Reedy Marsh Forest. It is probably true that few honourable senators will have ever heard of Reedy Marsh. It is an area of unspectacular, typical Australian bush near the picturesque town of Deloraine in Tasmania's mid-north, halfway between Launceston and Devonport. It is a quiet place; nothing special by Tasmanian standards—just a few modest farms, some bush cottages and a quiet population made up of old established families and new settlers, people who have more recently opted to pursue a semi self-sufficient lifestyle in this typical Australian setting.

One of these new settlers, I am sure the Senate will be interested to know, is former Senator Paul McLean, a close friend of mine and someone I visit every chance I get. Paul and his wife, Ingrid O'Sullivan, live in a delightful mud brick cottage deep in the Reedy Marsh Forest. It is within that area that they can now hear the chainsaws, and they, together with many others who live in and around the forest, are enraged by forest practices they are witnessing. They are so enraged that they have formed the Reedy Marsh Forest Conservation Group which has quickly marshalled considerable local and other support.

I have met with some members of the group, and at their suggestion, and accompanied by the group's co-convenor, Mr Andrew Ricketts and Ms Suzi Mannigan, of the Tasmanian Conversation Trust, I have inspected ravaged dry forests from the air and also at ground level.

To visit coupe 469A at Parrot Creek, in the Reedy Marsh Forest, is like a flashback to the devastation that we only ever see in times of world wars. But the magnitude of the tragedy is only appreciated when one realises that in the next few years seven more coupes of equal size are scheduled to adjoin that devastated area and that such devastation may be repeated again and again, even throughout this one forest—the one in which many members of the Reedy Marsh Forest Conservation Group actually live.

Worse still is that this is occurring simultaneously in more than 30 other locations just in Tasmania, and it may be repeated in each one of those areas again and again. These are among our most vulnerable and slowest growing forests, but they harbour a most diverse range of flora and fauna. By the Forestry Commission's own estimates it will take as long as 150 years—that is six generations of humanity—for those areas to grow back, if ever. There is no way of knowing what the area will look like when that regrowth occurs. The reality is that they are irreplaceable and that under such a regime of exploitation the face of Tasmania will be utterly transformed by just the end of this decade.

As Paul McLean put it to me, were he to stand with his grandchildren upon a mound of the clearfell rubble in Parrot Creek coupe not far from his home and look out upon a sea of devastation, they would find no joy in the Forestry Commission's assurance that if these youngsters returned in 50 years with their grandchildren, they would be able to promise them that when they in turn returned with their grandchildren—100 years or more from now—they could be confident that by the end of the lifetime of those youngsters the forest might have grown back again. I am sure none of us would be reassured by that prospect. We must all be enraged alongside the members of the Reedy Marsh Forest Conservation Group.

So, the battle has begun to save, firstly, the remaining dry forests of Tasmania and then those of our whole continent. The Reedy Marsh Forest Conservation Group has been formed to initiate and sustain the dry forest campaign which will save our Australian bush for all future generations.

For the reasons that I will now outline, this new and vigorous group, co-founded by Paul McLean with his neighbour, Andrew Ricketts, must have our whole-hearted support and that of the federal government. They have advised the Tasmanian Minister for Forests, Premier Ray Groom, that the battle lines are drawn and that the group and many other similar groups soon to be formed across Tasmania both challenge and reject current forestry practices which are threatening to destroy those vital forest ecosystems.

Informed and thinking Australians will find their arguments irrefutable, and they are these: firstly, the logging of dry forests of Reedy Marsh and other similar areas is not essential to the saw log industry; secondly, sensible and viable alternatives are currently available to the destructive clearance of our natural forests; thirdly, that woodchipping of these forests does not provide a satisfactory financial return, but paper fibre extraction from alternatives such as kanaf, hemp, grain crop stubble, with a little technological development, offer huge opportunities for the diversification and expansion of agriculture across Australia; fourthly, intrinsic conservation values greatly outweigh the wood production value to Tasmania and to the nation, and priceless and irreplaceable natural forest products are being destroyed for little benefit to Australia; and, fifthly, that a process urgently needs to be established to ensure that Tasmania honours its part of Australia's international obligations. Such a process must: maintain bio diversity; conserve all forest resources and values, including soil and geomorphology; completely identify and protect vulnerable, rare and endangered species; reserve relic vegetation and other known isolated plant communities; fully identify what is there; substantially increase the areas of contiguous protected forested land; and fully buffer all reserves from dangerous forestry operations.

I do not intend to extend this debate in the Senate tonight, but I wish to advise that there are many more aspects to this issue that I will bring to the attention of this chamber. This is the opening salvo of the battle.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gibson Sen B.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is sad to hear Senator Bell raise here in this chamber a matter which is really a state issue, the assumption being that all wisdom resides here in the centre of political life in Australia. To actually suggest that we should take interest in compartment X or compartment Y here or there in a particular part of Australia—that the Commonwealth government has a right to consider and should know all the details of that—I find absolutely unbelievable. The fact is that the Tasmanian Forestry Commission has been a very good manager of forests in Tasmania and, in the Australian and world context, has been an excellent manager.

PARA.TAB: The Resource Assessment Commission in its report last year quite clearly showed that the native forests of Australia are being managed by the various state governments, through their forestry commissions or equivalent departments, on a sustained yield basis; that the accusation by the Green movement, including the Democrats, that the native forests of Australia are being desecrated is just not true; and that the losses of forest values in Australia are due to the fact that we as a community cleared a lot of the forests for the agricultural community. Since that time there has been no substantial loss of forest. In fact, the native forests of Australia have been well managed by state governments, which own about two-thirds of the native forests, and by the private individuals who own the other third.

To suggest that the Commonwealth government should get concerned about particular little areas, such as this one of Reedy Marsh out the back of Deloraine, is absolute nonsense. The underlying assumption is that the residents near there somehow own those forests.

TALK.START.PARA: —A former Democrat senator lives there.
—I know.
—It is just a coincidence.

—Senator Sherry is quite right; that is true. These people are assuming that they own the forests and that forests should be managed for their aesthetic benefit, whereas the forests that we are talking about are owned by the state government and are managed for the community of Tasmania in a very professional and excellent way.

PARA.TAB: I just wanted to put on record that what Senator Bell has been saying tonight is quite misleading to the Senate and to the Australian community and that the fact is that the forests of Tasmania have been and are being well managed. Over the last 10 years about a third of the forests of Tasmania have been locked up in parks of one sort or another, with the largest grab emanating from the Commonwealth government's decision, after the Helsham inquiry, to go to World Heritage areas.
As honourable senators know, the Commonwealth government decision went against the

SPEECH.PARA: recommendations of that inquiry, but that was basically a political decision, and that has been taken. Given that, the green movement, the Democrats and the conservation movement—the anti-development movement—will never be satisfied. Their objective is to take all commercial work out of all native forests in Australia. They will keep moving and agitating to that end.

PARA.TAB: On the contrary, the forest industry of Australia is about 60 per cent dependent on the native forests of Australia. To take the broad ecological view of being consistent with the long-term ecological sustainable yield out of those forests, it is a good thing that they are being managed for multiple use, that is, for wood production as well as conservation, water and other values.

I have had a long history and background in forestry in Victoria and, in the last 20 years, in Tasmania. I can assure the Senate that the forests of Tasmania are not being desecrated. They are being well managed and well looked after.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel, upon notice, on 24 November 1993:

PARA.TAB: (1) How many trained lawyers are there in the Australian Defence Force (ADF).
(2) How many trained para-lawyers are there in the ADF.
(3) How many senior executive service equivalents are there among the permanent lawyers in the ADF.
(4) How does this compare with the Attorney-General's Department.
(5) What is the rank of the senior legal officer in each of the three services.
(6) How many specialist lawyers are members of the ADF.
(7) What is the wastage rate among lawyers in the ADF.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) There are 394 trained lawyers in the ADF. This includes both permanent and reserve officers. Broken down by service, the figures are:
Navy—24 permanent legal officers; 94 reserve legal officers
Army—36 permanent legal officers; 117 reserve legal officers
Air Force—31 permanent legal officers; 92 reserve legal officers.
(2) There are no trained paralegals in the ADF but 2 officers and 3 warrant officers in the Navy occupy positions in which they are required to undertake paralegal duties.

(3) There are 2 senior executive service equivalents among the permanent lawyers in the ADF. One of these officers occupies a legal position with Headquarters ADF. The other is about to take up a non legal position in Headquarters ADF.

(4) In order to obtain accurate figures concerning senior executive service positions within the Attorney-General's Department, the honourable senator should seek such information from the Attorney-General.
(5) The senior legal officers in the three services are:
Navy—Captain
Army—Colonel
Air Force—Group Captain.
The two senior executive service officers are Commodore equivalents.

(6) There are no specialist lawyers in the ADF. All are expected to undertake the full range of duties of a legal officer during the course of their careers. Within the reserve forces, a number of legal officers are Queens Counsel. Some reserve legal officers also hold judicial appointments.
(7) The wastage rate for permanent legal officers in the ADF is:
Total—38.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel, upon notice, on 8 December 1993:

PARA.TAB: (1) Please provide a full list of the branches under each portfolio program which are involved in policy formulation for, or administration of, matters relating to the pay and conditions of defence force personnel.

(2) How many Australian Defence Force members are working in sub-programs related to policy formulation for, and administration of, matters relating to the pay and conditions of defence force personnel.
(3) How many public servants are working in sub-programs related to policy formulation for, and administration of, matters relating to the pay and conditions of defence force personnel.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Faulkner Sen J.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) The following branches are involved in policy formulation for, or administration of, matters related to the pay and conditions of defence force personnel. Pay and Conditions Branch of the Forces Executive Program is responsible only for policy development. Other Branches have mixed responsibilities for policy development and administration.
Forces Executive Program—Pay and Conditions Branch
Budget and Management Program—Personnel Policy Branch; Financial Policy and Operations Branch
Navy Program—Personal Services and Conditions Branch
Army Program—Personnel Support Branch
Air Force Program—Personnel Branch

(2) Some 30 Australian Defence Force (ADF) personnel in Headquarters Australian Defence Force (HQADF), and 31 ADF personnel in the Service Offices, all located in Canberra, work in sub-programs related to policy formulation for, and administration of, matters relating to the pay and conditions of defence force personnel. While Service Offices have a limited role in the development of policy, their major responsibility relates to administration of pay and conditions of service. Three ADF personnel work in the Defence Force Pay Accounting Centre in Melbourne. Below Service Office level it is impracticable to identify those ADF personnel specifically dedicated to the task of pay and conditions administration as they have other clerical duties.

(3) Some 13 APS personnel in HQADF, and 42 Australian Public Service (APS) personnel in the Service Offices, all located in Canberra, work in sub-programs related to policy formulation for, and administration of, matters relating to the pay and conditions of defence force personnel. While Service Offices have a limited role in the develop

ANSWER.PARA: ment of policy, their major responsibility relates to administration of pay and conditions of service. A further 32 APS personnel in the Budget and Management Program, all located in Canberra, are employed on the task. Some of these personnel have responsibilities in relation to policy formulation for, and administration of, Defence civilian staff. Some 147 APS personnel work in the Defence Force Pay Accounting Centre in Melbourne, and, in the regions, a further 64 are involved in the administration of essentially military compensation and rehabilitation.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 12 January 1994:

PARA.TAB: (1) What type of wrist watches were purchased by the Royal Australian Air Force Base, Amberley, Purchasing, with a purchase reference date 23 November 1993, from Citizen Watches Australia Pty Ltd.
(2) What was the total cost of these wrist watches.
(3) How many wrist watches were purchased.
(4) What is the reason for this purchase.
(5) What characteristics make this purchase necessary.
(6) Which personnel will make use of this purchase.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) Citizen `Adventure' watches, catalogue No. T011, part No. JJ0084-07J.
(3) Fifty watches.
(4) The wrist watch forms part of the approved RAAF uniform for personnel on a number of specific duties.

(5) RAAF specifications prescribe that the watches meet criteria including: luminous dial and three hands, hour, minute and second; stopwatch feature; waterproof stainless steel or plastic case; quartz operation, marker every minute, continuous 12 or 24 hour readout with alarm; battery powered with low power indication and interior light for LCD display.
(6) Issue of the watches is restricted to aircrew, ground defence officers, medical staff on active clinical duty, air traffic control officers and members of police dog sections.
